article_title: Constitution Summary
content: Supreme legal document. Longest written constitution. Framework for political code, structure, procedures, powers, duties. Fundamental rights, directive principles, citizen duties. Constitutional supremacy. Ratified 26 Nov 1949, effective 26 Jan 1950. Federal parliamentary republic.

article_title: Sovereign Republic
content: Sovereign socialist secular democratic republic. Justice, liberty, equality, fraternity. Original 1950 preserved in nitrogen case at Parliament Library. Celebrated as Republic Day 26 Jan.

article_title: Previous Legislation
content: Based on Government of India Act 1935 (Samuel Hoare). Nehru Report 1928. British rule 1858-1947. Dominion status 1947-1950. Repealed Indian Independence Act 1947, Govt of India Act 1935 (Art 395). Articles 5-9,60,324,366-367,379-380,388,391-394 effective 26 Nov 1949.

article_title: Assembly Formation
content: Formed 6 Dec 1946 per French practice. First meeting 9 Dec 1946 in Constitution Hall (now Central Hall). J.B. Kripalani addressed, Sachchidananda Sinha temporary president. Muslim League boycotted. 389 members reduced to 299 post-partition (292 provinces, 4 chief commissioners, 93 princely states).

article_title: Leadership Appointments
content: 11 Dec 1946: Rajendra Prasad president, H.C. Mukherjee vice-president, B.N. Rau constitutional advisor. 16 Jul 1948: Harendra Coomar Mookerjee, V.T. Krishnamachari vice-presidents. G.V. Mavlankar first Lok Sabha Speaker.

article_title: Nehru Resolution
content: 13 Dec 1946: Jawaharlal Nehru presented Objective Resolution (became Preamble). 22 Jan 1947: Unanimously adopted. 22 Jul 1947: National flag adopted. 15 Aug 1947: Independence, India-Pakistan partition.

article_title: Committee Formation
content: 29 Aug 1947: Drafting Committee appointed, B.R. Ambedkar chairman. Members: K.M. Munshi, Muhammed Sadulla, Alladi Krishnaswamy Iyer, N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar, Devi Prasad Khaitan, B.L. Mitter.

article_title: Initial Draft
content: B.N. Rau (constitutional advisor): Initial draft Feb 1948, 243 articles, 13 schedules. 14 Aug 1947: Committees proposed. 4 Nov 1947: Revised draft submitted to assembly.

article_title: Sessions and Amendments
content: 11 sessions over 165 days. 7,635 amendments proposed, 2,473 moved/discussed/disposed. 26 Nov 1949: Constitution adopted. 24 Jan 1950: Last meeting, signed by 284 members (395 articles, 8 schedules, 22 parts). 26 Jan 1950: Effective. Cost: 6.4 million, 2yrs 11mos 18days.

article_title: Ambedkar Credits
content: B.R. Ambedkar 25 Nov 1949: Credit to B.N. Rau (rough draft), Drafting Committee (141 days), S.N. Mukherjee (Chief Draftsman), staff. T.T. Krishnamachari: Heavy burden on Ambedkar due to member absences.

article_title: Prominent Members
content: B.R. Ambedkar, Jawaharlal Nehru, Rajendra Prasad, Vallabhbhai Patel, K.M. Munshi, G.V. Mavalankar, Sarojini Naidu, Hansa Mehta, Durgabai Deshmukh, Amrit Kaur, Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit. 30+ scheduled class reps. Frank Anthony (Anglo-Indian), H.P. Modi (Parsis), Harendra Coomar Mookerjee (Christians), Ari Bahadur Gurung (Gorkha).

article_title: Handwritten Constitution
content: Hand-written, decorated by Shantiniketan artists (Beohar Rammanohar Sinha, Nandalal Bose). Calligrapher: Prem Behari Narain Raizada. Published Dehradun, photolithographed by Survey of India. Production: 5 years. Signed in Hindi/English.

article_title: United Kingdom Influence
content: Parliamentary government, nominal head of state, Prime Minister post, powerful lower house, single citizenship, legislative procedure, bicameral legislature, rule of law, cabinet system, legislative speaker, prerogative writ, parliamentary privilege.

article_title: United States Influence
content: Bill of Rights, fundamental rights, written constitution, Preamble, federal structure, impeachment of president, vice president functions, Supreme Court, judicial review, separation of powers, President as commander-in-chief, equal protection.

article_title: Other Countries
content: Ireland: Directive principles, Rajya Sabha nominations, President election. Australia: Concurrent list, trade freedom, joint sessions. France: Liberty/equality/fraternity. Canada: Quasi-federal. Soviet: Fundamental duties, planning. Weimar: Emergency rights suspension. South Africa: Amendment procedure. Japan: Procedure by law.

article_title: Worlds Longest
content: Original: 395 articles, 22 parts, 8 schedules, 145,000 words. Current: 470 articles, 25 parts, 12 schedules, 5 appendices. 106 amendments (latest 28 Sep 2023). Longest active constitution after Alabama.

article_title: Special Status
content: Appendix I: J&K Order 1954. Appendix II: Exceptions/modifications for J&K. Art 370 repealed.

article_title: Quasi-Federal Nature
content: Federal: codified constitution, 3-tier govt, power division, bicameralism, independent judiciary. Unitary: single constitution/citizenship, integrated judiciary, strong Centre, All India Services, emergency powers.

article_title: Presidential Powers
content: Head of executive. Elected by electoral college (Art 55). Acts on Council advice (Art 74). Can return advice once. Signs bills (Art 111). Ordinance power (Art 123).

article_title: Council of Ministers
content: PM heads Council, real executive power. Collectively responsible to Lok Sabha. No confidence motion possible.

article_title: Governors
content: Appointed by President (PM advice), 5-year term. Executes state powers. Generally follows CM advice. Can reserve bills for President, recommend President's Rule (Art 356).

article_title: Article 356
content: President dismisses state govt, assumes direct control if constitutional machinery fails. Judicial review post-S.R. Bommai case.

article_title: Judicial Independence
content: Final arbiter of Constitution. Watchdog against legislative/executive overreach. Protects fundamental rights. Independent judiciary = basic structure. Art 50: Separate judiciary from executive.

article_title: Article 13
content: Pre-constitutional laws void if conflict (Doctrine of Eclipse). Post-constitutional laws void ab initio if conflict. Arts 32,226,227 provide basis. Supreme Court/High Court determine constitutionality.

article_title: Kesavananda Bharati
content: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala: Amendments can't destroy basic structure. Features: supremacy, republican democratic form, secularism, separation of powers, federal character.

article_title: Golaknath Minerva Mills
content: Golaknath (1967): Fundamental rights unamendable (overturned). Minerva Mills: Judicial review = basic structure. S.R. Bommai: President's Rule judicial review. 24th Amendment (1971) response.

article_title: Article 368
content: 2/3 majority both Houses (present/voting). Federal amendments need state ratification. No joint session. Most frequently amended constitution. 106 amendments (latest 28 Sep 2023).

article_title: 42nd 44th Amendments
content: 38th Amendment: No judicial review during emergency. 42nd Amendment: Widened Art 31C, added 368(4)(5). Minerva Mills struck down 31C expansion, 368(4)(5). 44th restored judicial review.

article_title: Single Hierarchy
content: High Courts constituted by Constitution. State lower courts under High Courts. Appeals to Supreme Court. Integrated federalism (unlike US federal/state courts).

article_title: Article 123
content: President ordinances when Parliament not in session. Expire 6 weeks after reassembly. Used ~10/year recently, abused for bypassing opposition.

article_title: Seventh Schedule State List
content: Police, public health/order, agriculture, land revenue, local government. Only state legislatures can legislate. Centre temporarily via Rajya Sabha 2/3 vote (1 year).

article_title: Seventh Schedule Union List
content: Defense, foreign affairs, banking, currency, railways, atomic energy, interstate trade. Exclusive Union jurisdiction.

article_title: Seventh Schedule Concurrent
content: Criminal law, marriage, contracts, education, forests, trade unions. Union law prevails over state law. State override with President consent.

article_title: Unlisted Powers
content: Powers not in any list vest with Union (unlike Canada).

article_title: Article 3
content: Parliament creates new states, alters boundaries by simple law. States consulted but no veto. Recent: Telangana (2014), Ladakh UT (2019), Daman&Diu merger (2020).

article_title: States Representation
content: States represented per population (4th Schedule). Co-equal with Lok Sabha except money bills. 2/3 vote for amendments. Temporary state list takeover.

article_title: Electoral College
content: Elected by electoral college: Parliament + state legislatures. Secret single transferable vote. Half votes by population proportion.

article_title: Article 111
content: President assent required for bills. Can return once. Parliament resubmits = must assent.

article_title: Pleasure of President
content: PM/Council holds office during President's pleasure. Never exercised. Zail Singh threatened Rajiv Gandhi (1987).

article_title: Appointment Powers
content: Appointed by President (PM advice). 5-year term, removable anytime. Can delay bills, send to President.

article_title: Dualist System
content: President makes treaties (PM advice). Parliament implements via domestic law (Art 253). Recent SC: Direct incorporation of int'l law.

article_title: Venkatachaliah Commission
content: Term-based law commissions recommend reforms. 2000 Venkatachaliah Commission report (2002) not implemented.

article_title: 73rd Amendment
content: 73rd Amendment: Panchayati Raj rural local govt. 11th Schedule: 29 subjects.

article_title: 74th Amendment
content: 74th Amendment: Municipalities/Nagar Palikas. 12th Schedule: 18 subjects.

article_title: IAS IFS IPS
content: All India Services (IAS, IFS, IPS): Central control over state administration.

article_title: No Dual Citizenship
content: Single citizenship for Union and states (unlike US).

content: National emergency declaration. Suspends fundamental rights.

article_title: Article 360
content: Financial emergency provisions.

article_title: National Law Day

article_title: Assembly Cost
content: Constituent Assembly cost: 6.3-6.4 crore rupees. Process: 2 years, 11 months, 18 days.

article_title: Most Amended
content: World's most frequently amended constitution. 106 amendments. Specific provisions need statutory changes elsewhere.

article_title: Member Absences

content: Struck down 42nd Amendment's Art 31C expansion, 368(4)(5). Judicial review = basic structure of Constitution.

article_title: S.R. Bommai v. Union

article_title: Pre-Constitutional Laws

article_title: Gramophone Case

1947-1950: Dominion of UK. Princely states integrated by Nehru, Patel, Mountbatten. British handled external security.

article_title: Basic Structure Protection
content: Parliament amends to basic structure limit only. Supreme Court/High Court declare violating amendments void.

article_title: Federal with Unitary Bias
content: Federal in form, unitary in spirit. Strong Centre dominates. Single constitution, citizenship, judiciary. Centre appoints governors, All India Services, emergency powers, residual powers.

article_title: Unlike US System
content: Single judicial hierarchy. High Courts directly by Constitution. State courts under High Courts. Appeals to Supreme Court for federal/state matters.

article_title: No Joint Sitting
content: Constitutional amendments: No joint session Lok Sabha/Rajya Sabha (unlike ordinary bills). Both houses need 2/3 majority separately.

article_title: Ordinance Misuse
content: Ordinances bypass opposition-controlled Rajya Sabha. ~10/year recently, peak 30+/year. Topics: land rights, COVID response, banking.

article_title: State Ratification

article_title: Special Status Ended

article_title: Part III Articles 12-35
content: Rights against State. Justiciable. Six categories: equality, freedom, exploitation prohibition, religion freedom, cultural/educational, constitutional remedies (Art 32). Borrowed from US Bill of Rights.

article_title: Articles 14-18 Equality
content: Art 14: Equality before law. Art 15: No discrimination. Art 16: Equal opportunity employment. Art 17: Untouchability abolished. Art 18: Abolition of titles.

article_title: Articles 19-22 Freedom
content: Art 19: Six freedoms (speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, profession) with reasonable restrictions. Art 20: Criminal convictions protection. Art 21: Life/liberty. Art 22: Arrest/detention.

article_title: Articles 23-24
content: Art 23: Traffic in humans, forced labour prohibited. Art 24: Child labour under 14 prohibited in factories/mines.

article_title: Articles 25-28
content: Art 25: Freedom of conscience/religion. Art 26: Religious institutions management. Art 27: No taxes for religion promotion. Art 28: No religious instruction in state institutions.

article_title: Articles 29-30
content: Art 29: Minority language/culture protection. Art 30: Minorities right to educational institutions.

article_title: Article 32 Heart and Soul
content: Art 32: Right to constitutional remedies. Writs: habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, certiorari, quo warranto. Dr. Ambedkar: 'Heart and soul' of Constitution.

article_title: Article 51A
content: 11 duties added by 42nd Amendment 1976 (Soviet influence). Abide Constitution, respect ideals, protect sovereignty/unity, defend country, promote harmony, protect environment, scientific temper, safeguard public property, strive excellence.

article_title: 11 Duties Detailed
content: 1. Abide Constitution/flag. 2. Cherish freedom struggle. 3. Uphold sovereignty/unity. 4. Defend country. 5. Promote harmony/ brotherhood. 6. Value composite culture. 7. Protect environment/wildlife. 8. Develop scientific temper. 9. Safeguard public property. 10. Strive excellence. 11. Provide education to children 6-14.

article_title: Reasonable Restrictions
content: Art 19 freedoms subject to reasonable restrictions: state security, public order, decency, morality, defamation, contempt of court, friendly relations with foreign states, incitement to offence.

article_title: Emergency Suspension
content: National emergency (Art 352): Fundamental rights suspension except Arts 20,21. 44th Amendment: Art 21 can't be suspended.

article_title: Non-Justiciable vs Justiciable
content: Fundamental Rights (Part III): Justiciable. Directive Principles (Part IV): Non-justiciable, moral obligation. Irish Constitution influence.

article_title: Part IV Overview
content: Non-justiciable guidelines for State welfare, social justice. Irish Constitution influence. Fundamental to governance (Art 37). Promote social/economic democracy.

article_title: Economic Justice
content: Art 39: Adequate livelihood, resource distribution. Art 41: Work, education, assistance. Art 43: Living wage, worker participation.

article_title: Village Development
content: Art 40: Village panchayats. Art 43: Cottage industries. Art 47: Cow protection, prohibition. Art 48: Agriculture, animal husbandry.

article_title: Social Reforms
content: Art 44: Uniform civil code. Art 39A: Free legal aid. Art 45: Early childhood education. Art 51: International peace.

article_title: Article 37
content: Non-enforceable by court. Fundamental in governance. State shall apply in law-making.

article_title: 42nd Amendment 1976
content: Added Art 39A (legal aid), 43A (worker participation), 48A (environment protection).

article_title: 44th & 86th Amendments
content: 44th (1978): Modified Art 45. 86th (2002): Art 21A made education Fundamental Right.

article_title: FR vs DPSP Conflicts
content: Champakam Dorairajan (1951): FRs prevail. Kesavananda Bharati (1973): Harmonious construction.

article_title: Article 39
content: Ownership means of production distributed for common good. Wealth concentration prevention.

article_title: Article 44
content: State shall secure Uniform Civil Code for all citizens.

article_title: Article 48A
content: Protect environment, forests, wildlife. Added 42nd Amendment 1976.

article_title: Article 43A
content: Worker participation in industry management. Added 42nd Amendment 1976.

article_title: WE, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA
content: WE, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA, having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC and to secure to all its citizens: JUSTICE, social, economic and political; LIBERTY of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship: EQUALITY of status and of opportunity; and to promote among them all FRATERNITY assuring the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the Nation; IN OUR CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY this twenty-sixth day of November, 1949, do HEREBY ADOPT, ENACT AND GIVE TO OURSELVES THIS CONSTITUTION.

sub_sections.text: SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC
JUSTICE, social, economic and political
LIBERTY of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship
EQUALITY of status and of opportunity
FRATERNITY assuring the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the Nation

amendments_notes: The phrase 'SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC' was substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, s.2, for 'SOVEREIGN DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC' (w.e.f. 3-1-1977). The phrase 'unity and integrity of the Nation' was substituted by s. 2, ibid., for 'Unity of the Nation' (w.e.f. 3-1-1977).

article_title: Name and territory of the Union.
content: India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States. The States and the territories thereof shall be as specified in the First Schedule. The territory of India shall comprise the territories of the States; the Union territories specified in the First Schedule; and such other territories as may be acquired.

sub_sections.text: India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States.
The States and the territories thereof shall be as specified in the First Schedule.
The territory of India shall comprise the territories of the States; the Union territories specified in the First Schedule; and such other territories as may be acquired.

amendments_notes: Clause (2) was substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, s. 2, for cl. (2) (w.e.f. 1-11-1956). Sub-clause (b) of Clause (3) was substituted by s. 2 ibid. for sub-clause (b) (w.e.f. 1-11-1956).

article_title: Admission or establishment of new States.
content: Parliament may by law admit into the Union, or establish, new States on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.
amendments_notes: Article 2A: 'Sikkim to be associated with the Union' was omitted by the Constitution (Thirty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1975, s. 5 (w.e.f. 26-4-1975).

article_title: Formation of new States and alteration of areas, boundaries or names of existing States.
content: Parliament may by law form a new State by separation of territory from any State or by uniting two or more States or parts of States or by uniting any territory to a part of any State; increase the area of any State; diminish the area of any State; alter the boundaries of any State; alter the name of any State. Provided that no Bill for the purpose shall be introduced in either House of Parliament except on the recommendation of the President and unless, where the proposal contained in the Bill affects the area, boundaries or name of any of the States, the Bill has been referred by the President to the Legislature of that State for expressing its views thereon within such period as may be specified in the reference or within such further period as the President may allow and the period so specified or allowed has expired. Explanation I: 'State' includes a Union territory, but in the proviso, 'State' does not include a Union territory. Explanation II: The power conferred on Parliament by clause (a) includes the power to form a new State or Union territory by uniting a part of any State or Union territory to any other State or Union territory.

sub_sections.text: form a new State by separation of territory from any State or by uniting two or more States or parts of States or by uniting any territory to a part of any State;
increase the area of any State;
diminish the area of any State;
alter the boundaries of any State;
alter the name of any State:

amendments_notes: The original proviso was substituted by the Constitution (Fifth Amendment) Act, 1955. Words were omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956. Explanations I and II were inserted by the Constitution (Eighteenth Amendment) Act, 1966.

article_title: Laws made under articles 2 and 3 to provide for the amendment of the First and the Fourth Schedules and supplemental, incidental and consequential matters.
content: Any law referred to in article 2 or article 3 shall contain such provisions for the amendment of the First Schedule and the Fourth Schedule as may be necessary to give effect to the provisions of the law and may also contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions (including provisions as to representation in Parliament and in the Legislature or Legislatures of the State or States affected by such law) as Parliament may deem necessary. No such law as aforesaid shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.

sub_sections.text: Any law referred to in article 2 or article 3 shall contain such provisions for the amendment of the First Schedule and the Fourth Schedule as may be necessary to give effect to the provisions of the law and may also contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions (including provisions as to representation in Parliament and in the Legislature or Legislatures of the State or States affected by such law) as Parliament may deem necessary.
No such law as aforesaid shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.

article_title: Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution.
content: At the commencement of this Constitution, every person who has his domicile in the territory of India and who was born in the territory of India; or either of whose parents was born in the territory of India; or who has been ordinarily resident in the territory of India for not less than five years immediately preceding such commencement, shall be a citizen of India.

sub_sections.text: every person who has his domicile in the territory of India and
who was born in the territory of India; or
either of whose parents was born in the territory of India; or
who has been ordinarily resident in the territory of India for not less than five years immediately preceding such commencement, shall be a citizen of India.

article_title: Rights of citizenship of certain persons who have migrated to India from Pakistan.
content: Notwithstanding anything in article 5, a person who has migrated to the territory of India from the territory now included in Pakistan shall be deemed to be a citizen of India at the commencement of this Constitution if he or either of his parents or any of his grand-parents was born in India as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935 (as originally enacted); and in the case where such person has so migrated before the nineteenth day of July, 1948, he has been ordinarily resident in the territory of India since the date of his migration, or in the case where such person has so migrated on or after the nineteenth day of July, 1948, he has been registered as a citizen of India by an officer appointed in that behalf by the Government of the Dominion of India on an application made by him therefor to such officer before the commencement of this Constitution in the form and manner prescribed by that Government. No person shall be so registered unless he has been resident in the territory of India for at least six months immediately preceding the date of his application.

article_title: Rights of citizenship of certain migrants to Pakistan.
content: Notwithstanding anything in articles 5 and 6, a person who has after the first day of March, 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India. Provided that nothing in this article shall apply to a person who, after having so migrated to the territory now included in Pakistan, has returned to the territory of India under a permit for resettlement or permanent return issued by or under the authority of any law and every such person shall for the purposes of clause (b) of article 6 be deemed to have migrated to the territory of India after the nineteenth day of July, 1948.

article_title: Rights of citizenship of certain persons of Indian origin residing outside India.
content: Notwithstanding anything in article 5, any person who or either of whose parents or any of whose grand-parents was born in India as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935 (as originally enacted), and who is ordinarily residing in any country outside India as so defined shall be deemed to be a citizen of India if he has been registered as a citizen of India by the diplomatic or consular representative of India in the country where he is for the time being residing on an application made by him therefor to such diplomatic or consular representative, whether before or after the commencement of this Constitution, in the form and manner prescribed by the Government of the Dominion of India or the Government of India.

article_title: Persons voluntarily acquiring citizenship of a foreign State not to be citizens.
content: No person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of article 5, or be deemed to be a citizen of India by virtue of article 6 or article 8, if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State.

article_title: Continuance of the rights of citizenship.
content: Every person who is or is deemed to be a citizen of India under any of the foregoing provisions of this Part shall, subject to the provisions of any law that may be made by Parliament, continue to be such citizen.

article_title: Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.
content: Nothing in the foregoing provisions of this Part shall derogate from the power of Parliament to make any provision with respect to the acquisition and termination of citizenship and all other matters relating to citizenship.

article_title: Definition.
content: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

article_title: Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights.
content: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void. In this article, unless the context otherwise requires, 'law' includes any Ordinance, order, bye-law, rule, regulation, notification, custom or usage having in the territory of India the force of law; and 'laws in force' includes laws passed or made by a Legislature or other competent authority in the territory of India before the commencement of this Constitution and not previously repealed, notwithstanding that any such law or any part thereof may not be then in operation either at all or in particular areas. Nothing in this article shall apply to any amendment of this Constitution made under article 368.

article_title: Equality before law.
content: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

article_title: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth.
content: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment; or the use of wells, tanks, bathing ghats, roads and places of public resort maintained wholly or partly out of State funds or dedicated to the use of the general public. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women and children. Nothing in this article or in clause (2) of article 29 shall prevent the State from making any special provision for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes. Nothing in this article or in sub-clause (g) of clause (1) of article 19 shall prevent the State from making any special provision, by law, for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes in so far as such special provisions relate to their admission to educational institutions including private educational institutions, whether aided or unaided by the State, other than the minority educational institutions referred to in clause (1) of article 30. Nothing in this article or sub-clause (g) of clause (1) of article 19 or clause (2) of article 29 shall prevent the State from making any special provision for the advancement of any economically weaker sections of citizens other than the classes mentioned in clauses (4) and (5); and any special provision for the advancement of any economically weaker sections of citizens other than the classes mentioned in clauses (4) and (5) in so far as such special provisions relate to their admission to educational institutions including private educational institutions, whether aided or unaided by the State, other than the minority educational institutions referred to in clause (1) of article 30, which in the case of reservation would be in addition to the existing reservations and subject to a maximum of ten per cent. of the total seats in each category. 'Economically weaker sections' shall be such as may be notified by the State from time to time on the basis of family income and other indicators of economic disadvantage.

article_title: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.
content: There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of, any employment or office under the State. Nothing in this article shall prevent Parliament from making any law prescribing, in regard to a class or classes of employment or appointment to an office under the Government of, or any local or other authority within, a State or Union territory, any requirement as to residence within that State or Union territory prior to such employment or appointment. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for the reservation of appointments or posts in favour of any backward class of citizens which, in the opinion of the State, is not adequately represented in the services under the State. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for reservation in matters of promotion, with consequential seniority, to any class or classes of posts in the services under the State in favour of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes which, in the opinion of the State, are not adequately represented in the services under the State. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from considering any unfilled vacancies of a year which are reserved for being filled up in that year in accordance with any provision for reservation made under clause (4) or clause (4A) as a separate class of vacancies to be filled up in any succeeding year or years and such class of vacancies shall not be considered together with the vacancies of the year in which they are being filled up for determining the ceiling of fifty per cent. reservation on total number of vacancies of that year. Nothing in this article shall affect the operation of any law which provides that the incumbent of an office in connection with the affairs of any religious or denominational institution or any member of the governing body thereof shall be a person professing a particular religion or belonging to a particular denomination. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for the reservation of appointments or posts in favour of any economically weaker sections of citizens other than the classes mentioned in clause (4), in addition to the existing reservation and subject to a maximum of ten per cent. of the posts in each category.

article_title: Abolition of Untouchability.
content: 'Untouchability' is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of 'Untouchability' shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law.

article_title: Abolition of titles.
content: No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State. No citizen of India shall accept any title from any foreign State. No person who is not a citizen of India shall, while he holds any office of profit or trust under the State, accept without the consent of the President any title from any foreign State. No person holding any office of profit or trust under the State shall, without the consent of the President, accept any present, emolument, or office of any kind from or under any foreign State.

article_title: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc.
content: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions or co-operative societies; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practise any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business. Nothing in sub-clause (a) of clause (1) shall affect the operation of any existing law, or prevent the State from making any law, in so far as such law imposes reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by the said sub-clause in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation or incitement to an offence. Nothing in sub-clause (b) of the said clause shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it imposes, or prevent the State from making any law imposing, in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India or public order, reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by the said sub-clause. Nothing in sub-clause (c) of the said clause shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it imposes, or prevent the State from making any law imposing, in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India or public order or morality, reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by the said sub-clause. Nothing in sub-clauses (d) and (e) of the said clause shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it imposes, or prevent the State from making any law imposing, reasonable restrictions on the exercise of any of the rights conferred by the said sub-clauses either in the interests of the general public or for the protection of the interests of any Scheduled Tribe. Nothing in sub-clause (g) of the said clause shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it imposes, or prevent the State from making any law imposing, in the interests of the general public, reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by the said sub-clause, and, in particular, nothing in the said sub-clause shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it relates to, or prevent the State from making any law relating to, the professional or technical qualifications necessary for practising any profession or carrying on any occupation, trade or business; or the carrying on by the State, or by a corporation owned or controlled by the State, of any trade, business, industry or service, whether to the exclusion, complete or partial, of citizens or otherwise.

article_title: Protection in respect of conviction for offences.
content: No person shall be convicted of any offence except for violation of a law in force at the time of the commission of the Act charged as an offence, nor be subjected to a penalty greater than that which might have been inflicted under the law in force at the time of the commission of the offence. No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once. No person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself.

[cite: 594]

article_title: Protection of life and personal liberty.
content: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

article_title: Right to education.
content: The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Eighty-sixth Amendment) Act, 2002, s.  2 (w.e.f. 1-4-2010). [cite: 596]

article_title: Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases.
content: No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds for such arrest nor shall he be denied the right to consult, and to be defended by, a legal practitioner of his choice. Every person who is arrested and detained in custody shall be produced before the nearest magistrate within a period of twenty-four hours of such arrest excluding the time necessary for the journey from the place of arrest to the court of the magistrate and no such person shall be detained in custody beyond the said period without the authority of a magistrate. These provisions shall not apply to any person who for the time being is an enemy alien; or to any person who is arrested or detained under any law providing for preventive detention. No law providing for preventive detention shall authorise the detention of a person for a longer period than three months unless an Advisory Board has reported before the expiration of the said period that there is sufficient cause for such detention (subject to Parliament prescribing a maximum period). When any person is detained, the authority making the order shall communicate the grounds and afford the earliest opportunity for a representation, though facts against public interest need not be disclosed. Parliament may prescribe by law the circumstances and cases for longer detention without an Advisory Board opinion, the maximum period of detention, and the Advisory Board procedure.

article_title: Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour.
content: Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from imposing compulsory service for public purposes, and in imposing such service the State shall not make any discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste or class or any of them.

sub_sections.text: Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour (including begar).  Contravention is a punishable offence. [cite: 617]
Permits the State to impose compulsory service for public purposes, provided there is no discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste or class. [cite: 617]

article_title: Prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc.
content: No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.

article_title: Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and propagation of religion.
content: Subject to public order, morality and health and to the other provisions of this Part, all persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practice and propagate religion. Nothing in this article shall affect the operation of any existing law or prevent the State from making any law regulating or restricting any economic, financial, political or other secular activity which may be associated with religious practice; or providing for social welfare and reform or the throwing open of Hindu religious institutions of a public character to all classes and sections of Hindus. The wearing and carrying of kirpans shall be deemed to be included in the profession of the Sikh religion. Reference to Hindus shall be construed as including a reference to persons professing the Sikh, Jaina or Buddhist religion, and the reference to Hindu religious institutions shall be construed accordingly.

article_title: Freedom to manage religious affairs.
content: Subject to public order, morality and health, every religious denomination or any section thereof shall have the right to establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes; to manage its own affairs in matters of religion; to own and acquire movable and immovable property; and to administer such property in accordance with law.

to own and acquire movable and immovable property. [cite: 625]
to administer such property in accordance with law. [cite: 626]

article_title: Freedom as to payment of taxes for promotion of any particular religion.
content: No person shall be compelled to pay any taxes, the proceeds of which are specifically appropriated in payment of expenses for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion or religious denomination.

article_title: Freedom as to attendance at religious instruction or religious worship in certain educational institutions.
content: No religious instruction shall be provided in any educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds. This shall not apply to an educational institution which is administered by the State but established under an endowment or trust requiring religious instruction. No person attending any educational institution recognised by the State or receiving aid out of State funds shall be required to take part in any religious instruction or worship without their or their guardian's consent.

Attendance at religious instruction or worship in State-recognised or State-aided institutions is voluntary (requires consent of the person or their guardian). [cite: 628]

article_title: Protection of interests of minorities.
content: Any section of the citizens residing in the territory of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to conserve the same. No citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

sub_sections.text: Any section of the citizens having a distinct language, script or culture shall have the right to conserve the same. [cite: 629]

No citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them. [cite: 629]

article_title: Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions.
content: All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. In making any law providing for the compulsory acquisition of any property of a minority educational institution, the State shall ensure that the amount fixed is such as would not restrict or abrogate the right guaranteed. The State shall not, in granting aid to educational institutions, discriminate against any educational institution on the ground that it is under the management of a minority, whether based on religion or language.

sub_sections.text: All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. [cite: 630]

The State shall not discriminate in granting aid to educational institutions managed by a minority. [cite: 633]

article_title: [Compulsory acquisition of property.]
content: This article was omitted.

article_title: Saving of laws providing for acquisition of estates, etc.
content: Notwithstanding anything contained in article 13, no law providing for the acquisition by the State of any estate or rights therein; taking over of management of any property; amalgamation of corporations; extinguishment or modification of rights of directors/managers of corporations; or extinguishment or modification of mining rights shall be void on the ground of inconsistency with Article 14 or Article 19. Laws of a State require the President's assent. Where an estate land is acquired from personal cultivation, it must provide for compensation at a rate not less than the market value for land within the ceiling limit. 'Estate' and 'rights' are defined broadly in relation to local land tenures.

sub_sections.text: Laws for the acquisition/modification of rights in estates, taking over management of property, amalgamation of corporations, extinguishment of corporate management rights, or modification of mining rights cannot be held void for contravening Article 14 or Article 19. [cite: 637, 638, 639, 643]
A State law under this article requires the President's assent. [cite: 644]
Compensation at market value is mandatory for acquisition of land within the ceiling limit that is under personal cultivation. [cite: 644]

Definition of 'estate' includes jagir, inam, muafi, janmam rights, ryotwari settlement lands, and agricultural lands (including waste, forest, pasture, sites of buildings for cultivators/labourers/artisans). [cite: 645, 646, 647, 649]

Definition of 'rights' in relation to an estate includes rights of proprietors, sub-proprietors, tenure-holders, raiyats, under-raiyats, or other intermediaries, and rights in respect of land revenue. [cite: 651, 654]

[cite: 648]

article_title: Validation of certain Acts and Regulations.
content: Without prejudice to the generality of the provisions contained in article 31A, none of the Acts and Regulations specified in the Ninth Schedule nor any of the provisions thereof shall be deemed to be void, or ever to have become void, on the ground that such Act, Regulation or provision is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by, any provisions of this Part, and notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any court or Tribunal to the contrary, each of the said Acts and Regulations shall, subject to the power of any competent Legislature to repeal or amend it, continue in force.
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951. [cite: 652, 654]

article_title: Saving of laws giving effect to certain directive principles.
content: Notwithstanding anything contained in article 13, no law giving effect to the policy of the State towards securing all or any of the principles laid down in Part IV shall be deemed to be void on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by article 14 or article 19; and no law containing a declaration that it is for giving effect to such policy shall be called in question in any court on the ground that it does not give effect to such policy. State laws require the President's assent.

sub_sections.text: No law giving effect to the policy of the State towards securing all or any of the principles laid down in Part IV shall be deemed to be void on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by Article 14 or Article 19. [cite: 652, 654, 655]
State laws require the President's assent. [cite: 653]

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-fifth Amendment) Act, 1971. [cite: 654]  The words 'all or any of the principles laid down in Part IV' substituted for 'the principles specified in clause (b) or clause (c) of article 39' by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 (Section 4 has been declared invalid by the Supreme Court). [cite: 654]  Reference to Article 14 or 19 substituted for Article 14, 19 or 31 by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 654]  The italicized portion regarding the declaration clause was struck down by the Supreme Court. [cite: 655]

article_title: [Saving of laws in respect of anti-national activities.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977. [cite: 653]

article_title: Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part.
content: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions, orders or writs, including habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, for the enforcement of any of the rights. Parliament may, by law, empower any other court to exercise these powers. The right guaranteed by this article shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided for by this Constitution.

sub_sections.text: The right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. [cite: 658]
The Supreme Court has the power to issue directions, orders or writs (habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto, certiorari) for the enforcement of the rights. [cite: 658]
Parliament may, by law, empower any other court to exercise these powers. [cite: 659]
The right guaranteed shall not be suspended except as provided by the Constitution. [cite: 659]

article_title: [Constitutional validity of State laws not to be considered in proceedings under article 32.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977. [cite: 660]

article_title: Power of Parliament to modify the rights conferred by this Part in their application to Forces, etc.
content: Parliament may, by law, determine to what extent any of the rights conferred by this Part shall be restricted or abrogated in their application to members of the Armed Forces; members of Forces charged with public order; persons employed in intelligence or counter intelligence organisations; or persons employed in telecommunication systems for those Forces/organisations, to ensure the proper discharge of their duties and maintenance of discipline.
amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Fiftieth Amendment) Act, 1984. [cite: 663]

article_title: Restriction on rights conferred by this Part while martial law is in force in any area.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Part, Parliament may by law indemnify any person in the service of the Union or of a State or any other person in respect of any act done by him in connection with the maintenance or restoration of order in any area within India where martial law was in force or validate any sentence passed, punishment inflicted, forfeiture ordered or other act done under martial law in such area.

article_title: Legislation to give effect to the provisions of this Part.
content: Parliament shall have exclusive power to make laws with respect to matters under Article 16(3), Article 32(3), Article 33, and Article 34, and for prescribing punishment for offences under this Part. Existing laws in force immediately before commencement relating to these matters shall continue in force until altered, repealed or amended by Parliament.

sub_sections.text: Parliament shall have, and a State Legislature shall not have, power to make laws for matters under Articles 16(3), 32(3), 33, 34, and for prescribing punishment for offences under this Part. [cite: 667, 668]
Existing laws in force immediately before commencement related to these matters shall continue in force until altered or repealed by Parliament. [cite: 669]

article_title: Definition.
content: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' has the same meaning as in Part III[cite: 671].

article_title: Application of the principles contained in this Part.
content: The provisions contained in this Part shall not be enforceable by any court, but the principles therein laid down are nevertheless fundamental in the governance of the country and it shall be the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws[cite: 672].

article_title: State to secure a social order for the promotion of welfare of the people.
content: The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting as effectively as it may a social order in which justice, social, economic and political, shall inform all the institutions of the national life[cite: 672].  The State shall, in particular, strive to minimise the inequalities in income, and endeavour to eliminate inequalities in status, facilities and opportunities, not only amongst individuals but also amongst groups of people residing in different areas or engaged in different vocations[cite: 673].

sub_sections.text: The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting a social order in which justice (social, economic and political) informs all national institutions[cite: 672].
The State shall strive to minimise inequalities in income, and eliminate inequalities in status, facilities and opportunities, both among individuals and groups[cite: 673].

amendments_notes: Article 38 renumbered as clause (1) and clause (2) inserted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 672, 676].

article_title: Certain principles of policy to be followed by the State.
content: The State shall, in particular, direct its policy towards securing that citizens, men and women equally, have the right to an adequate means of livelihood [cite: 674] ; that the ownership and control of the material resources of the community are so distributed as best to subserve the common good [cite: 674] ; that the operation of the economic system does not result in the concentration of wealth and means of production to the common detriment [cite: 674] ; that there is equal pay for equal work for both men and women [cite: 675] ; that the health and strength of workers, men and women, and the tender age of children are not abused and that citizens are not forced by economic necessity to enter avocations unsuited to their age or strength [cite: 675] ; that children are given opportunities and facilities to develop in a healthy manner and in conditions of freedom and dignity and that childhood and youth are protected against exploitation and against moral and material abandonment[cite: 679].

sub_sections.text: That citizens, men and women equally, have the right to an adequate means of livelihood[cite: 674].
That the ownership and control of the material resources of the community are distributed to subserve the common good[cite: 674].
That the economic system avoids the concentration of wealth and means of production to the common detriment[cite: 674].
That there is equal pay for equal work for both men and women[cite: 675].
That the health and strength of workers and children are not abused, and citizens are not forced by economic necessity into unsuited avocations[cite: 675].
That children are given facilities for healthy development and are protected against exploitation and abandonment[cite: 679].

amendments_notes: Clause (f) substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 677].

article_title: Equal justice and free legal aid.
content: The State shall secure that the operation of the legal system promotes justice, on a basis of equal opportunity, and shall, in particular, provide free legal aid, by suitable legislation or schemes or in any other way, to ensure that opportunities for securing justice are not denied to any citizen by reason of economic or other disabilities[cite: 683].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 683].

article_title: Organisation of village panchayats.
content: The State shall take steps to organise village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government[cite: 680].

article_title: Right to work, to education and to public assistance in certain cases.
content: The State shall, within the limits of its economic capacity and development, make effective provision for securing the right to work, to education and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness and disablement, and in other cases of undeserved want[cite: 680].

article_title: Provision for just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief.
content: The State shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and for maternity relief[cite: 681].

article_title: Living wage, etc., for workers.
content: The State shall endeavour to secure, by suitable legislation or economic organisation or in any other way, to all workers, agricultural, industrial or otherwise, work, a living wage, conditions of work ensuring a decent standard of life and full enjoyment of leisure and social and cultural opportunities and, in particular, the State shall endeavour to promote cottage industries on an individual or co-operative basis in rural areas[cite: 681].

article_title: Participation of workers in management of Industries.
content: The State shall take steps, by suitable legislation or in any other way, to secure the participation of workers in the management of undertakings, establishments or other organisations engaged in any industry[cite: 682].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 683].

article_title: Promotion of co-operative societies.
content: The State shall endeavour to promote voluntary formation, autonomous functioning, democratic control and professional management of co-operative societies[cite: 686].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-seventh Amendment) Act, 2011[cite: 686].

article_title: Uniform civil code for the citizens.
content: The State shall endeavour to secure for the citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India[cite: 686].

article_title: Provision for early childhood care and education to children below the age of six years.
content: The State shall endeavour to provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of six years[cite: 687].
amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Eighty-sixth Amendment) Act, 2002, for the original Article 45[cite: 687].

article_title: Promotion of educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and other weaker sections.
content: The State shall promote with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and, in particular, of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, and shall protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation[cite: 687].

article_title: Duty of the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living and to improve public health.
content: The State shall regard the raising of the level of nutrition and the standard of living of its people and the improvement of public health as among its primary duties and, in particular, the State shall endeavour to bring about prohibition of the consumption except for medicinal purposes of intoxicating drinks and of drugs which are injurious to health[cite: 688].

article_title: Organisation of agriculture and animal husbandry.
content: The State shall endeavour to organise agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines and shall, in particular, take steps for preserving and improving the breeds, and prohibiting the slaughter, of cows and calves and other milch and draught cattle[cite: 688].

article_title: Protection and improvement of environment and safeguarding of forests and wild life.
content: The State shall endeavour to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard the forests and wild life of the country[cite: 689].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 690].

article_title: Protection of monuments and places and objects of national importance.
content: It shall be the obligation of the State to protect every monument or place or object of artistic or historic interest, declared by or under law made by Parliament to be of national importance, from spoliation, disfigurement, destruction, removal, disposal or export, as the case may be[cite: 692, 696].
amendments_notes: The phrase 'declared by or under law made by Parliament' substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 696].

article_title: Separation of judiciary from executive.
content: The State shall endeavour to take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State[cite: 693].

article_title: Promotion of international peace and security.
content: The State shall endeavour to promote international peace and security [cite: 694] ; maintain just and honourable relations between nations [cite: 694] ; foster respect for international law and treaty obligations [cite: 695] ; and encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration[cite: 696].

sub_sections.text: promote international peace and security[cite: 694];
maintain just and honourable relations between nations[cite: 694];
foster respect for international law and treaty obligations in the dealings of organised peoples with one another[cite: 695], and
encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration[cite: 696].

article_title: Fundamental duties.
content: It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag and the National Anthem [cite: 699] ; to cherish and follow the noble ideals which inspired our national struggle for freedom [cite: 700] ; to uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India [cite: 701] ; to defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so [cite: 701] ; to promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic and regional or sectional diversities; to renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women [cite: 701] ; to value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture [cite: 702] ; to protect and improve the natural environment including forests, lakes, rivers and wild life, and to have compassion for living creatures [cite: 703] ; to develop the scientific temper, humanism and the spirit of inquiry and reform [cite: 703] ; to safeguard public property and to abjure violence [cite: 704] ; to strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of endeavour and achievement [cite: 704] ; and who is a parent or guardian to provide opportunities for education to his child or, as the case may be, ward between the age of six and fourteen years[cite: 705].

sub_sections.text: to abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag and the National Anthem[cite: 699];
to cherish and follow the noble ideals which inspired our national struggle for freedom[cite: 700];
to uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India[cite: 701];
to defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so[cite: 701];

to promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic and regional or sectional diversities; to renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women[cite: 701];
to value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture[cite: 702];
to protect and improve the natural environment including forests, lakes, rivers and wild life, and to have compassion for living creatures[cite: 703];
to develop the scientific temper, humanism and the spirit of inquiry and reform[cite: 703];
to safeguard public property and to abjure violence[cite: 704];
to strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of endeavour and achievement[cite: 704];
who is a parent or guardian to provide opportunities for education to his child or, as the case may be, ward between the age of six and fourteen years[cite: 705].

amendments_notes: Part IVA, including Article 51A, inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 698].  Clause (k) inserted by the Constitution (Eighty-sixth Amendment) Act, 2002[cite: 705].

article_title: The President of India.
content: There shall be a President of India[cite: 709].

article_title: Executive power of the Union.
content: The executive power of the Union shall be vested in the President and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution[cite: 709].  The supreme command of the Defence Forces of the Union shall be vested in the President and the exercise thereof shall be regulated by law[cite: 710].  Nothing in this article shall be deemed to transfer to the President any functions conferred by any existing law on the Government of any State or other authority [cite: 711] ; or prevent Parliament from conferring by law functions on authorities other than the President[cite: 711].

sub_sections.text: The executive power of the Union shall be vested in the President and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution[cite: 709].
The supreme command of the Defence Forces of the Union shall be vested in the President and the exercise thereof shall be regulated by law[cite: 710].
Nothing shall be deemed to transfer to the President any functions conferred by any existing law on the Government of any State or other authority[cite: 711].
Nothing shall prevent Parliament from conferring by law functions on authorities other than the President[cite: 711].

article_title: Election of President.
content: The President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the elected members of both Houses of Parliament [cite: 712] ; and the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States[cite: 712].  'State' includes the National Capital Territory of Delhi and the Union territory of Puducherry[cite: 714].

sub_sections.text: The President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of
the elected members of both Houses of Parliament[cite: 712]; and
the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States[cite: 712].
In this article and in article 55, 'State' includes the National Capital Territory of Delhi and the Union territory of Puducherry[cite: 714].

amendments_notes: Explanation inserted by the Constitution (Seventieth Amendment) Act, 1992[cite: 714].

article_title: Manner of election of President.
content: As far as practicable, there shall be uniformity in the scale of representation of the different States at the election of the President[cite: 713].  For the purpose of securing such uniformity among the States inter se as well as parity between the States as a whole and the Union, the number of votes for each elected member shall be determined by a formula based on State population and the number of elected members[cite: 713].  The election shall be held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting shall be by secret ballot[cite: 718].  'Population' means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census whose figures have been published, with a provision to refer to the 1971 census until figures for the first census after the year 2026 are published[cite: 718, 719, 722].

sub_sections.text: As far as practicable, there shall be uniformity in the scale of representation of the different States at the election of the President[cite: 713].
Manner of securing uniformity and parity, defining the vote value of MLAs and MPs[cite: 713, 717].
The election shall be held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting shall be by secret ballot[cite: 718].
Defines 'population' as per the last preceding published census, currently referring to the 1971 census until after 2026[cite: 718, 719].

amendments_notes: Explanation regarding census reference amended by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 and the Constitution (Eighty-fourth Amendment) Act, 2001[cite: 722].

article_title: Term of office of President.
content: The President shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office[cite: 719].  The President may resign to the Vice-President [cite: 720] , be removed by impeachment (Article 61) [cite: 720] , or continue to hold office until his successor enters upon office, notwithstanding the expiration of his term[cite: 721].  Any resignation is communicated by the Vice-President to the Speaker of the House of the People[cite: 721].

sub_sections.text: The President holds office for five years[cite: 719].
Resignation by writing to the Vice-President[cite: 720].
Removal by impeachment in the manner provided in article 61[cite: 720].
Continuation in office until the successor enters upon office[cite: 721].
Resignation addressed to the Vice-President must be communicated by him to the Speaker of the House of the People[cite: 721].

article_title: Eligibility for re-election.
content: A person who holds, or who has held, office as President shall, subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, be eligible for re-election to that office[cite: 725].

article_title: Qualifications for election as President.
content: A person must be a citizen of India [cite: 726] , have completed the age of thirty-five years [cite: 726] , and be qualified for election as a member of the House of the People[cite: 727].  A person is ineligible if they hold any office of profit under the Government of India, any State, or any local or other controlled authority[cite: 727].  Holding the office of President, Vice-President, Governor, or Minister does not count as an 'office of profit' for this purpose[cite: 728].

sub_sections.text: Qualifications: citizen of India, at least thirty-five years old, and qualified for election as a member of the House of the People[cite: 726, 727].
Ineligibility: holding any office of profit under the Union, a State, or any local/controlled authority[cite: 727].
Certain constitutional offices (President, Vice-President, Governor, Minister) are not considered 'offices of profit'[cite: 728].

article_title: Conditions of President's office.
content: The President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or a State Legislature, and if a member is elected President, their seat is deemed vacated upon entry into office[cite: 728].  The President shall not hold any other office of profit[cite: 729].  The President is entitled to use their official residences without rent, and to emoluments, allowances, and privileges determined by Parliament, or as specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 729].  The emoluments and allowances shall not be diminished during the term of office[cite: 730].

sub_sections.text: The President cannot be a member of Parliament or a State Legislature (seat automatically vacated upon taking office)[cite: 728].
The President shall not hold any other office of profit[cite: 729].
Entitled to official residences, emoluments, allowances, and privileges as determined by Parliament or specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 729].
Emoluments and allowances shall not be diminished during the term of office[cite: 730].

article_title: Oath or affirmation by the President.
content: Every President, or person acting as or discharging the functions of President, shall, before entering office, make and subscribe an oath or affirmation before the Chief Justice of India (or senior-most available Supreme Court Judge), faithfully executing the office, preserving, protecting, and defending the Constitution and the law, and devoting themselves to the service and well-being of the people of India[cite: 730, 734].

sub_sections.text: Prescribes the form of the oath/affirmation to be taken by the President or acting President[cite: 730, 734].

article_title: Procedure for impeachment of the President
content: A charge for violation of the Constitution can be preferred by either House of Parliament[cite: 734].  The proposal must be a resolution moved after at least fourteen days' written notice, signed by not less than one-fourth of the total membership of the House, and passed by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the total membership of the House[cite: 735, 736].  The other House shall investigate the charge, and the President has the right to appear and be represented[cite: 736].  If the investigating House passes a resolution by a two-thirds majority of its total membership declaring the charge sustained, the President is removed from office from the date the resolution is passed[cite: 737].

sub_sections.text: The charge for violating the Constitution must be preferred by either House of Parliament[cite: 734].
Procedure for initiating the charge (notice and two-thirds majority requirement)[cite: 735, 736].
The other House investigates the charge, and the President has the right to representation[cite: 736].
Removal requires a resolution passed by two-thirds of the total membership of the investigating House[cite: 737].

article_title: Time of holding election to fill vacancy in the office of President and the term of office of person elected to fill casual vacancy.
content: An election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term shall be completed before the expiration of the term[cite: 737].  An election to fill a vacancy due to death, resignation, removal, or otherwise shall be held as soon as possible, and not later than six months from the date of vacancy, and the person elected holds office for a full term of five years[cite: 738].

sub_sections.text: Election for a regular vacancy (expiration of term) must be completed before the term expires[cite: 737].
Election for a casual vacancy (death, resignation, removal) must be held within six months, and the newly elected person holds office for a full five-year term[cite: 738].

article_title: The Vice-President of India.
content: There shall be a Vice-President of India[cite: 738].

article_title: The Vice-President to be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States.
content: The Vice-President shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of the States and shall not hold any other office of profit[cite: 738].  During any period when the Vice-President acts as President or discharges presidential functions (Article 65), he shall not perform the duties of the Chairman of the Council of States and shall not be entitled to the Chairman's salary or allowance (Article 97)[cite: 741].

sub_sections.text: The Vice-President is the ex officio Chairman of the Council of States and shall not hold any other office of profit[cite: 738].
When acting as or discharging the functions of the President, he does not perform the duties or receive the salary/allowances of the Chairman of the Council of States[cite: 741].

article_title: The Vice-President to act as President or to discharge his functions during casual vacancies in the office, or during the absence, of President.
content: In the event of a vacancy in the office of the President (death, resignation, removal, etc.), the Vice-President shall act as President until a new President enters office[cite: 741].  When the President is unable to discharge functions (absence, illness, etc.), the Vice-President shall discharge them until the President resumes duties[cite: 742].  While acting as or discharging presidential functions, the Vice-President has all the powers and immunities of the President and is entitled to the emoluments, allowances, and privileges determined by Parliament or specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 742].

sub_sections.text: The Vice-President acts as President during a casual vacancy until a new President takes office[cite: 741].
The Vice-President discharges presidential functions during the Presidents absence or inability until the President resumes duties[cite: 742].
While acting as President, the Vice-President has all presidential powers, immunities, and receives the emoluments/allowances/privileges specified[cite: 742].

article_title: Election of Vice-President.
content: The Vice-President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the members of both Houses of Parliament [cite: 743]  in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting shall be by secret ballot[cite: 743].  The Vice-President shall not be a member of Parliament or a State Legislature (seat automatically vacated upon taking office)[cite: 743].  A person must be a citizen of India [cite: 744] , have completed the age of thirty-five years [cite: 744] , and be qualified for election as a member of the Council of States[cite: 747].  A person is ineligible if they hold any office of profit (though President, Vice-President, Governor, or Minister is excluded)[cite: 747, 748].

sub_sections.text: Manner of election by an electoral college of members of both Houses of Parliament, using proportional representation and secret ballot[cite: 743].
The Vice-President cannot be a member of Parliament or a State Legislature (seat automatically vacated)[cite: 743].
Qualifications: citizen of India, at least thirty-five years old, and qualified for election as a member of the Council of States[cite: 744, 747].
Ineligibility: holding any office of profit (excluding President, Vice-President, Governor, or Minister)[cite: 747, 748].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) substituted by the Constitution (Eleventh Amendment) Act, 1961[cite: 745].

article_title: Term of office of Vice-President.
content: The Vice-President holds office for a term of five years[cite: 748].  He may resign by writing to the President[cite: 749].  He can be removed by a resolution of the Council of States passed by a majority of all then members and agreed to by the House of the People, with at least fourteen days' notice[cite: 749].  He continues to hold office, notwithstanding the expiration of his term, until his successor enters upon office[cite: 750].

sub_sections.text: The Vice-President holds office for a term of five years[cite: 748].
Resignation by writing to the President[cite: 749].
Removal by a resolution of the Council of States (absolute majority) agreed to by the House of the People (requires 14 days' notice)[cite: 749].
