Continuation in office until the successor enters upon office[cite: 750].

article_title: Time of holding election to fill vacancy in the office of Vice-President and the term of office of person elected to fill casual vacancy.
content: An election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term must be completed before the expiration of the term[cite: 750].  An election to fill a casual vacancy (death, resignation, removal, or otherwise) must be held as soon as possible, and the person elected holds office for a full term of five years[cite: 751].

sub_sections.text: Election for a regular vacancy (expiration of term) must be completed before the term expires[cite: 750].
Election for a casual vacancy must be held as soon as possible, and the newly elected person holds office for a full five-year term[cite: 751].

article_title: Oath or affirmation by the Vice-President.
content: Every Vice-President shall, before entering office, make and subscribe an oath or affirmation before the President (or appointee), pledging true faith and allegiance to the Constitution and faithfully discharging their duty[cite: 752, 755].

sub_sections.text: Prescribes the form of the oath/affirmation to be taken by the Vice-President[cite: 752, 755].

article_title: Discharge of President's functions in other contingencies.
content: Parliament may make such provision as it thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the President in any contingency not provided for in this Chapter[cite: 755].

article_title: Matters relating to, or connected with, the election of a President or Vice-President.
content: All doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of a President or Vice-President shall be inquired into and decided by the Supreme Court, whose decision is final[cite: 756].  Acts done by a President or Vice-President before their election is declared void by the Supreme Court are not invalidated by that declaration[cite: 756].  Parliament may regulate any matter relating to or connected with the election[cite: 757].  The election cannot be questioned on the ground of any vacancy among the members of the electoral college[cite: 757].

sub_sections.text: Supreme Court is the final authority to inquire into and decide all doubts and disputes regarding the election of the President or Vice-President[cite: 756].
Acts of the President or Vice-President done before their election is declared void are not invalidated[cite: 756].
Parliament may regulate matters relating to the election[cite: 757].
Election cannot be questioned due to any vacancy in the electoral college[cite: 757].

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Thirty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1975, and further substituted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 759].

article_title: Power of President to grant pardons, etc., and to suspend, remit or commute sentences in certain cases.
content: The President has the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment or to suspend, remit or commute sentences in all cases where the punishment is by a Court Martial [cite: 758] ; where the punishment is for an offence against any law relating to a matter to which the Union's executive power extends [cite: 761] ; and in all cases where the sentence is a sentence of death[cite: 762].  This power does not affect the power conferred by law on an officer of the Armed Forces to deal with a Court Martial sentence [cite: 762] , nor does it affect the power of the Governor of a State to deal with a death sentence under any law in force[cite: 763].

sub_sections.text: Power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites, remissions, or commute sentences in cases involving: (a) Court Martial, (b) Union executive power laws, and (c) sentence of death[cite: 758, 761, 762].
Does not affect the power of Armed Forces officers to suspend, remit or commute a Court Martial sentence[cite: 762].
Does not affect the Governor's power to deal with a sentence of death under any State law[cite: 763].

article_title: Extent of executive power of the Union.
content: The executive power of the Union extends to matters where Parliament has power to make laws [cite: 764] ; and to the exercise of rights and jurisdiction by virtue of any treaty or agreement[cite: 764].  The executive power over matters in the Concurrent List (where both Parliament and State Legislatures can make laws) is generally restricted and does not extend to a State unless expressly provided by the Constitution or Parliament[cite: 765].  A State and its authorities may continue to exercise existing executive power over Concurrent List matters until Parliament provides otherwise[cite: 765].

sub_sections.text: Union executive power extends to matters where Parliament can make laws and rights/jurisdiction under treaties/agreements[cite: 764].
Limits Union executive power in a State over Concurrent List matters, unless expressly provided by the Constitution or a law made by Parliament[cite: 765].
States continue to exercise existing executive power over Concurrent List matters until Parliament provides otherwise[cite: 765].

article_title: Council of Ministers to aid and advise President.
content: There shall be a Council of Ministers (COM) with the Prime Minister at the head to aid and advise the President, who shall act in accordance with such advice[cite: 769].  The President may require the COM to reconsider the advice, but shall act in accordance with the advice tendered after such reconsideration[cite: 770].  The question of whether, and what, advice was tendered by Ministers shall not be inquired into in any court[cite: 770].

sub_sections.text: COM to aid and advise the President, who acts on advice[cite: 769].
President may ask for reconsideration of advice once, and acts on reconsidered advice[cite: 770].
Judicial inquiry into the advice tendered is barred[cite: 770].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and its proviso substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 and the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978, respectively[cite: 769, 774].

article_title: Other provisions as to Ministers.
content: The Prime Minister is appointed by the President, and other Ministers are appointed by the President on the PM's advice[cite: 771].  The total number of Ministers, including the PM, shall not exceed fifteen per cent. of the total members of the House of the People[cite: 771].  A disqualified member of Parliament under the Tenth Schedule is also disqualified to be a Minister[cite: 772].  Ministers hold office during the pleasure of the President[cite: 772].  The COM is collectively responsible to the House of the People[cite: 772].  Oaths of office and secrecy are administered by the President (Third Schedule)[cite: 773].  A non-member of either House of Parliament for six consecutive months ceases to be a Minister[cite: 776].  Salaries and allowances are determined by Parliament or specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 777].

sub_sections.text: Appointment procedure (PM appointed by President; other Ministers by President on PM's advice)[cite: 771].
Ceiling on Council of Ministers size (15% of House of the People)[cite: 771].
Disqualification provisions for Ministers under the Tenth Schedule[cite: 772].
Ministers hold office during the pleasure of the President[cite: 772].
Collective responsibility to the House of the People[cite: 772].
Oaths of office and secrecy (Third Schedule)[cite: 773].
Six-month limit for a non-MP Minister[cite: 776].
Salaries and allowances determined by Parliament/Second Schedule[cite: 777].

amendments_notes: Clauses (1A) and (1B) inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-first Amendment) Act, 2003[cite: 771, 772].

article_title: Attorney-General for India.
content: The President shall appoint a person qualified to be a Supreme Court Judge to be Attorney-General (AG) for India[cite: 778].  The AG advises the Government of India on legal matters, performs legal duties assigned by the President, and discharges functions conferred by the Constitution or law[cite: 778].  The AG has the right of audience in all courts in India[cite: 779].  The AG holds office during the pleasure of the President and receives remuneration determined by the President[cite: 779].

sub_sections.text: Appointment and qualification (Supreme Court Judge qualification)[cite: 778].
Duties (to advise Government, perform legal duties assigned by President)[cite: 778].
Right of audience in all courts in India[cite: 779].
Tenure (pleasure of the President) and remuneration (determined by the President)[cite: 779].

article_title: Conduct of business of the Government of India.
content: All executive action of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the President[cite: 780].  Orders and instruments made in the President's name shall be authenticated as specified in rules made by the President, and the validity of a so-authenticated order shall not be questioned on the ground that it was not made/executed by the President[cite: 780].  The President shall make rules for the convenient transaction of Government business and its allocation among Ministers[cite: 781].

sub_sections.text: All executive action is taken in the name of the President[cite: 780].
Authentication of orders and instruments in the President's name (validity cannot be questioned)[cite: 780].
President makes rules for convenient business transaction and allocation among Ministers[cite: 781].

amendments_notes: Clause (4) was inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 and omitted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 783].

article_title: Duties of Prime Minister as respects the furnishing of information to the President, etc.
content: The Prime Minister's duties include communicating all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to administration and proposals for legislation to the President [cite: 786] ; furnishing any information the President calls for relating to administration and legislation [cite: 786] ; and if the President requires it, submitting any matter on which a Minister has taken a decision (but the COM has not considered) for the consideration of the Council of Ministers[cite: 787].

sub_sections.text: To communicate all COM decisions and legislative proposals to the President[cite: 786].
To furnish any information requested by the President[cite: 786].
To submit for COM consideration any matter decided by a Minister but not considered by the COM, if required by the President[cite: 787].

article_title: Constitution of Parliament.
content: There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses to be known respectively as the Council of States and the House of the People. [cite: 788]

article_title: Composition of the Council of States.
content: The Council of States shall consist of twelve members to be nominated by the President [cite: 789]  in accordance with the provisions of clause (3); and not more than two hundred and thirty-eight representatives of the States and of the Union territories. [cite: 790]  The allocation of seats shall be in accordance with the Fourth Schedule. [cite: 790]  Nominated members should have special knowledge or practical experience in literature, science, art and social service. [cite: 791]  Representatives of each State shall be elected by the elected members of the Legislative Assembly of the State in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote. [cite: 795]  Representatives of Union territories shall be chosen in such manner as Parliament may by law prescribe. [cite: 795]

sub_sections.text: Composition: 12 nominated members and not more than 238 representatives of States and Union territories. [cite: 789, 790]
Allocation of seats as per Fourth Schedule. [cite: 790]
Criteria for President's nomination: literature, science, art, and social service. [cite: 791]
State representatives elected by elected MLAs using proportional representation (single transferable vote). [cite: 795]
Union territory representatives chosen as prescribed by Parliament. [cite: 795]

amendments_notes: References to 'Union territories' added by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956. Initial words subject to para.  4 of the Tenth Schedule omitted by the Constitution (Thirty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1975. [cite: 792]

article_title: Composition of the House of the People.
content: Subject to Article 331, [cite: 796]  the House of the People shall consist of not more than five hundred and thirty members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the States; and not more than twenty members to represent the Union territories, chosen as Parliament provides. [cite: 796]  Seats are allotted to States such that the ratio between the number of seats and the population of the State is, as far as practicable, the same for all States. [cite: 797]  Each State is divided into territorial constituencies such that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted to it is, as far as practicable, the same throughout the State. [cite: 797]  The principle of equal representation (cl. 2(a)) does not apply to any State whose population does not exceed six millions. [cite: 798] 'Population' means the last preceding published census figure, currently referring to the 1971 census for cl. 2(a) and the 2001 census for cl.  2(b), until figures for the first census after 2026 are published. [cite: 807, 808]

sub_sections.text: Composition: Max 530 members from States and max 20 members from Union territories. [cite: 796]
Uniform ratio of seats to population among States (as far as practicable). [cite: 797]
Uniform ratio of seats to population within constituencies of a State (as far as practicable). [cite: 797]
Clause 2(a) does not apply to States with population not exceeding six millions. [cite: 798]
Definition of 'population' (currently based on 1971/2001 census, until after 2026). [cite: 807, 808]

amendments_notes: Article 81 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956. Max members for States and UTs changed by subsequent amendments.  The ceiling date (2026) and census reference (2001) were set by the Constitution (Eighty-fourth Amendment) Act, 2001, and the Constitution (Eighty-seventh Amendment) Act, 2003. [cite: 803, 804, 807, 808, 812]

article_title: Readjustment after each census.
content: After each census, the allocation of seats and division of States into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by an authority determined by Parliament. [cite: 809]  Such readjustment does not affect representation until the dissolution of the existing House. [cite: 809]  The readjustment takes effect from a date specified by the President's order. [cite: 810]  Readjustment is currently suspended until after the first census taken after 2026, referring to the 1971 census for seat allocation and the 2001 census for territorial constituency division. [cite: 810, 816]

sub_sections.text: Readjustment of seat allocation and constituency division after each census. [cite: 809]
Contain provisions for effect date, interim elections, and the current freeze on readjustment using the 1971 and 2001 census figures until after 2026. [cite: 810, 816]

amendments_notes: Provisos inserted and subsequently amended, notably by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, the Constitution (Eighty-fourth Amendment) Act, 2001, and the Constitution (Eighty-seventh Amendment) Act, 2003, relating to the census freeze date (2026). [cite: 811, 812]

article_title: Duration of Houses of Parliament.
content: The Council of States is not subject to dissolution, but approximately one-third of its members retire every second year. [cite: 817]  The House of the People continues for five years from its first meeting, unless sooner dissolved, and the expiration of this period causes dissolution. [cite: 817]  This five-year period can be extended by Parliament by law for up to one year at a time while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, but not beyond six months after the Proclamation ceases to operate. [cite: 817, 818]

sub_sections.text: Council of States is permanent (one-third retire every two years). [cite: 817]
House of the People's duration is five years (unless sooner dissolved). [cite: 817]
The five-year period can be extended during an Emergency. [cite: 818]

amendments_notes: The term was changed from five years to six years by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and back to five years by the 44th Amendment, 1978. [cite: 821]

article_title: Qualification for membership of Parliament.
content: A person must be a citizen of India and subscribe to an oath/affirmation set out in the Third Schedule. [cite: 819]  For the Council of States, the age must be at least thirty years; for the House of the People, at least twenty-five years. [cite: 819]  They must also possess any other qualifications prescribed by or under law made by Parliament. [cite: 820]

sub_sections.text: Citizen of India and subscribing to the oath/affirmation (Third Schedule). [cite: 819]
Age: 30 years for Council of States, 25 years for House of the People. [cite: 819]
Possessing other qualifications prescribed by Parliament. [cite: 820]

amendments_notes: Clause (a) substituted by the Constitution (Sixteenth Amendment) Act, 1963. [cite: 820]

article_title: Sessions of Parliament, prorogation and dissolution.
content: The President shall summon each House of Parliament to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, but six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session. [cite: 824]  The President may also prorogue the Houses or either House, or dissolve the House of the People. [cite: 825]

sub_sections.text: President summons Houses; max six-month gap between sessions. [cite: 824]
President may prorogue the Houses or dissolve the House of the People. [cite: 825]

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951. [cite: 829]

article_title: Right of President to address and send messages to Houses.
content: The President may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together. [cite: 826]  The President may send messages to either House, and the House shall consider the matter required by the message. [cite: 826]

sub_sections.text: President's right to address and require attendance. [cite: 826]
President's right to send messages, and the House's duty to consider them. [cite: 826]

article_title: Special address by the President.
content: At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the House of the People and at the commencement of the first session of each year, the President shall address both Houses of Parliament assembled together and inform Parliament of the causes of its summons. [cite: 827]  Provision for allotment of time for discussion of the matters in the address shall be made by rules of procedure. [cite: 827]

sub_sections.text: President addresses both Houses at the start of the first session after each general election and the first session of each year. [cite: 827]
Rules must provide time for discussion of the address. [cite: 827]

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and (2) amended by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951. [cite: 827, 829]

article_title: Rights of Ministers and Attorney-General as respects Houses.
content: Every Minister and the Attorney-General of India shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise take part in the proceedings of, either House, any joint sitting, and any committee of Parliament of which he may be named a member, but shall not be entitled to vote by virtue of this article. [cite: 828]

article_title: The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States.
content: The Vice-President of India shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States. [cite: 832]  The Council shall choose one of its members to be Deputy Chairman. [cite: 833]

sub_sections.text: The Vice-President is the ex officio Chairman. [cite: 832]
The Council chooses a member to be Deputy Chairman. [cite: 833]

article_title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the office of Deputy Chairman.
content: A member holding office as Deputy Chairman vacates office if they cease to be a member of the Council; [cite: 834]  may resign in writing to the Chairman; [cite: 834]  and may be removed by a resolution of the Council passed by a majority of all the then members (requires 14 days' notice). [cite: 834, 835]

sub_sections.text: Vacates if ceases to be a member of the Council. [cite: 834]
May resign to the Chairman. [cite: 834]
May be removed by a Council resolution (requires majority and 14 days' notice). [cite: 834, 835]

article_title: Power of the Deputy Chairman or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Chairman.
content: When the office of Chairman is vacant, or during any period when the Vice-President is acting as or discharging the functions of President, the Deputy Chairman (or a person appointed by the President) performs the duties of the office. [cite: 835]  During the absence of the Chairman from a sitting, the Deputy Chairman (or a person determined by rules/Council) acts as Chairman. [cite: 836]

sub_sections.text: Deputy Chairman (or President's appointee) performs duties when the Chairmanship is vacant or the Chairman is acting as President. [cite: 835]
Deputy Chairman (or other determined person) acts as Chairman during absence from a sitting. [cite: 836]

article_title: The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration.
content: Neither the Chairman nor the Deputy Chairman shall preside over a sitting while a resolution for their removal is under consideration. [cite: 836]  The Chairman has the right to speak and take part in the proceedings while a resolution for the Vice-Presidents removal is considered but is not entitled to vote (including on the resolution itself). [cite: 839]

sub_sections.text: Chairman/Deputy Chairman cannot preside while a resolution for their removal is under consideration. [cite: 836]
The Chairman (Vice-President) may speak and participate in proceedings for their removal but has no right to vote. [cite: 839]

article_title: The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People.
content: The House of the People shall, as soon as may be, choose two members to be Speaker and Deputy Speaker, and whenever either office becomes vacant, the House shall choose another member. [cite: 839]

article_title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker.
content: A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker vacates if they cease to be a member of the House; [cite: 840]  may resign by writing to the Deputy Speaker (Speaker) or Speaker (Deputy Speaker); [cite: 841]  and may be removed by a resolution of the House passed by a majority of all the then members (requires 14 days' notice). [cite: 841]  The Speaker does not vacate office upon dissolution of the House until immediately before the first meeting of the new House. [cite: 842]

sub_sections.text: Vacates if ceases to be a member. [cite: 840]
May resign (Speaker to Deputy Speaker, and vice versa). [cite: 841]
May be removed by a House resolution (requires majority and 14 days' notice). [cite: 841]
Speaker does not vacate upon dissolution until the first meeting of the new House. [cite: 842]

article_title: Power of the Deputy Speaker or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Speaker.
content: When the office of Speaker is vacant, the Deputy Speaker (or a person appointed by the President) performs the duties. [cite: 842]  During the absence of the Speaker from a sitting, the Deputy Speaker (or a person determined by rules/House) acts as Speaker. [cite: 843]

sub_sections.text: Deputy Speaker (or President's appointee) performs duties when the Speakership is vacant. [cite: 842]
Deputy Speaker (or other determined person) acts as Speaker during absence from a sitting. [cite: 843]

article_title: The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration.
content: Neither the Speaker nor the Deputy Speaker shall preside over a sitting while a resolution for their removal is under consideration. [cite: 845]  The Speaker has the right to speak and participate in the proceedings for their removal and is entitled to vote only in the first instance (not a casting vote). [cite: 846]

sub_sections.text: Speaker/Deputy Speaker cannot preside while a resolution for their removal is under consideration. [cite: 845]
The Speaker may speak and participate in proceedings for their removal and has a right to vote in the first instance (no casting vote). [cite: 846]

article_title: Salaries and allowances of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker.
content: Salaries and allowances for the Chairman, Deputy Chairman of the Council of States, and the Speaker, Deputy Speaker of the House of the People shall be fixed by Parliament by law, or as specified in the Second Schedule until then. [cite: 846]

article_title: Secretariat of Parliament.
content: Each House of Parliament shall have a separate secretarial staff (though common posts may be created). [cite: 847]  Parliament may regulate the recruitment and conditions of service for the secretarial staff by law. [cite: 847]  Until such law is made, the President may make rules after consultation with the Speaker/Chairman. [cite: 848]

sub_sections.text: Separate secretarial staff for each House (with provision for common posts). [cite: 847]
Parliament regulates staff recruitment and conditions of service by law. [cite: 847]
President makes interim rules after consultation with the Speaker/Chairman. [cite: 848]

article_title: Oath or affirmation by members.
content: Every member of either House of Parliament shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the President (or appointee) an oath or affirmation according to the form set out in the Third Schedule. [cite: 851]

article_title: Voting in Houses, power of Houses to act notwithstanding vacancies and quorum.
content: All questions are determined by a majority of members present and voting, excluding the presiding officer, who has a casting vote in case of equality. [cite: 851, 852]  The Houses can act notwithstanding vacancies, and proceedings are valid even if an ineligible person sat or voted. [cite: 852]  Until Parliament provides otherwise, the quorum is one-tenth of the total membership. [cite: 853]  If there is no quorum, the presiding officer must adjourn or suspend the meeting. [cite: 853]

sub_sections.text: Decision by majority of present and voting; presiding officer has a casting vote. [cite: 851, 852]
Houses can act despite vacancies (proceedings remain valid). [cite: 852]
Quorum is one-tenth of total members (until Parliament provides otherwise). [cite: 853]
Lack of quorum requires adjournment or suspension. [cite: 853]

amendments_notes: Clauses (3) and (4) were temporarily removed and then restored by the 42nd and 44th Amendments respectively. [cite: 855]

article_title: Vacation of seats.
content: A person cannot be a member of both Houses of Parliament (Parliament will provide by law for the vacation of one seat). [cite: 854]  A person cannot be a member of both Parliament and a State Legislature (seat in Parliament becomes vacant after a specified period unless the State Legislature seat is resigned). [cite: 857]  A member's seat becomes vacant if they incur disqualification under Article 102(1) or 102(2), or resign in writing and the resignation is accepted by the Chairman/Speaker. [cite: 858, 859]  The resignation is not accepted if the presiding officer determines it is not voluntary or genuine. [cite: 860]  A seat is vacated if the member is absent from all meetings for sixty days without permission. [cite: 861]

sub_sections.text: Prohibition on membership of both Houses. [cite: 854]
Prohibition on simultaneous membership of Parliament and a State Legislature. [cite: 857]
Seat vacated on: (a) disqualification under Article 102(1) or 102(2), [cite: 858]  or (b) acceptance of resignation. [cite: 859]
Resignation must be voluntary and genuine to be accepted. [cite: 860]
Seat vacated for 60 days' unauthorized absence. [cite: 861]

amendments_notes: Clause (3)(a) amended by the 52nd Amendment, 1985. [cite: 862]  Clause (3)(b) and its proviso inserted/substituted by the 33rd Amendment, 1974. [cite: 863]

article_title: Disqualifications for membership.
content: A person is disqualified if they hold any office of profit under the Government of India or any State (unless Parliament exempts it by law); [cite: 866]  are of unsound mind (declared by a competent court); [cite: 866]  are an undischarged insolvent; [cite: 867]  are not a citizen of India, have voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship, or acknowledge allegiance to a foreign State; [cite: 867]  or are disqualified by or under any law made by Parliament. [cite: 868]  Holding the office of Minister is not considered holding an office of profit. [cite: 868]  A person is also disqualified if they are so disqualified under the Tenth Schedule (defection). [cite: 869]

sub_sections.text: Holding an unexempted office of profit. [cite: 866]
Unsound mind. [cite: 866]
Undischarged insolvent. [cite: 867]
Loss of Indian citizenship/acquiring foreign citizenship. [cite: 867]
Disqualification by Parliamentary law. [cite: 868]
Ministerial office is not an office of profit. [cite: 868]
Disqualification under the Tenth Schedule (defection). [cite: 869]

amendments_notes: Clause (1)(a) saw substitution attempts and omissions by the 42nd and 44th Amendments. [cite: 870]  Clause (2) inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-second Amendment) Act, 1985. [cite: 871]

article_title: Decision on questions as to disqualifications of members.
content: If a question arises regarding a member's disqualification under Article 102(1), it is referred to the President for a final decision. [cite: 869]  Before giving any decision, the President must obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and shall act according to that opinion. [cite: 874]

sub_sections.text: Disqualification questions (under Article 102(1)) are decided by the President (decision is final). [cite: 869]
The President must consult the Election Commission and act according to its opinion. [cite: 874]

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 and further substituted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 871]

article_title: Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under article 99 or when not qualified or when disqualified.
content: Any person who sits or votes in Parliament without taking the oath, or when disqualified/not qualified, is liable to a penalty of five hundred rupees for each day, recoverable as a debt due to the Union. [cite: 874]

article_title: Powers, privileges, etc., of the Houses of Parliament and of the members and committees thereof.
content: Subject to the provisions of the Constitution and the rules of procedure, there shall be freedom of speech in Parliament. [cite: 875]  No member is liable to court proceedings for anything said or any vote given in Parliament/committee, nor is any person liable for publication of reports under House authority. [cite: 876]  In other respects, the powers, privileges, and immunities shall be those of that House and its members/committees immediately before the coming into force of Section 15 of the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 877]  These provisions also apply to persons who have the right to speak in or take part in proceedings (like Ministers/AG). [cite: 880]

sub_sections.text: Freedom of speech in Parliament. [cite: 875]
Immunity from legal proceedings for speech, vote, or authorized publication. [cite: 876]
Other privileges are those existing before the 44th Amendment (1978). [cite: 877]
Applicable to persons other than members who have the right to speak (Ministers, AG). [cite: 880]

amendments_notes: Clause (3) substituted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 877]

article_title: Salaries and allowances of members.
content: Members shall receive salaries and allowances determined by Parliament by law, or allowances at the rates applicable to members of the Constituent Assembly until then. [cite: 880]

article_title: Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills.
content: Bills (except Money Bills and Financial Bills under Art. 117) may originate in either House. [cite: 881]  A Bill is deemed passed only if agreed to by both Houses. [cite: 882]  A Bill pending does not lapse by reason of prorogation. [cite: 882]  A Bill pending in the Council of States (not passed by the House of the People) does not lapse on dissolution of the House of the People. [cite: 883]  A Bill pending in or passed by the House of the People and pending in the Council of States lapses on the dissolution of the House of the People (subject to Art. 108). [cite: 883]

sub_sections.text: Bills may originate in either House (except Money Bills/Financial Bills). [cite: 881]
Bill requires agreement by both Houses. [cite: 882]
Bill does not lapse on prorogation. [cite: 882]
Bill pending in the Council of States (not passed by the House) does not lapse on dissolution. [cite: 883]
Bill pending in or passed by the House of the People lapses on dissolution. [cite: 883]

article_title: Joint sitting of both Houses in certain cases.
content: If a Bill (not a Money Bill) passed by one House is rejected by the other, or if the Houses finally disagree on amendments, or if more than six months elapse without the Bill passing, the President may notify an intention to summon a joint sitting for deliberation and voting (unless the Bill has lapsed due to dissolution). [cite: 884, 885, 887]  The six-month period excludes time when the House is prorogued or adjourned for more than four days. [cite: 888]  Once notification is sent, neither House proceeds further; the President summons the joint sitting. [cite: 889]  If the Bill is passed at the joint sitting by a majority of the total members present and voting, it is deemed passed by both Houses. [cite: 889]  Restrictions apply on the type of amendments that can be proposed at a joint sitting. [cite: 890, 891]

sub_sections.text: Circumstances for joint sitting (rejection, disagreement, six-month delay). [cite: 884, 885, 887]
Does not apply to a Money Bill. [cite: 888]
Exclusion period for six-month delay calculation. [cite: 888]
Procedure after notification and for summoning the sitting. [cite: 889]
Bill deemed passed if approved by majority of total members present and voting in joint sitting. [cite: 889]
Restrictions on amendments in a joint sitting. [cite: 890, 891]
Joint sitting can be held despite intervening dissolution. [cite: 891]

article_title: Special procedure in respect of Money Bills.
content: A Money Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States. [cite: 892]  After passing the House of the People, it is transmitted to the Council of States for recommendations, which must be returned within fourteen days. [cite: 894]  The House of the People may accept or reject all or any recommendations. [cite: 894]  If the House accepts recommendations, the Bill is deemed passed with those amendments. [cite: 895]  If the House rejects recommendations, the Bill is deemed passed in its original form. [cite: 895]  If the Council of States does not return the Bill within fourteen days, it is deemed passed by both Houses in the form passed by the House of the People. [cite: 896]

sub_sections.text: Money Bills cannot be introduced in the Council of States. [cite: 892]
Council of States must return Money Bill with recommendations within 14 days. [cite: 894]
Bill passed with accepted recommendations. [cite: 895]
Bill passed without rejected recommendations. [cite: 895]
Bill deemed passed if not returned within 14 days. [cite: 896]

article_title: Definition of 'Money Bills'.
content: A Bill is a Money Bill if it contains only provisions dealing with: imposition/regulation of taxes; [cite: 897]  regulation of borrowing/guarantees by the Government of India; [cite: 898]  custody/withdrawal of the Consolidated Fund or Contingency Fund; [cite: 898]  appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of India; [cite: 899]  declaring expenditure charged on the Fund or increasing such amount; [cite: 899]  receipt/custody/issue of money for the Consolidated Fund/public account, or audit; [cite: 901]  or any incidental matter. [cite: 902]  It is **not** a Money Bill merely because it imposes fines, pecuniary penalties, fees for licences/services, or taxes by a local authority. [cite: 902]  The Speaker's decision on whether a Bill is a Money Bill is final. [cite: 903]  The Speaker's certificate must be endorsed on the Bill when transmitted to the Council of States or presented to the President. [cite: 903]

sub_sections.text: List of seven subjects (a-g) that define a Money Bill (if dealing *only* with these matters). [cite: 897, 898, 899, 901, 902]
Exclusions from the definition (fines, fees, local taxes). [cite: 902]
Speaker's decision is final. [cite: 903]
Speaker's certificate is required on the Bill. [cite: 903]

article_title: Assent to Bills.
content: When a Bill is passed by both Houses, it is presented to the President, who declares assent or withholds assent. [cite: 904] The President may return a Bill (if it is not a Money Bill) to the Houses for reconsideration (with or without amendments).  If the Houses pass the Bill again, the President shall not withhold assent. [cite: 904]

sub_sections.text: President gives assent or withholds assent. [cite: 904]
President may return a non-Money Bill for reconsideration.  If passed again, the President must assent. [cite: 904]

article_title: Annual financial statement.
content: The President causes the 'annual financial statement' (budget) of estimated receipts and expenditure for the financial year to be laid before both Houses. [cite: 905]  Expenditure estimates must show separately sums charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (non-votable) and sums proposed to be made from it (votable), distinguishing revenue and other expenditure. [cite: 906, 909]  Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund includes emoluments of the President/presiding officers, debt charges, salaries/pensions of Supreme Court Judges/CAG, and sums satisfying court judgments. [cite: 910, 911, 912, 913, 914]

sub_sections.text: Annual financial statement (budget) is laid before both Houses. [cite: 905]
Estimates distinguish charged (non-votable) and other (votable) expenditure, and revenue vs. other expenditure. [cite: 906, 909]
List of expenditures charged on the Consolidated Fund of India (non-votable). [cite: 910, 911, 912, 913, 914]

article_title: Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates.
content: Expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India is non-votable but may be discussed in either House. [cite: 914]  Other expenditure is submitted to the House of the People as demands for grants, which the House may assent to, refuse, or assent subject to reduction. [cite: 917]  No demand for a grant can be made except on the recommendation of the President. [cite: 918]

sub_sections.text: Charged expenditure is non-votable but discussable. [cite: 914]
Other expenditure is submitted as demands for grants to the House of the People for voting. [cite: 917]
Demands for grants require the President's recommendation. [cite: 918]

article_title: Appropriation Bills.
content: After grants are made, an Appropriation Bill is introduced to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of India of the grants and the charged expenditure. [cite: 918, 919]  No amendment can be proposed to vary the amount or destination of any grant or vary the charged expenditure. [cite: 920]  No money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India except under appropriation made by law passed under this article (subject to Arts. 115 and 116). [cite: 920]

sub_sections.text: An Appropriation Bill is introduced for all grants and charged expenditure. [cite: 918, 919]
No amendment to vary grants or charged expenditure is admissible (presiding officer's decision is final). [cite: 920]
Money cannot be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund except by an Appropriation law. [cite: 920]

article_title: Supplementary, additional or excess grants.
content: The President shall cause another statement/demand for excess grants to be laid before Parliament if the authorized amount is insufficient, if new/additional expenditure is needed, or if excess money has been spent. [cite: 921, 922]  The procedure for the annual financial statement and appropriation (Arts. 112, 113, 114) applies to these grants/expenditures. [cite: 924]

sub_sections.text: Procedure for insufficient, additional, or excess grants/expenditure (President causes a statement/demand to be laid). [cite: 921, 922]
Articles 112, 113, and 114 procedures apply to supplementary, additional, and excess grants. [cite: 924]

article_title: Votes on account, votes of credit and exceptional grants.
content: The House of the People has the power to make a vote on account (advance grant for a part of the year pending full procedure), a vote of credit (for unexpected or indefinite demands), and an exceptional grant (not part of current service). [cite: 925, 926]  Parliament can authorize by law the withdrawal of moneys from the Consolidated Fund for these purposes. [cite: 927]  The procedures in Articles 113 and 114 apply to these grants and authorization laws. [cite: 927]

sub_sections.text: House of the People's power to make special grants: (a) Vote on account, (b) Vote of credit, (c) Exceptional grants. [cite: 925, 926]
Parliament's power to authorize withdrawal of money for these grants. [cite: 927]
Articles 113 and 114 procedures apply to these special grants. [cite: 927]

article_title: Special provisions as to financial Bills.
content: A Bill or amendment making provision for the Money Bill matters (Art. 110(1)(a) to (f)) requires the President's recommendation to be introduced or moved, and such a Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States. [cite: 928]  However, no recommendation is needed for an amendment reducing or abolishing any tax. [cite: 928]  A Bill is not deemed to contain the aforesaid matters merely because it relates to fines, fees, or local taxes. [cite: 931]  A Bill that, if enacted, would involve expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India shall not be passed by either House unless the President has recommended its consideration. [cite: 931]

sub_sections.text: Financial Bill (Category I) requires the President's recommendation for introduction/moving and cannot be introduced in the Council of States. [cite: 928]
No recommendation needed for tax reduction/abolition amendments. [cite: 928]
Exclusions from the Financial Bill definition (fines, fees, local taxes). [cite: 931]
Financial Bill (Category II - involving expenditure) requires the President's recommendation for *consideration*. [cite: 931]

article_title: Rules of procedure.
content: Each House may make rules for regulating its procedure and business. [cite: 932]  Until rules are made, the existing rules of the Dominion Legislature shall apply, subject to modifications by the Chairman/Speaker. [cite: 933]  The President may make rules for joint sittings and communications after consulting the Chairman and Speaker. [cite: 933]  The Speaker presides over a joint sitting. [cite: 934]

sub_sections.text: Each House may make its own rules. [cite: 932]
Interim rules: Dominion Legislature rules apply. [cite: 933]
President makes rules for joint sittings/communications after consulting the Chairman and Speaker. [cite: 933]
The Speaker presides over a joint sitting. [cite: 934]

article_title: Regulation by law of procedure in Parliament in relation to financial business.
content: Parliament may regulate by law the procedure and conduct of business in each House related to financial matters (e.g., timely completion of business).  If a law made under this article is inconsistent with a rule of procedure made by a House (under Art. 118), the law shall prevail. [cite: 934]

article_title: Language to be used in Parliament.
content: Business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or in English (subject to Art. 348). [cite: 937]  The presiding officer may permit any member unable to express themselves in Hindi or English to address the House in their mother-tongue. [cite: 938]  The use of English was set to expire after fifteen years from commencement, unless Parliament provided otherwise. [cite: 938]

sub_sections.text: Language in Parliament is Hindi or English. [cite: 937]
Presiding officer may permit use of mother-tongue. [cite: 938]
Original provision for the cessation of English after 15 years. [cite: 938]

article_title: Restriction on discussion in Parliament.
content: No discussion shall take place in Parliament regarding the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of duties, except upon a motion for presenting an address to the President praying for the Judge's removal. [cite: 939]

article_title: Courts not to inquire into proceedings of Parliament.
content: The validity of any proceedings in Parliament shall not be questioned in a court on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure. [cite: 939]  No officer or member of Parliament who has powers for regulating procedure, conduct of business, or maintaining order shall be subject to court jurisdiction for the exercise of those powers. [cite: 940]

sub_sections.text: Courts cannot inquire into the validity of proceedings due to irregularity of procedure. [cite: 939]
Officers/members are protected from court jurisdiction regarding the exercise of their powers to regulate procedure or maintain order. [cite: 940]

article_title: Power of President to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Parliament.
content: If, except when both Houses of Parliament are in session, the President is satisfied that immediate action is necessary, he may promulgate Ordinances. [cite: 941]  An Ordinance has the same force as an Act of Parliament, but must be laid before both Houses and ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly (or sooner if disapproved). [cite: 942]  The President may withdraw an Ordinance at any time. [cite: 944]  An Ordinance making a provision that Parliament could not enact shall be void. [cite: 945]

sub_sections.text: President's power to promulgate Ordinances when Parliament is in recess. [cite: 941]
Ordinance effect and duration (ceases after six weeks of reassembly or sooner if disapproved). [cite: 942, 944]
Ordinance is void if Parliament is incompetent to enact the provision. [cite: 945]

amendments_notes: Clause (4), inserted by the 38th Amendment, 1975, was omitted by the 44th Amendment, 1978. [cite: 946]

article_title: Establishment and constitution of the Supreme Court.
content: There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice of India and, until Parliament prescribes a larger number, of not more than thirty-three other Judges. [cite: 948, 953]  Every Judge is appointed by the President by warrant under hand and seal [cite: 948]  and holds office until age sixty-five. [cite: 948]  A Judge may resign [cite: 951]  or be removed by the President following an address by each House of Parliament (supported by a two-thirds majority of members present and voting and a majority of total membership) on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity. [cite: 952, 960]  Parliament may regulate the procedure for presenting the address and investigating the misbehaviour. [cite: 961]  The age of a Judge is determined by law made by Parliament. [cite: 957]  Qualifications for appointment include being a citizen of India and having five years experience as a High Court Judge, or ten years as a High Court Advocate, or being a distinguished jurist in the President's opinion. [cite: 958, 959]  Judges take an oath (Third Schedule) before entering office. [cite: 961]  No person who has held office as a Supreme Court Judge shall plead or act in any court or before any authority in India. [cite: 962]

sub_sections.text: Constitution: Chief Justice and up to 33 other Judges (number prescribed by Parliament). [cite: 948, 953]
Appointment by the President; tenure up to age 65. [cite: 948]
Age determined by law made by Parliament. [cite: 957]
Qualifications: 5 years HC Judge or 10 years HC Advocate or distinguished jurist. [cite: 958, 959]
Removal procedure (impeachment on grounds of misbehaviour or incapacity). [cite: 960]
Parliament regulates the removal procedure. [cite: 961]
Oath/affirmation (Third Schedule) before office. [cite: 961]
Prohibition on practice after retirement. [cite: 962]

amendments_notes: References to the National Judicial Appointments Commission (124A, etc.) were inserted by the 99th Amendment, 2014, but subsequently struck down by the Supreme Court. [cite: 948, 954, 955]

article_title: National Judicial Appointments Commission.
content: This article was inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-ninth Amendment) Act, 2014, and provided for the constitution of the National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC). [cite: 963]  The NJAC was to consist of the Chief Justice of India (Chairperson), two other senior Supreme Court Judges, the Union Minister in charge of Law and Justice, and two eminent persons nominated by a committee. [cite: 966, 967]  Provisions were made for the nomination of one eminent person from SC/ST/OBC/Minority/Women. [cite: 968]  No act of the Commission was to be invalidated merely due to vacancy/defect. [cite: 969]
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-ninth Amendment) Act, 2014, but subsequently struck down by the Supreme Court in 2015. [cite: 963, 966, 967, 968, 969]

article_title: Functions of Commission.
content: This article, now inoperative, defined the duty of the NJAC to recommend persons for appointment as Chief Justice and Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts, recommend transfer of High Court Judges, and ensure the person recommended is of ability and integrity. [cite: 970, 971]
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-ninth Amendment) Act, 2014, but subsequently struck down by the Supreme Court in 2015. [cite: 970, 971]

article_title: Power of Parliament to make law.
content: This article, now inoperative, stated that Parliament may regulate the procedure for the appointment of Judges and empower the NJAC to lay down regulations for its functions. [cite: 971]
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-ninth Amendment) Act, 2014, but subsequently struck down by the Supreme Court in 2015. [cite: 971]

article_title: Salaries, etc., of Judges.
content: Judges of the Supreme Court shall be paid salaries determined by Parliament by law, or as specified in the Second Schedule until then. [cite: 972]  Every Judge is entitled to privileges, allowances, and rights in respect of leave and pension determined by Parliament or specified in the Second Schedule. [cite: 972]  Neither the privileges/allowances nor the rights regarding leave/pension shall be varied to a Judge's disadvantage after appointment. [cite: 975]

sub_sections.text: Salaries determined by Parliament/Second Schedule. [cite: 972]
Allowances, privileges, and rights in respect of leave and pension determined by Parliament/Second Schedule. [cite: 972]
No variation to disadvantage after appointment. [cite: 975]

amendments_notes: Clause (1) substituted by the Constitution (Fifty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1986. [cite: 972]

article_title: Appointment of acting Chief Justice.
content: When the office of CJI is vacant or the CJI is unable to perform duties, the duties shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint. [cite: 975]

article_title: Appointment of ad hoc Judges.
content: If a quorum of Supreme Court Judges is unavailable, the Chief Justice of India may, with the President's previous consent and after consulting the High Court Chief Justice concerned, request a qualified High Court Judge to attend as an ad hoc Judge. [cite: 976]  The designated Judge must prioritize the Supreme Court sitting and, while attending, has the jurisdiction, powers, and privileges of a Supreme Court Judge. [cite: 976]

sub_sections.text: CJI appoints ad hoc Judges (from HCs) with the President's consent if a quorum is lacking. [cite: 976]
Ad hoc Judge has the powers and privileges of a Supreme Court Judge. [cite: 976]

amendments_notes: References to the NJAC inserted by the 99th Amendment, 2014, but subsequently struck down by the Supreme Court in 2015. [cite: 976]

article_title: Attendance of retired Judges at sittings of the Supreme Court.
content: The Chief Justice of India may, with the President's previous consent, request any retired Supreme Court or Federal Court Judge, or a retired High Court Judge qualified for the Supreme Court, to sit and act as a Supreme Court Judge. [cite: 977]  Such a person is entitled to allowances determined by the President and possesses the jurisdiction, powers, and privileges of a Supreme Court Judge, but is not deemed to be one. [cite: 977]  They are not required to sit unless they consent. [cite: 981]

sub_sections.text: CJI may request retired Judges (with President's consent) to sit and act as Judges of the Supreme Court. [cite: 977]
The Judge must consent to sit. [cite: 981]

amendments_notes: References to the NJAC inserted by the 99th Amendment, 2014, but subsequently struck down by the Supreme Court in 2015. [cite: 978]

article_title: Supreme Court to be a court of record.
content: The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself. [cite: 981]

article_title: Seat of Supreme Court.
content: The Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or in such other place or places as the Chief Justice of India may, with the approval of the President, from time to time, appoint. [cite: 982]

article_title: Original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
content: The Supreme Court has exclusive original jurisdiction in disputes: between the Government of India and one or more States; [cite: 983]  between the Government of India and any State(s) on one side and one or more other States on the other; [cite: 983]  or between two or more States, [cite: 984]  where the dispute involves a question (of law or fact) on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends. [cite: 984]  This jurisdiction does not extend to disputes arising out of pre-commencement treaties, agreements, etc., that continue in operation or exclude such jurisdiction. [cite: 985]

sub_sections.text: Original jurisdiction over disputes between the Union and States, or between States. [cite: 983, 984]
Excludes disputes arising from pre-commencement treaties/agreements. [cite: 985]

amendments_notes: The proviso was substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956. Article 131A was omitted by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977. [cite: 985, 987]

article_title: Appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in certain cases.
content: An appeal lies to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree, or final order of a High Court in any proceeding (civil, criminal, or other) if the High Court certifies (under Art. 134A) that the case involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution. [cite: 986]  Where a certificate is given, any party may appeal on the ground that the constitutional question was wrongly decided. [cite: 991]  'Final order' includes an order deciding an issue which would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case if decided in the appellant's favour. [cite: 992]

sub_sections.text: Appeal lies if HC certifies a substantial question of law regarding Constitutional interpretation. [cite: 986]
Party may appeal on the ground that the constitutional question was wrongly decided. [cite: 991]
Definition of 'final order'. [cite: 992]

amendments_notes: Clause (2) omitted and Clause (1) and (3) amended by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 987, 996, 997]

article_title: Appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in regard to civil matters.
content: An appeal lies to the Supreme Court from a High Court judgment/decree/final order in a civil proceeding if the High Court certifies (under Art. 134A) that the case involves a substantial question of law of general importance and the question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court. [cite: 992, 993]  The appellant may argue that a substantial constitutional question was wrongly decided, even if they appeal under this article. [cite: 993]  No appeal lies from the decision of a single High Court Judge, unless Parliament provides otherwise. [cite: 994]

sub_sections.text: Appeal lies if HC certifies: (a) substantial question of law of general importance, AND (b) SC decision is needed. [cite: 992, 993]
Appeals may include the ground that a constitutional question was wrongly decided. [cite: 993]
No appeal from a single HC Judge (unless Parliament provides). [cite: 994]

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and (3) substituted/amended by the 30th and 44th Amendments. [cite: 997, 998]

article_title: Appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in regard to criminal matters.
content: An appeal lies to the Supreme Court from a High Court criminal judgment/final order/sentence if the High Court: has reversed an acquittal and sentenced the accused to death; or has withdrawn a case for trial before itself, convicted, and sentenced the accused to death; [cite: 995]  or certifies (under Art. 134A) that the case is a fit one for appeal (subject to SC rules/HC conditions). [cite: 996, 1001]  Parliament may confer further appellate powers on the Supreme Court by law. [cite: 1001]

sub_sections.text: Appeal lies if HC: (a) reversed acquittal and sentenced to death; (b) convicted and sentenced to death in a withdrawn case; or (c) certifies under Art.  134A. [cite: 995, 996, 1001]
Parliament may confer further appellate powers by law. [cite: 1001]

amendments_notes: Clause (1)(c) amended by the 44th Amendment, 1978. [cite: 998]

article_title: Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court.
content: Every High Court passing a judgment/decree/order/sentence referred to in Articles 132(1), 133(1), or 134(1) may, on its own motion, and shall, if an oral application is made by the aggrieved party immediately after the passing, determine the question of whether a certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court should be given. [cite: 1002, 1003]

sub_sections.text: HC must determine whether to grant a certificate for appeal to the SC (either suo motu or upon oral application). [cite: 1002, 1003]

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 1006]

article_title: Jurisdiction and powers of the Federal Court under existing law to be exercisable by the Supreme Court.
content: Until Parliament provides otherwise, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to matters not covered by Articles 133 or 134 if the Federal Court was exercisable these powers immediately before the commencement of this Constitution under any existing law. [cite: 1004]

article_title: Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Supreme Court may, in its discretion, grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed or made by any court or tribunal in the territory of India. [cite: 1004]  This power does not apply to judgments, etc., passed by any court or tribunal constituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces. [cite: 1005]

sub_sections.text: SC's discretionary power to grant Special Leave to Appeal (SLA) from any court/tribunal. [cite: 1004]
SLA does not apply to Armed Forces courts/tribunals. [cite: 1005]

article_title: Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court.
content: Subject to Parliamentary law or rules under Article 145, the Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it. [cite: 1005]

article_title: Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
content: Parliament may, by law, confer further jurisdiction and powers on the Supreme Court with respect to any matters in the Union List. [cite: 1008]  The SC may also have further jurisdiction/powers with respect to any matter if conferred by special agreement between the Government of India and any State Government, provided Parliament by law provides for the exercise of such jurisdiction. [cite: 1009]

sub_sections.text: Parliament may enlarge SC jurisdiction re: Union List matters. [cite: 1008]
SC jurisdiction enlarged by Union-State agreement, provided Parliament legislates for its exercise. [cite: 1009]

article_title: Conferment on the Supreme Court of powers to issue certain writs.
content: Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court power to issue directions, orders or writs (including habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari) for any purposes other than the enforcement of Fundamental Rights (Art. 32(2)). [cite: 1009]

article_title: Transfer of certain cases.
content: Where cases with the same or substantially the same substantial questions of law of general importance are pending before the Supreme Court and one or more High Courts, or two or more High Courts, the Supreme Court may withdraw and dispose of all the cases itself (suo motu or on application). [cite: 1010]  Alternatively, the SC may return the withdrawn case to the High Court after determining the question of law. [cite: 1010]  The Supreme Court may also transfer any case/appeal/proceeding pending before any High Court to any other High Court if expedient for the ends of justice. [cite: 1011]

sub_sections.text: SC power to withdraw cases involving the same substantial question of law from HCs and dispose of them, or return them with a judgment on the question. [cite: 1010]
SC power to transfer cases/appeals/proceedings between High Courts. [cite: 1011]

amendments_notes: Inserted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and Clause (1) substituted by the 44th Amendment, 1978. [cite: 1012]

article_title: Ancillary powers of the Supreme Court.
content: Parliament may by law make provision for conferring upon the Supreme Court such supplemental powers, not inconsistent with this Constitution, as may be necessary or desirable for the Court to exercise its jurisdiction more effectively. [cite: 1011]

article_title: Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts.
content: The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India. [cite: 1014]

article_title: Enforcement of decrees and orders of the Supreme Court and orders as to discovery, etc.
content: The Supreme Court may pass any decree or make any order necessary for doing complete justice in any cause or matter pending before it, and such decree/order is enforceable throughout India. [cite: 1015]  The SC has all power to make any order for securing the attendance of any person, discovery/production of documents, or the investigation/punishment of any contempt of itself. [cite: 1016]

sub_sections.text: SC power to pass decrees/orders for doing 'complete justice' (enforceable throughout India). [cite: 1015]
SC power regarding attendance of persons, discovery of documents, and punishment for contempt. [cite: 1016]

article_title: Power of the President to consult the Supreme Court.
content: If the President feels a question of law or fact of public importance has arisen or is likely to arise, he may refer the question to the Supreme Court for consideration and opinion. [cite: 1016]  The President may also refer a pre-commencement dispute (of the kind mentioned in the proviso to Art. 131) to the SC for opinion, and the SC shall report its opinion thereon. [cite: 1017]

sub_sections.text: President may refer questions of law/fact of public importance for SC opinion. [cite: 1016]
President may refer pre-commencement disputes (excluded by Art. 131 proviso) for SC opinion. [cite: 1017]

article_title: Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court.
content: All authorities, civil and judicial, in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court. [cite: 1017]

article_title: [Special provisions as to disposal of questions relating to constitutional validity of laws.]
content: This article was omitted. [cite: 1018]
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, and omitted by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977. [cite: 1018]

article_title: Rules of Court, etc.
content: The Supreme Court may, with the President's approval and subject to Parliamentary law, make rules for regulating the practice and procedure of the Court (e.g., persons practising, hearing appeals, enforcement of FRs, review, costs). [cite: 1018, 1019, 1024, 1025, 1026, 1027, 1028]  Rules may fix the minimum number of Judges for any purpose. [cite: 1028]  A minimum of five Judges must sit for deciding any case involving a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution (or a reference under Art. 143). [cite: 1029]  Judgments/opinions must be delivered in open court with the concurrence of a majority of Judges present (Judges may deliver a dissenting judgment). [cite: 1034]

sub_sections.text: SC power to make rules of practice and procedure (with President's approval/subject to Parliamentary law). [cite: 1018]
Rules may fix minimum number of Judges (quorum) and powers of single/Division Courts. [cite: 1028]
Minimum quorum of five Judges for Constitutional interpretation and Article 143 references. [cite: 1029]
Judgment/opinion must be delivered in open Court. [cite: 1034]
Decision requires majority concurrence. [cite: 1034]

amendments_notes: Clause (1)(cc) inserted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and amended by the 43rd Amendment, 1977. Clause (2) and (3) amended by the 42nd and 43rd Amendments. [cite: 1029, 1030, 1031]

article_title: Officers and servants and the expenses of the Supreme Court.
content: Appointments of SC officers and servants are made by the CJI (or his appointee), though the President may require consultation with the UPSC in certain cases. [cite: 1035]  Conditions of service are prescribed by rules made by the CJI (or his appointee), subject to Parliamentary law, and require the President's approval if they relate to salaries, allowances, leave, or pensions. [cite: 1036]  The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court (salaries, allowances, pensions, etc.) are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India. [cite: 1037]

sub_sections.text: Appointments by CJI (subject to President's rule requiring UPSC consultation). [cite: 1035]
Conditions of service prescribed by CJI's rules (subject to Parliamentary law and President's approval for financial matters). [cite: 1036]
Administrative expenses are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India. [cite: 1037]

article_title: Interpretation.
content: References to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution shall be construed as including references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Government of India Act, 1935, or any Order in Council/order made thereunder, or the Indian Independence Act, 1947, or any order made thereunder. [cite: 1039]

article_title: Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.
content: There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor-General (CAG) of India, appointed by the President. [cite: 1040]  The CAG can only be removed in like manner and on the like grounds as a Judge of the Supreme Court. [cite: 1040]  The CAG takes an oath (Third Schedule) before office. [cite: 1041]  Salary and conditions of service are determined by Parliament by law, or as specified in the Second Schedule, and shall not be varied to his disadvantage after appointment. [cite: 1041, 1042]  The CAG is ineligible for further office under the Government of India or any State after ceasing to hold office. [cite: 1042]  The conditions of service for the Indian Audit and Accounts Department staff and the CAG's administrative powers are prescribed by President's rules after consulting the CAG. [cite: 1043]  Administrative expenses of the CAG's office are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India. [cite: 1043]

sub_sections.text: Appointment and removal procedure (like a Supreme Court Judge). [cite: 1040]
Oath/affirmation (Third Schedule). [cite: 1041]
Salary and conditions of service determined by Parliament/Second Schedule (cannot be varied to his disadvantage). [cite: 1041, 1042]
Ineligible for further government office after demitting office. [cite: 1042]
Conditions of service for staff and administrative powers prescribed by President's rules (after consulting CAG). [cite: 1043]
Administrative expenses charged on the Consolidated Fund of India. [cite: 1043]

article_title: Duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General.
content: The CAG shall perform duties and exercise powers in relation to the accounts of the Union and of the States and of any other authority/body as prescribed by Parliament by law, or as conferred on the Auditor-General of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution. [cite: 1046]

article_title: Form of accounts of the Union and of the States.
content: The accounts of the Union and of the States shall be kept in such form as the President may, on the advice of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, prescribe. [cite: 1046]
amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, and amended by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978. [cite: 1048]

article_title: Audit reports.
content: The CAG's reports on the accounts of the Union shall be submitted to the President, who shall cause them to be laid before each House of Parliament. [cite: 1047]  The reports on a State's accounts shall be submitted to the Governor of the State, who shall cause them to be laid before the State Legislature. [cite: 1047]

sub_sections.text: Union audit reports go to the President, who tables them in Parliament. [cite: 1047]
State audit reports go to the Governor, who tables them in the State Legislature. [cite: 1047]

article_title: Definition.
content: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression 'State' does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir[cite: 1050].
amendments_notes: The initial reference to States in Part A of the First Schedule was omitted and the exclusion of the State of Jammu and Kashmir was substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1050].

article_title: Governors of States.
content: There shall be a Governor for each State[cite: 1050].  Nothing in this article shall prevent the appointment of the same person as Governor for two or more States[cite: 1050].

sub_sections.text: There shall be a Governor for each State[cite: 1050].
Nothing in this article shall prevent the appointment of the same person as Governor for two or more States[cite: 1050].

amendments_notes: Proviso added by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1050].

article_title: Executive power of State.
content: The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution[cite: 1050].  This shall not be deemed to transfer to the Governor any functions conferred by any existing law on any other authority; or prevent Parliament or the Legislature of the State from conferring by law functions on any authority subordinate to the Governor[cite: 1050].

sub_sections.text: The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and exercised by him directly or through subordinate officers[cite: 1050].
Nothing shall be deemed to transfer to the Governor functions conferred by existing law on any other authority[cite: 1050].
Nothing shall prevent Parliament or the State Legislature from conferring functions by law on any authority subordinate to the Governor[cite: 1050].

article_title: Appointment of Governor.
content: The Governor of a State shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal[cite: 1050].

article_title: Term of office of Governor.
content: The Governor shall hold office during the pleasure of the President[cite: 1050].  The Governor may resign to the President[cite: 1050].  Subject to the foregoing provisions, a Governor holds office for a term of five years from the date of entering office[cite: 1050].  Notwithstanding the expiration of his term, a Governor shall continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his office[cite: 1051].

sub_sections.text: The Governor shall hold office during the pleasure of the President[cite: 1050].
The Governor may resign to the President[cite: 1050].
The Governor shall hold office for a term of five years[cite: 1050].
The Governor continues to hold office until his successor enters upon office[cite: 1051].

article_title: Qualifications for appointment as Governor.
content: No person shall be eligible for appointment as Governor unless he is a citizen of India and has completed the age of thirty-five years[cite: 1051].

article_title: Conditions of Governor's office.
content: The Governor shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or a State Legislature (seat automatically vacated upon taking office)[cite: 1051].  The Governor shall not hold any other office of profit[cite: 1051].  The Governor is entitled to free use of his official residences and to emoluments, allowances, and privileges determined by Parliament, or as specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 1051].  If the same person is appointed Governor of two or more States, emoluments and allowances shall be allocated among the States as the President determines by order[cite: 1051].  The emoluments and allowances shall not be diminished during the term of office[cite: 1051].

sub_sections.text: The Governor cannot be a member of Parliament or a State Legislature (seat automatically vacated)[cite: 1051].
The Governor shall not hold any other office of profit[cite: 1051].
Entitled to official residences, emoluments, allowances, and privileges determined by Parliament/Second Schedule[cite: 1051].
Emoluments and allowances for a Governor of two or more States shall be allocated by President's order[cite: 1051].
Emoluments and allowances shall not be diminished during the term of office[cite: 1051].

amendments_notes: Clause (3A) inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1051].

article_title: Oath or affirmation by the Governor.
content: Every Governor and every person discharging the functions of the Governor shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe an oath or affirmation before the Chief Justice of the High Court (or senior-most available Judge), pledging to faithfully execute the office, preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and the law, and devote themselves to the service and well-being of the people of the State[cite: 1051].

sub_sections.text: Prescribes the form and procedure for the Governor's oath or affirmation[cite: 1051].

article_title: Discharge of the functions of the Governor in certain contingencies.
content: The President may make such provision as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the Governor of a State in any contingency not provided for in this Chapter[cite: 1052].

article_title: Power of Governor to grant pardons, etc., and to suspend, remit or commute sentences in certain cases.
content: The Governor of a State shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment or to suspend, remit or commute the sentence of any person convicted of any offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the State extends[cite: 1052].

article_title: Extent of executive power of State.
content: The executive power of a State extends to the matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has power to make laws[cite: 1052].  In any matter where the State Legislature and Parliament both have power to make laws (Concurrent List), the State's executive power shall be subject to, and limited by, the executive power expressly conferred by the Constitution or Parliamentary law upon the Union or its authorities[cite: 1052].

sub_sections.text: The executive power of a State extends to the matters where the State Legislature has power to make laws[cite: 1052].
In Concurrent List matters, the State's executive power is limited by the Union's executive power conferred by the Constitution or Parliamentary law[cite: 1052].

article_title: Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor.
content: There shall be a Council of Ministers (COM) with the Chief Minister (CM) at the head to aid and advise the Governor, except in so far as the Governor is required to exercise functions in his discretion[cite: 1052].  If any question arises as to whether a matter is one requiring the Governor to act in his discretion, the Governor's decision in his discretion is final, and the validity of anything done by the Governor cannot be questioned on the ground that he ought or ought not to have acted in his discretion[cite: 1052].  The question of whether, and what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the Governor shall not be inquired into in any court[cite: 1052].

sub_sections.text: COM (with CM as head) to aid and advise the Governor, except for discretionary functions[cite: 1052].
Governor's decision is final on whether a matter falls under his discretion (judicial inquiry is barred)[cite: 1052].
Judicial inquiry into the advice tendered by Ministers is barred[cite: 1052].

article_title: Other provisions as to Ministers.
content: The Chief Minister (CM) is appointed by the Governor, and other Ministers are appointed by the Governor on the CM's advice, holding office during the pleasure of the Governor[cite: 1052].  In the States of Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, and Odisha, there shall be a Minister in charge of tribal welfare[cite: 1053].  The total number of Ministers, including the CM, shall not exceed fifteen per cent. of the total number of members of the Legislative Assembly of that State, and shall not be less than twelve[cite: 1053].  A disqualified member of the State Legislature under the Tenth Schedule is also disqualified to be appointed as a Minister[cite: 1053].  The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly of the State[cite: 1053].  Oaths of office and secrecy are administered by the Governor (Third Schedule)[cite: 1053].  A non-member of the Legislature for six consecutive months ceases to be a Minister[cite: 1054].  Salaries and allowances are determined by the State Legislature or specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 1054].
