sub_sections.text: Appointment procedure and tenure (CM appointed by Governor; Ministers appointed by Governor on CM's advice; hold office during Governor's pleasure)[cite: 1052].
Mandatory Tribal Welfare Minister in Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, and Odisha[cite: 1053].
Ceiling (15%) and floor (12) on Council of Ministers size[cite: 1053].
Disqualification provisions for Ministers under the Tenth Schedule[cite: 1053].
Collective responsibility to the Legislative Assembly[cite: 1053].
Oaths of office and secrecy (Third Schedule)[cite: 1053].
Six-month limit for a non-Legislature Minister[cite: 1054].
Salaries and allowances determined by the State Legislature/Second Schedule[cite: 1054].

amendments_notes: Proviso to cl. (1)  substituted by 94th Amendment, 2006 (adding Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand)[cite: 1053].  Clauses (1A) and (1B) inserted by the 91st Amendment, 2003[cite: 1053].  'Orissa' substituted with 'Odisha' by Act 15 of 2011[cite: 1053].

article_title: Advocate-General for the State.
content: The Governor of each State shall appoint a person qualified to be a High Court Judge to be Advocate-General (AG) for the State[cite: 1054].  The AG's duty is to advise the State Government on legal matters, perform legal duties assigned by the Governor, and discharge functions conferred by the Constitution or law[cite: 1054].  The AG holds office during the pleasure of the Governor and receives remuneration determined by the Governor[cite: 1054].

sub_sections.text: Appointment and qualification (High Court Judge qualification)[cite: 1054].
Duties (to advise Government, perform legal duties assigned by the Governor)[cite: 1054].
Tenure (pleasure of the Governor) and remuneration (determined by the Governor)[cite: 1054].

article_title: Conduct of Business of the Government of a State.
content: All executive action of the Government of a State shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor[cite: 1054].  Orders and instruments made and executed in the Governor's name shall be authenticated as specified in rules made by the Governor, and the validity of a so-authenticated order cannot be questioned[cite: 1054].  The Governor shall make rules for the convenient transaction of State Government business and its allocation among Ministers, excluding matters requiring the Governor to act in his discretion[cite: 1054].

sub_sections.text: Executive action is taken in the name of the Governor[cite: 1054].
Authentication of orders and instruments (validity cannot be questioned)[cite: 1054].
Governor makes rules for convenient business transaction and allocation (excluding discretionary matters)[cite: 1054].

amendments_notes: Clause (4), inserted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, was omitted by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1055].

article_title: Duties of Chief Minister as respects the furnishing of information to Governor, etc.
content: The Chief Minister's duties include communicating all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to administration and proposals for legislation to the Governor; furnishing any information the Governor calls for relating to administration and legislation; and if the Governor requires it, submitting any matter decided by a Minister (but the COM has not considered) for the consideration of the Council of Ministers[cite: 1055].

sub_sections.text: To communicate all COM decisions and legislative proposals to the Governor[cite: 1055].
To furnish any information requested by the Governor[cite: 1055].
To submit for COM consideration any matter decided by a Minister but not considered by the COM, if required by the Governor[cite: 1055].

article_title: Constitution of Legislatures in States.
content: For every State, there shall be a Legislature consisting of the Governor, and: two Houses in the States of Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, and Uttar Pradesh; and one House in other States[cite: 1055, 1056].  Where there are two Houses, one is the Legislative Council and the other the Legislative Assembly; where there is one House, it is the Legislative Assembly[cite: 1056].

sub_sections.text: Legislature consists of the Governor and [cite: 1055] : (a) two Houses in: Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, and Uttar Pradesh[cite: 1056]; (b)  one House in other States[cite: 1056].
The two Houses are the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly; the single House is the Legislative Assembly[cite: 1056].

amendments_notes: List of bicameral states has seen numerous additions/omissions due to reorganization and abolition/creation of Legislative Councils[cite: 1055, 1056].

article_title: Abolition or creation of Legislative Councils in States.
content: Parliament may by law provide for the abolition of a Legislative Council or for the creation of such a Council, if the Legislative Assembly of the State passes a resolution to that effect by a majority of the total membership and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting[cite: 1056].  Any such law must contain necessary amendments to the Constitution, but shall not be deemed to be an amendment of the Constitution for the purposes of Article 368[cite: 1056].

sub_sections.text: Parliament can abolish or create a Legislative Council if the Legislative Assembly passes a resolution with a special majority[cite: 1056].
A law under this article is not deemed an amendment for the purposes of Article 368[cite: 1056].

article_title: Composition of the Legislative Assemblies.
content: Subject to Article 333, the Legislative Assembly of each State shall consist of not more than five hundred, and not less than sixty, members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the State[cite: 1056].  Each State shall be divided into territorial constituencies such that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted is, as far as practicable, the same throughout the State[cite: 1056].  'Population' means the last preceding published census figure, currently referring to the 2001 census until figures for the first census after 2026 are published[cite: 1057].  Readjustment based on census data is performed by a mechanism Parliament determines, but is currently frozen regarding the total number of seats (1971 census) and territorial constituencies (2001 census) until after 2026[cite: 1057].

sub_sections.text: Max 500, min 60 members chosen by direct election[cite: 1056].
Constituencies defined by a uniform population/seat ratio[cite: 1056].
Defines 'population' and specifies the census freeze until after 2026[cite: 1057].
Readjustment after each census (currently frozen)[cite: 1057].

amendments_notes: Article 170 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1056].  Explanation regarding census reference amended multiple times, setting the current freeze until after 2026 based on the 1971 and 2001 census figures[cite: 1057].

article_title: Composition of the Legislative Councils.
content: The total number of members in the Legislative Council of a State shall not exceed one-third of the total number of members in the Legislative Assembly of that State, but in no case shall be less than forty[cite: 1058].  The composition (until Parliament provides otherwise) is specified: one-third elected by local authorities; one-twelfth elected by graduates; one-twelfth elected by teachers (secondary level and above); one-third elected by members of the Legislative Assembly from non-members; and the remainder nominated by the Governor[cite: 1058, 1059].  Governor's nominees must have special knowledge or practical experience in literature, science, art, co-operative movement, and social service[cite: 1059].  Elections use the proportional representation system (single transferable vote)[cite: 1059].

sub_sections.text: Max membership is one-third of Assembly strength (min 40 members)[cite: 1058].
Detailed breakdown of seat allocation by election (local authorities, graduates, teachers, MLAs) and nomination by the Governor[cite: 1058].
Governor's nominations based on special experience in literature, science, art, co-operative movement, and social service[cite: 1059].

amendments_notes: Max membership ratio changed from one-fourth to one-third by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1058].

article_title: Duration of State Legislatures.
content: The Legislative Assembly (LA) continues for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting, unless sooner dissolved[cite: 1059].  This period may be extended by Parliament by law for up to one year at a time during a Proclamation of Emergency, not extending beyond six months after the Proclamation ceases to operate[cite: 1059].  The Legislative Council is not subject to dissolution, but approximately one-third of its members retire every second year[cite: 1059].

sub_sections.text: Legislative Assembly duration is five years (with emergency extension provisions)[cite: 1059].
Legislative Council is permanent (one-third retire every two years)[cite: 1059].

amendments_notes: The term was changed from five years to six years by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and back to five years by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1059].

article_title: Qualification for membership of the State Legislature.
content: A person must be a citizen of India and subscribe to an oath/affirmation (Third Schedule)[cite: 1059].  For the Legislative Assembly, the age must be at least twenty-five years; for the Legislative Council, at least thirty years[cite: 1060].  They must also possess any other qualifications prescribed by or under law made by Parliament[cite: 1060].

sub_sections.text: Citizen of India and subscribing to the oath/affirmation (Third Schedule)[cite: 1059].
Age: 25 years for Legislative Assembly, 30 years for Legislative Council[cite: 1060].
Possessing other qualifications prescribed by Parliament[cite: 1060].

amendments_notes: Clause (a) substituted by the Constitution (Sixteenth Amendment) Act, 1963[cite: 1059].

article_title: Sessions of the State Legislature, prorogation and dissolution.
content: The Governor shall summon the House or each House to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, but six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session[cite: 1060].  The Governor may also prorogue the House or either House, or dissolve the Legislative Assembly[cite: 1060].

sub_sections.text: Governor summons Houses; max six-month gap between sessions[cite: 1060].
Governor may prorogue the Houses or dissolve the Legislative Assembly[cite: 1060].

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951[cite: 1060].

article_title: Right of Governor to address and send messages to the House or Houses.
content: The Governor may address the Legislative Assembly or both Houses assembled together and may require the attendance of members[cite: 1060].  The Governor may send messages to the House(s), whether regarding a pending Bill or otherwise, and the House must consider the matter required by the message[cite: 1060].

sub_sections.text: Governor's right to address and require attendance[cite: 1060].
Governor's right to send messages, and the House's duty to consider them[cite: 1060].

article_title: Special address by the Governor.
content: At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the Legislative Assembly and at the commencement of the first session of each year, the Governor shall address the Legislative Assembly (or both Houses assembled together) and inform the Legislature of the causes of its summons[cite: 1060].  Rules must provide time for discussion of the matters referred to in the address[cite: 1060].

sub_sections.text: Governor addresses House(s) at the start of the first session after each general election and the first session of each year[cite: 1060].
Rules must provide time for discussion of the address[cite: 1060].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and (2) amended by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951[cite: 1060].

article_title: Rights of Ministers and Advocate-General as respects the Houses.
content: Every Minister and the Advocate-General for a State have the right to speak in, and take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Assembly (or both Houses) and any committee of the Legislature of which he may be named a member, but are not entitled to vote by virtue of this article[cite: 1061].

article_title: The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly.
content: Every Legislative Assembly shall choose two members to be Speaker and Deputy Speaker, and whenever either office becomes vacant, the Assembly shall choose another member[cite: 1061].

article_title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker.
content: A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker vacates if they cease to be a member of the Assembly; may resign by writing to the Deputy Speaker (Speaker) or Speaker (Deputy Speaker); and may be removed by a resolution of the Assembly passed by a majority of all the then members (requires 14 days' notice)[cite: 1061].  The Speaker does not vacate office upon dissolution of the Assembly until immediately before the first meeting of the new Assembly[cite: 1061].

sub_sections.text: Vacates if ceases to be a member of the Assembly[cite: 1061].
May resign (Speaker to Deputy Speaker, and vice versa)[cite: 1061].
May be removed by a resolution of the Assembly (requires majority and 14 days' notice)[cite: 1061].
Speaker does not vacate upon dissolution until the first meeting of the new Assembly[cite: 1061].

article_title: Power of the Deputy Speaker or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Speaker.
content: When the office of Speaker is vacant, the Deputy Speaker (or a member appointed by the Governor) performs the duties[cite: 1061].  During the absence of the Speaker from a sitting, the Deputy Speaker (or a person determined by rules/Assembly) acts as Speaker[cite: 1061].

sub_sections.text: Deputy Speaker (or Governor's appointee) performs duties when the Speakership is vacant[cite: 1061].
Deputy Speaker (or other determined person) acts as Speaker during absence from a sitting[cite: 1061].

article_title: The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration.
content: Neither the Speaker nor the Deputy Speaker shall preside over a sitting while a resolution for their removal is under consideration[cite: 1062].  The Speaker has the right to speak and participate in the proceedings for his removal and is entitled to vote only in the first instance (not a casting vote)[cite: 1062].

sub_sections.text: Speaker/Deputy Speaker cannot preside while a resolution for their removal is under consideration[cite: 1062].
The Speaker may speak and participate in proceedings for his removal and has a right to vote in the first instance (no casting vote)[cite: 1062].

article_title: The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council.
content: The Legislative Council of every State having such Council shall choose two members to be Chairman and Deputy Chairman, and whenever either office becomes vacant, the Council shall choose another member[cite: 1062].

article_title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Chairman and Deputy Chairman.
content: A member holding office as Chairman or Deputy Chairman vacates if they cease to be a member of the Council; may resign by writing to the Deputy Chairman (Chairman) or Chairman (Deputy Chairman); and may be removed by a resolution of the Council passed by a majority of all the then members (requires 14 days' notice)[cite: 1062].

sub_sections.text: Vacates if ceases to be a member of the Council[cite: 1062].
May resign (Chairman to Deputy Chairman, and vice versa)[cite: 1062].
May be removed by a Council resolution (requires majority and 14 days' notice)[cite: 1062].

article_title: Power of the Deputy Chairman or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Chairman.
content: When the office of Chairman is vacant, the Deputy Chairman (or a member appointed by the Governor) performs the duties[cite: 1062].  During the absence of the Chairman from a sitting, the Deputy Chairman (or a person determined by rules/Council) acts as Chairman[cite: 1063].

sub_sections.text: Deputy Chairman (or Governor's appointee) performs duties when the Chairmanship is vacant[cite: 1062].
Deputy Chairman (or other determined person) acts as Chairman during absence from a sitting[cite: 1063].

article_title: The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration.
content: Neither the Chairman nor the Deputy Chairman shall preside over a sitting while a resolution for their removal is under consideration[cite: 1063].  The Chairman has the right to speak and participate in the proceedings for his removal and is entitled to vote only in the first instance (not a casting vote)[cite: 1063].

sub_sections.text: Chairman/Deputy Chairman cannot preside while a resolution for their removal is under consideration[cite: 1063].
The Chairman may speak and participate in proceedings for his removal and has a right to vote in the first instance (no casting vote)[cite: 1063].

article_title: Salaries and allowances of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker and the Chairman and Deputy Chairman.
content: Salaries and allowances for the Speaker, Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, and the Chairman, Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council shall be fixed by the State Legislature by law, or as specified in the Second Schedule until then[cite: 1063].

article_title: Secretariat of State Legislature.
content: The House or each House shall have a separate secretarial staff (with provision for common posts for bicameral Legislatures)[cite: 1063].  The State Legislature may regulate the recruitment and conditions of service for the staff by law[cite: 1064].  Until such law is made, the Governor may make rules after consultation with the Speaker/Chairman[cite: 1064].

sub_sections.text: Separate secretarial staff for each House (with provision for common posts)[cite: 1063].
State Legislature regulates staff recruitment and conditions of service by law[cite: 1064].
Governor makes interim rules after consultation with the Speaker/Chairman[cite: 1064].

article_title: Oath or affirmation by members.
content: Every member shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the Governor (or appointee) an oath or affirmation according to the form set out in the Third Schedule[cite: 1064].

article_title: Voting in Houses, power of Houses to act notwithstanding vacancies and quorum.
content: All questions are determined by a majority of members present and voting, excluding the presiding officer, who has a casting vote in case of equality[cite: 1064].  The Houses can act notwithstanding any vacancy, and proceedings are valid even if an ineligible person sat or voted[cite: 1064].  Until the Legislature provides otherwise, the quorum is ten members or one-tenth of the total members, whichever is greater[cite: 1064].  If there is no quorum, the presiding officer must adjourn or suspend the meeting[cite: 1064].

sub_sections.text: Decision by majority of present and voting; presiding officer has a casting vote[cite: 1064].
Houses can act despite vacancies (proceedings remain valid)[cite: 1064].
Quorum is ten members or one-tenth of total members, whichever is greater (until Legislature provides otherwise)[cite: 1064].
Lack of quorum requires adjournment or suspension[cite: 1064].

amendments_notes: Clauses (3) and (4) were temporarily omitted and then restored by the 42nd and 44th Amendments respectively[cite: 1064].

article_title: Vacation of seats.
content: A person cannot be a member of both Houses of a State Legislature (provision for vacation must be made by law)[cite: 1065].  A person cannot be a member of the Legislatures of two or more States (seat becomes vacant after a specified period unless resigned from all but one)[cite: 1065].  A member's seat becomes vacant if they incur disqualification under Article 191(1) or 191(2), or resign in writing and the resignation is accepted by the Speaker/Chairman[cite: 1065].  The resignation is not accepted if the presiding officer determines it is not voluntary or genuine[cite: 1065].  A seat is vacated if the member is absent from all meetings for sixty days without permission[cite: 1065].

sub_sections.text: Prohibition on membership of both Houses of a State Legislature[cite: 1065].
Prohibition on simultaneous membership of Legislatures of two or more States[cite: 1065].
Seat vacated on: (a) disqualification under Article 191(1) or 191(2), or (b) acceptance of resignation[cite: 1065].
Resignation must be voluntary and genuine to be accepted[cite: 1065].
Seat vacated for 60 days' unauthorized absence[cite: 1065].

amendments_notes: Clause (3)(a) amended by the 52nd Amendment, 1985[cite: 1065].  Clause (3)(b) and its proviso inserted/substituted by the 33rd Amendment, 1974[cite: 1065].

article_title: Disqualifications for membership.
content: A person is disqualified if they hold any office of profit under the Government of India or any State (unless the State Legislature exempts it by law) [cite: 1066] ; are of unsound mind (declared by a competent court); are an undischarged insolvent; are not a citizen of India, have voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship, or acknowledge allegiance to a foreign State; or are disqualified by or under any law made by Parliament[cite: 1066].  Holding the office of Minister is not considered holding an office of profit[cite: 1066].  A person is also disqualified if they are so disqualified under the Tenth Schedule (defection)[cite: 1066].

sub_sections.text: Holding an unexempted office of profit[cite: 1066].
Unsound mind[cite: 1066].
Undischarged insolvent[cite: 1066].
Loss of Indian citizenship/acquiring foreign citizenship[cite: 1066].
Disqualification by Parliamentary law[cite: 1066].
Ministerial office is not an office of profit[cite: 1066].
Disqualification under the Tenth Schedule (defection)[cite: 1066].

amendments_notes: Clause (1)(a) saw substitution attempts and omissions by the 42nd and 44th Amendments[cite: 1066].  Clause (2) inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-second Amendment) Act, 1985[cite: 1066].

article_title: Decision on questions as to disqualifications of members.
content: If a question arises regarding a member's disqualification under Article 191(1), it is referred to the Governor for a final decision[cite: 1066].  Before giving any decision, the Governor must obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and shall act according to such opinion[cite: 1067].

sub_sections.text: Disqualification questions (under Article 191(1)) are decided by the Governor (decision is final)[cite: 1066].
The Governor must consult the Election Commission and act according to its opinion[cite: 1067].

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 and further substituted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1066, 1067].

article_title: Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under article 188 or when not qualified or when disqualified.
content: Any person who sits or votes in a State Legislature without taking the oath, or when disqualified/not qualified, is liable to a penalty of five hundred rupees for each day, recoverable as a debt due to the State[cite: 1067].

article_title: Powers, privileges, etc., of the Houses of Legislatures and of the members and committees thereof.
content: Subject to the Constitution and the rules of procedure, there shall be freedom of speech in the Legislature of every State[cite: 1067].  No member is liable to court proceedings for anything said or any vote given in the Legislature/committee, nor is any person liable for publication of reports under House authority[cite: 1067].  In other respects, the powers, privileges, and immunities shall be those of that House and its members/committees immediately before the coming into force of Section 26 of the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1068].  These provisions also apply to persons who have the right to speak in or take part in proceedings (like Ministers/AG)[cite: 1068].

sub_sections.text: Freedom of speech in the Legislature[cite: 1067].
Immunity from legal proceedings for speech, vote, or authorized publication[cite: 1067].
Other privileges are defined by law or are those existing before the 44th Amendment (1978)[cite: 1068].
Applicable to persons other than members who have the right to speak (Ministers, AG)[cite: 1068].

amendments_notes: Clause (3) substituted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1068].

article_title: Salaries and allowances of members.
content: Members shall receive salaries and allowances determined by the State Legislature by law, or salaries and allowances applicable to members of the Legislative Assembly of the corresponding Province until then[cite: 1068].

article_title: Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills.
content: Bills (except Money Bills and Financial Bills under Art. 207) may originate in either House of a State Legislature having a Council[cite: 1068].  A Bill is passed only if agreed to by both Houses[cite: 1068].  A Bill pending does not lapse by reason of prorogation[cite: 1068].  A Bill pending in the Legislative Council (not passed by the Assembly) does not lapse on dissolution of the Assembly[cite: 1068].  A Bill pending in or passed by the Assembly and pending in the Council lapses on the dissolution of the Assembly[cite: 1068].

sub_sections.text: Bills may originate in either House of a bicameral Legislature (except Money Bills/Financial Bills)[cite: 1068].
Bill requires agreement by both Houses[cite: 1068].
Bill does not lapse on prorogation[cite: 1068].
Bill pending in the Legislative Council (not passed by Assembly) does not lapse on dissolution[cite: 1068].
Bill pending in or passed by the Legislative Assembly lapses on dissolution[cite: 1068].

article_title: Restriction on powers of Legislative Council as to Bills other than Money Bills.
content: If a Bill (not a Money Bill) passed by the Assembly is rejected by the Council, delayed for more than three months, or passed with amendments the Assembly disagrees with, the Assembly may pass it again in the same or a subsequent session and transmit it to the Council[cite: 1069].  If the Bill is passed again by the Assembly and the Council rejects it, delays it for more than one month, or passes it with amendments the Assembly disagrees with, the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses in the form passed by the Assembly the second time (with any agreed amendments)[cite: 1069].

sub_sections.text: Assembly may pass a Bill again if the Council delays it (3+ months), rejects it, or proposes unacceptable amendments[cite: 1069].
Bill is deemed passed if, after re-passage by Assembly, the Council again delays it (1+ month), rejects it, or proposes unacceptable amendments[cite: 1069].

article_title: Special procedure in respect of Money Bills.
content: A Money Bill shall not be introduced in a Legislative Council[cite: 1069].  After passing the Legislative Assembly, it is transmitted to the Council for recommendations, which must be returned within fourteen days[cite: 1069].  The Assembly may accept or reject all or any recommendations[cite: 1069].  If the Assembly accepts recommendations, the Bill is deemed passed with those amendments[cite: 1070].  If the Assembly rejects recommendations, the Bill is deemed passed in its original form[cite: 1070].  If the Council does not return the Bill within fourteen days, it is deemed passed by both Houses in the form passed by the Assembly[cite: 1070].

sub_sections.text: Money Bills cannot be introduced in the Legislative Council[cite: 1069].
Council must return Money Bill with recommendations within 14 days[cite: 1069].
Bill passed with accepted recommendations[cite: 1070].
Bill deemed passed if not returned within 14 days[cite: 1070].

article_title: Definition of 'Money Bills'.
content: A Bill is a Money Bill if it contains only provisions dealing with: imposition/regulation of taxes; regulation of borrowing/guarantees by the State; custody/withdrawal of the Consolidated Fund or Contingency Fund of the State; appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund; declaring expenditure charged on the Fund or increasing such amount; receipt/custody/issue of money for the Consolidated Fund/public account; or any incidental matter[cite: 1070].  It is **not** a Money Bill merely because it imposes fines, pecuniary penalties, fees for licences/services, or taxes by a local authority[cite: 1070].  The Speaker's decision on whether a Bill introduced in a bicameral Legislature is a Money Bill is final[cite: 1071].  The Speaker's certificate must be endorsed on the Bill when transmitted to the Council or presented to the Governor for assent[cite: 1071].

sub_sections.text: List of subjects (a-g) that define a Money Bill of a State (if dealing *only* with these matters)[cite: 1070].
Exclusions from the definition (fines, fees, local taxes)[cite: 1070].
Speaker's decision is final[cite: 1071].
Speaker's certificate is required on the Bill[cite: 1071].

article_title: Assent to Bills.
content: When a Bill is passed by the Legislature, it is presented to the Governor, who declares assent, withholds assent, or reserves the Bill for the consideration of the President[cite: 1071].  The Governor may return a Bill (if not a Money Bill) for reconsideration; if passed again, the Governor shall not withhold assent[cite: 1071].  The Governor shall not assent to, but must reserve for the President, any Bill that would endanger the position/powers of the High Court[cite: 1071].

sub_sections.text: Governor declares assent, withholds assent, or reserves for the President[cite: 1071].
Governor may return a non-Money Bill for reconsideration (must assent if passed again)[cite: 1071].
Governor must reserve Bills that endanger the High Court's position[cite: 1071].

article_title: Bills reserved for consideration.
content: When a Bill is reserved by a Governor for the President's consideration, the President declares assent or withholds assent[cite: 1071].  If the Bill is not a Money Bill, the President may direct the Governor to return it to the Legislature for reconsideration (within six months); if passed again, it is presented again to the President for consideration[cite: 1071, 1072].

sub_sections.text: President declares assent or withholds assent to reserved Bills[cite: 1071].
President may direct return of a non-Money Bill for reconsideration by the State Legislature (within six months)[cite: 1072].

article_title: Annual financial statement.
content: The Governor causes the 'annual financial statement' (budget) of estimated receipts and expenditure for the financial year to be laid before the House(s) of the State Legislature[cite: 1072].  Estimates show separately sums charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State (non-votable) and sums proposed to be made from it (votable)[cite: 1072].  Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund includes emoluments of the Governor/presiding officers, debt charges, expenditure on High Court Judges' salaries/allowances, and sums satisfying court judgments[cite: 1072].

sub_sections.text: Annual financial statement (budget) is laid before the House(s)[cite: 1072].
Estimates distinguish charged (non-votable) and other (votable) expenditure[cite: 1072].
List of expenditures charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State[cite: 1072].

article_title: Procedure in Legislature with respect to estimates.
content: Expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of a State is non-votable but may be discussed in the Legislature[cite: 1072, 1073].  Other expenditure is submitted as demands for grants to the Legislative Assembly, which the Assembly may assent to, refuse, or assent subject to reduction[cite: 1073].  No demand for a grant can be made except on the recommendation of the Governor[cite: 1073].

sub_sections.text: Charged expenditure is non-votable but discussable[cite: 1072, 1073].
Other expenditure is submitted as demands for grants to the Legislative Assembly for voting[cite: 1073].
Demands for grants require the Governor's recommendation[cite: 1073].

article_title: Appropriation Bills.
content: After grants are made, an Appropriation Bill is introduced to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of the State of the grants and the charged expenditure[cite: 1073].  No amendment can be proposed to vary the amount or destination of any grant or vary the charged expenditure (presiding officer's decision is final)[cite: 1073].  No money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund except under appropriation made by law passed under this article (subject to Arts. 205 and 206)[cite: 1073].

sub_sections.text: An Appropriation Bill is introduced for all grants and charged expenditure[cite: 1073].
No amendment to vary grants or charged expenditure is admissible (presiding officer's decision is final)[cite: 1073].
Money cannot be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund except by an Appropriation law[cite: 1073].

article_title: Supplementary, additional or excess grants.
content: The Governor shall cause another statement/demand for excess grants to be laid before the House(s) if the authorized amount is insufficient, if new/additional expenditure is needed, or if excess money has been spent[cite: 1073, 1074].  The procedure for the annual financial statement and appropriation (Arts. 202, 203, 204) applies to these grants/expenditures[cite: 1074].

sub_sections.text: Procedure for insufficient, additional, or excess grants/expenditure (Governor causes a statement/demand to be laid)[cite: 1073, 1074].
Articles 202, 203, and 204 procedures apply to supplementary, additional, and excess grants[cite: 1074].

article_title: Votes on account, votes of credit and exceptional grants.
content: The Legislative Assembly has power to make a vote on account (advance grant), a vote of credit (for unexpected demands), and an exceptional grant[cite: 1074].  The Legislature can authorize by law the withdrawal of moneys from the Consolidated Fund for these purposes[cite: 1074].  The procedures in Articles 203 and 204 apply to these grants and authorization laws[cite: 1074, 1075].

sub_sections.text: Legislative Assembly's power to make special grants: (a) Vote on account, (b) Vote of credit, (c) Exceptional grants[cite: 1074].
Articles 203 and 204 procedures apply to these special grants[cite: 1075].

article_title: Special provisions as to financial Bills.
content: A Bill or amendment making provision for the Money Bill matters (Art. 199(1)(a) to (f)) requires the Governor's recommendation to be introduced or moved, and such a Bill shall not be introduced in the Legislative Council[cite: 1075].  However, no recommendation is needed for an amendment reducing or abolishing any tax[cite: 1075].  A Bill is not deemed to contain the aforesaid matters merely because it relates to fines, fees, or local taxes[cite: 1075].  A Bill that, if enacted, would involve expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of a State shall not be passed by a House unless the Governor has recommended its consideration[cite: 1075].

sub_sections.text: Financial Bill (Category I) requires the Governor's recommendation for introduction/moving and cannot be introduced in the Legislative Council[cite: 1075].
No recommendation needed for tax reduction/abolition amendments[cite: 1075].
Financial Bill (Category II - involving expenditure) requires the Governor's recommendation for *consideration*[cite: 1075].

article_title: Rules of procedure.
content: A House of the State Legislature may make rules for regulating its procedure and business[cite: 1075].  Until rules are made, the existing rules of the corresponding Province's Legislature apply, subject to modifications by the Speaker/Chairman[cite: 1075].  In bicameral States, the Governor may make rules for communications between the two Houses after consulting the Speaker and Chairman[cite: 1075, 1076].

sub_sections.text: Each House may make its own rules[cite: 1075].
Interim rules: corresponding Province rules apply[cite: 1075].
Governor makes rules for inter-House communication (in bicameral States)[cite: 1076].

article_title: Regulation by law of procedure in the Legislature of the State in relation to financial business.
content: The State Legislature may regulate by law the procedure and conduct of business related to financial matters (e.g., timely completion of business)[cite: 1076].  If a law made under this article is inconsistent with a rule of procedure made by a House (under Art. 208), the law shall prevail[cite: 1076].

article_title: Language to be used in the Legislature.
content: Business in the Legislature shall be transacted in the official language(s) of the State or in Hindi or in English (subject to Art. 348)[cite: 1076].  The presiding officer may permit any member unable to express themselves in the aforesaid languages to address the House in their mother-tongue[cite: 1076].  The use of English was set to expire after fifteen years from commencement, unless the Legislature provided otherwise (with different expiry periods for certain North-Eastern States and Goa)[cite: 1076, 1077].

sub_sections.text: Language in Legislature is State official language(s), Hindi, or English[cite: 1076].
Presiding officer may permit use of mother-tongue[cite: 1076].

Original provision for the cessation of English after 15 years (with exceptions/extensions for certain States like Himachal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya, Tripura, Arunachal Pradesh, Goa, and Mizoram)[cite: 1076, 1077].

amendments_notes: Provisos added/amended multiple times extending the period for English use in certain States[cite: 1076, 1077].

article_title: Restriction on discussion in the Legislature.
content: No discussion shall take place in the Legislature of a State with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of his duties[cite: 1077].

article_title: Courts not to inquire into proceedings of the Legislature.
content: The validity of any proceedings in the Legislature of a State shall not be called in question in a court on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure[cite: 1077].  No officer or member of the Legislature who has powers for regulating procedure, conduct of business, or maintaining order shall be subject to court jurisdiction for the exercise of those powers[cite: 1077].

sub_sections.text: Courts cannot inquire into the validity of proceedings due to irregularity of procedure[cite: 1077].
Officers/members are protected from court jurisdiction regarding the exercise of their powers to regulate procedure or maintain order[cite: 1077].

article_title: Power of Governor to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Legislature.
content: If, except when the Legislative Assembly (or both Houses) is in session, the Governor is satisfied that immediate action is necessary, he may promulgate Ordinances[cite: 1077].  Governor cannot promulgate without instructions from the President if: a Bill containing the same provisions would have required President's previous sanction for introduction; or he would have had to reserve a Bill for President's consideration; or an Act containing the same provisions would have been invalid unless it received the President's assent after reservation[cite: 1077].  An Ordinance has the same force as an Act, but must be laid before the Legislature and ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly (or sooner if disapproved)[cite: 1078].  An Ordinance may be withdrawn at any time by the Governor[cite: 1078].  An Ordinance making a provision that would not be valid in an Act assented to by the Governor shall be void[cite: 1078].  An Ordinance promulgated with President's instructions concerning a Concurrent List matter (repugnant to an Act of Parliament) is deemed an Act assented to by the President[cite: 1078].

sub_sections.text: Governor's power to promulgate Ordinances when Legislature is in recess[cite: 1077].
Cases where President's instructions are required[cite: 1077].
Ordinance effect and duration (ceases after six weeks of reassembly or sooner if disapproved)[cite: 1078].
Ordinance is void if an Act would be invalid; saving provision for Concurrent List matters if President's instructions are obtained[cite: 1078].

amendments_notes: Clause (4), inserted by the 38th Amendment, 1975, was omitted by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1078].

article_title: High Courts for States.
content: There shall be a High Court for each State[cite: 1079].
amendments_notes: Brackets and figures were omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1079].

article_title: High Courts to be courts of record.
content: Every High Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself[cite: 1079].

article_title: Constitution of High Courts.
content: Every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other Judges as the President may from time to time deem it necessary to appoint[cite: 1079].
amendments_notes: A proviso regarding additional/acting Judges was omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1079].

article_title: Appointment and conditions of the office of a Judge of a High Court.
content: Judges are appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal, after consulting the Chief Justice of India, the Governor of the State, and (for other Judges) the Chief Justice of the High Court[cite: 1079].  Judges hold office until attaining the age of sixty-two years[cite: 1079].  A Judge may resign (to the President) or be removed by the President in the manner provided for a Supreme Court Judge (Art. 124(4))[cite: 1079, 1080].  Office is vacated if appointed as a Supreme Court Judge or transferred to another High Court[cite: 1080].  Qualifications include being a citizen of India and having held judicial office in India for at least ten years or being an advocate of a High Court (or successive Courts) for at least ten years[cite: 1080].  If a question arises as to the age of a Judge, the President's decision after consulting the CJI shall be final[cite: 1081].

sub_sections.text: Appointment procedure (President, consultation with CJI and Governor/HC CJ); tenure (until age 62)[cite: 1079].
A Judge may resign or be removed (as per Art. 124(4)); office is vacated if appointed to SC or transferred[cite: 1079, 1080].
Qualifications: 10 years judicial office or 10 years as HC advocate[cite: 1080].
Age question decided finally by the President after consulting the CJI[cite: 1081].

amendments_notes: Age limit changed from sixty to sixty-two by the 15th Amendment, 1963[cite: 1079].  Clause (2) contains multiple substitutions/omissions[cite: 1080].  Clause (3) inserted by the 15th Amendment, 1963[cite: 1081].  Reference to NJAC (99th Amendment) has been struck down by the Supreme Court[cite: 1079].

article_title: Application of certain provisions relating to Supreme Court to High Courts.
content: The provisions of clauses (4) and (5) of article 124 (removal procedure and Parliamentary regulation thereof) shall apply in relation to a High Court as they apply in relation to the Supreme Court[cite: 1081].

article_title: Oath or affirmation by Judges of High Courts.
content: Every person appointed to be a Judge of a High Court shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the Governor of the State (or his appointee) an oath or affirmation according to the form set out in the Third Schedule[cite: 1081].

article_title: Restriction on practice after being a permanent Judge.
content: No person who has held office as a permanent Judge of a High Court shall plead or act in any court or before any authority in India except the Supreme Court and the other High Courts[cite: 1081].
amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1081].

article_title: Salaries, etc., of Judges.
content: Judges of each High Court shall be paid salaries determined by Parliament by law, or as specified in the Second Schedule until then[cite: 1081, 1082].  Every Judge is entitled to allowances and rights in respect of leave and pension determined by Parliament or specified in the Second Schedule[cite: 1082].  Neither the allowances nor the rights regarding leave or pension shall be varied to a Judge's disadvantage after appointment[cite: 1082].

sub_sections.text: Salaries determined by Parliament/Second Schedule[cite: 1081, 1082].
Allowances and rights in respect of leave and pension determined by Parliament/Second Schedule (cannot be varied to disadvantage)[cite: 1082].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) substituted by the Constitution (Fifty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1986[cite: 1081].

article_title: Transfer of a Judge from one High Court to another.
content: The President may, after consultation with the Chief Justice of India, transfer a Judge from one High Court to any other High Court[cite: 1082].  A transferred Judge is entitled to receive, in addition to his salary, such compensatory allowance as Parliament determines by law (or as the President fixes by order until then)[cite: 1082].

sub_sections.text: President may transfer a Judge after consultation with the CJI[cite: 1082].
A transferred Judge is entitled to compensatory allowance[cite: 1082].

amendments_notes: Reference to the NJAC (99th Amendment) has been struck down by the Supreme Court[cite: 1082].  Clause (2) inserted by the Constitution (Fifteenth Amendment) Act, 1963[cite: 1082].

article_title: Appointment of acting Chief Justice.
content: When the office of Chief Justice of a High Court is vacant or the Chief Justice is unable to perform duties, the duties shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint[cite: 1082].

article_title: Appointment of additional and acting Judges.
content: The President may appoint duly qualified persons as additional Judges for a period not exceeding two years due to temporary increase in business or arrears of work[cite: 1083].  The President may appoint a duly qualified person as an acting Judge when a Judge (other than the CJ) is absent or temporarily acts as CJ[cite: 1083].  No person appointed as an additional or acting Judge shall hold office after attaining the age of sixty-two years[cite: 1083].

sub_sections.text: President may appoint additional Judges (max two years) due to work increase/arrears[cite: 1083].
President may appoint acting Judges when a Judge is absent or temporarily acting as CJ[cite: 1083].
Max age for additional/acting Judges is sixty-two years[cite: 1083].

amendments_notes: Article 224 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1083].  Age limit changed to 62 by the 15th Amendment, 1963[cite: 1083].  Reference to NJAC (99th Amendment) has been struck down by the Supreme Court[cite: 1083].

article_title: Appointment of retired Judges at sittings of High Courts.
content: The Chief Justice of a High Court may, with the President's previous consent, request any person who has held office as a Judge of that or any other High Court to sit and act as a Judge[cite: 1083].  Such a person is entitled to allowances determined by the President and possesses the jurisdiction, powers, and privileges of a Judge, but is not otherwise deemed to be one[cite: 1083, 1084].  They are not required to sit unless they consent[cite: 1084].

sub_sections.text: HC CJ may request retired Judges (with President's consent) to sit and act as Judges of the High Court[cite: 1083, 1084].
The Judge must consent to sit[cite: 1084].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fifteenth Amendment) Act, 1963[cite: 1083].  Reference to NJAC (99th Amendment) has been struck down by the Supreme Court[cite: 1083].

article_title: Jurisdiction of existing High Courts.
content: The jurisdiction, law administered, and respective powers of Judges of any existing High Court shall be the same as immediately before the commencement of this Constitution[cite: 1084].  Any restriction on the exercise of original jurisdiction by any High Court concerning revenue or its collection shall no longer apply[cite: 1084].

sub_sections.text: Existing jurisdiction and powers continue[cite: 1084].
Restrictions on original jurisdiction concerning revenue no longer apply[cite: 1084].

amendments_notes: Proviso omitted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and subsequently inserted by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1084].

article_title: Power of High Courts to issue certain writs.
content: Every High Court has the power, throughout its territorial jurisdiction, to issue directions, orders or writs (habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto, and certiorari) to any person, authority, or Government for the enforcement of any Fundamental Right (Part III) and for any other purpose[cite: 1084].  This power may also be exercised by a High Court if the cause of action, wholly or in part, arises within its territories, regardless of the seat of the Government or residence of the person[cite: 1085].  If an interim order is made without providing the affected party copies of the petition and a hearing opportunity, that party may apply for vacation of the order; the High Court must dispose of the application within two weeks, otherwise the interim order stands vacated[cite: 1085].  This power is not in derogation of the Supreme Court's power under Article 32[cite: 1085].

sub_sections.text: HC power to issue writs (e.g., habeas corpus, mandamus) for enforcement of FRs and for any other purpose[cite: 1084].
Jurisdiction extends to wherever the cause of action arises, wholly or in part[cite: 1085].
Provisions for vacating interim orders if passed ex parte (two-week disposal limit)[cite: 1085].
Power is not in derogation of SC power under Article 32[cite: 1085].

amendments_notes: Article 226 substituted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, then significantly modified and restored by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1084, 1085].

article_title: [Constitutional validity of Central laws not to be considered in proceedings under article 226.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1085].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, and omitted by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977[cite: 1085].

article_title: Power of superintendence over all courts by the High Court.
content: Every High Court shall have superintendence over all courts and tribunals throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction[cite: 1085].  The High Court may call for returns from such courts; make rules regulating their practice/proceedings and prescribe forms for accounts[cite: 1086].  The High Court may also settle tables of fees (rules and tables must be consistent with law and require the Governor's previous approval)[cite: 1086].  This power does not extend to any court or tribunal relating to the Armed Forces[cite: 1086].

sub_sections.text: HC has superintendence over all courts and tribunals within its jurisdiction[cite: 1085].
HC powers include calling for returns and making rules/prescribing forms[cite: 1086].
Excludes courts or tribunals related to the Armed Forces[cite: 1086].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and (5) were substituted/omitted and subsequently restored by the 42nd and 44th Amendments[cite: 1085, 1086].

article_title: Transfer of certain cases to High Court.
content: If a High Court is satisfied that a case pending in a subordinate court involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution, the High Court shall withdraw the case and may either dispose of the case itself, or determine the question of law and return the case to the subordinate court for disposal in conformity with the High Court's judgment[cite: 1086, 1087].

sub_sections.text: HC must withdraw cases involving a substantial constitutional interpretation question[cite: 1086].
HC may dispose of the case itself or decide the question of law and remit the case to the subordinate court[cite: 1087].

amendments_notes: Article amended by the 42nd and 43rd Amendments[cite: 1086, 1087].

article_title: [Special provisions as to disposal of questions relating to constitutional validity of State laws.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1087].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, and omitted by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977[cite: 1087].

article_title: Officers and servants and the expenses of High Courts.
content: Appointments of HC officers and servants are made by the Chief Justice (or his appointee), though the Governor may require consultation with the State Public Service Commission in certain cases[cite: 1087].  Conditions of service are prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice (or his appointee), subject to State Legislature law, and require the Governor's approval if they relate to salaries, allowances, leave, or pensions[cite: 1087].  The administrative expenses of a High Court (salaries, allowances, pensions, etc.) are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of the State[cite: 1087].

sub_sections.text: Appointments by HC CJ (subject to Governor's rule requiring State PSC consultation)[cite: 1087].
Conditions of service prescribed by HC CJ's rules (subject to State law and Governor's approval for financial matters)[cite: 1087].
Administrative expenses are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State[cite: 1087].

article_title: Extension of jurisdiction of High Courts to Union territories.
content: Parliament may by law extend the jurisdiction of a High Court to, or exclude the jurisdiction of a High Court from, any Union territory[cite: 1087].  Where the High Court of a State exercises jurisdiction in relation to a Union territory, the State Legislature cannot increase, restrict, or abolish that jurisdiction, and references to the Governor in Article 227 (superintendence) shall be construed as a reference to the President[cite: 1087, 1088].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to extend/exclude HC jurisdiction over Union territories[cite: 1087].
Provisions for High Courts exercising jurisdiction over Union territories (limits on State Legislature power, substitution of 'Governor' with 'President')[cite: 1088].

amendments_notes: Article 230 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1087].

article_title: Establishment of a common High Court for two or more States.
content: Parliament may by law establish a common High Court for two or more States or for two or more States and a Union territory[cite: 1088].  In relation to such a High Court, references to the Governor in Article 227 (subordinate courts) shall be construed as a reference to the Governor of the State where the subordinate courts are located[cite: 1088].  References to the State in Articles 219 (oath) and 229 (staff/expenses) shall be construed as a reference to the State where the High Court has its principal seat[cite: 1088].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to establish a common High Court for two or more States/UTs[cite: 1088].
Provisions relating to the application of other Articles to a common High Court[cite: 1088].

amendments_notes: Article 231 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1088].  Sub-clause (a) omitted by the 99th Amendment, 2014 (struck down by SC)[cite: 1088].

article_title: Appointment of district judges.
content: Appointments, posting, and promotion of district judges shall be made by the Governor of the State in consultation with the High Court[cite: 1089].  A person not already in service of the Union or State is only eligible if he has been an advocate or pleader for not less than seven years and is recommended by the High Court[cite: 1089].

sub_sections.text: Appointment, posting, and promotion by Governor in consultation with the High Court[cite: 1089].
Eligibility criteria for non-service candidates (seven years' experience as advocate/pleader and HC recommendation)[cite: 1089].

article_title: Validation of appointments of, and judgments, etc., delivered by, certain district judges.
content: Notwithstanding any judgment or decree, no appointment, posting, promotion, or transfer of a person (already in judicial service or with seven years' experience as advocate/pleader) as a district judge made before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966, shall be deemed illegal or void solely because it was not made in accordance with Article 233 or 235[cite: 1089].  No jurisdiction exercised or judgment passed by such a person shall be deemed illegal or invalid for the same reason[cite: 1089].

sub_sections.text: Validates irregular appointments, postings, promotions, and transfers of district judges made before the 20th Amendment, 1966[cite: 1089].
Validates the judicial acts and proceedings of such irregularly appointed persons[cite: 1089].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966[cite: 1089].

article_title: Recruitment of persons other than district judges to the judicial service.
content: Appointments of persons other than district judges to the judicial service of a State shall be made by the Governor in accordance with rules made by him after consultation with the State Public Service Commission and the High Court[cite: 1089].

article_title: Control over subordinate courts.
content: The control over district courts and courts subordinate thereto, including the posting and promotion of, and the grant of leave to, persons in the judicial service (holding posts inferior to that of district judge), shall be vested in the High Court[cite: 1090].  This control does not take away any person's right of appeal or authorize the High Court to deal with them otherwise than in accordance with their conditions of service prescribed under law[cite: 1090].

article_title: Interpretation.
content: The expression 'district judge' includes judge of a city civil court, additional district judge, joint district judge, assistant district judge, chief judge of a small cause court, chief presidency magistrate, additional chief presidency magistrate, sessions judge, additional sessions judge and assistant sessions Judge[cite: 1090].  The expression 'judicial service' means a service consisting exclusively of persons intended to fill the post of district judge and other civil judicial posts inferior to the post of district judge[cite: 1090].

sub_sections.text: Definition of 'district judge'[cite: 1090].
Definition of 'judicial service'[cite: 1090].

article_title: Application of the provisions of this Chapter to certain class or classes of magistrates.
content: The Governor may by public notification direct that the provisions of this Chapter and any rules made thereunder shall apply in relation to any class or classes of magistrates in the State, with such exceptions and modifications as he may specify[cite: 1090].

part_title: THE STATES IN PART B OF THE FIRST SCHEDULE
article_title: [Omitted.]
content: This Part, relating to the States in Part B of the First Schedule, was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, s. 29 and Sch. (w.e.f. 1-11-1956).

article_title: Administration of Union territories.
content: Save as otherwise provided by Parliament by law, every Union territory shall be administered by the President acting, to such extent as he thinks fit, through an administrator to be appointed by him with such designation as he may specify. Notwithstanding anything contained in Part VI, the President may appoint the Governor of a State as the administrator of an adjoining Union territory, and where a Governor is so appointed, he shall exercise his functions as such administrator independently of his Council of Ministers.

sub_sections.text: Union territories are administered by the President acting through an appointed administrator.
The President may appoint a State Governor as administrator of an adjoining Union territory, exercising functions independently of his Council of Ministers.

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: Creation of local Legislatures or Council of Ministers or both for certain Union territories.
content: Parliament may by law create for the Union territory of Puducherry a body to function as a Legislature, or a Council of Ministers, or both, with such constitution, powers and functions, as may be specified in the law. Any such law shall not be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.

sub_sections.text: Parliament may by law create a Legislature, Council of Ministers, or both for the Union territory of Puducherry.
Such a law is not considered a Constitutional amendment under Article 368.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fourteenth Amendment) Act, 1962. Amended regarding the territories listed by subsequent Acts. Made applicable to the Union Territory of Jammu and Kashmir by Act 34 of 2019.

article_title: Special provisions with respect to Delhi.
content: The Union territory of Delhi shall be called the National Capital Territory of Delhi (NCT), and its administrator shall be designated as the Lieutenant Governor[cite: 1093]. There shall be a Legislative Assembly for the NCT, with seats filled by direct election from territorial constituencies[cite: 1093]. The number of seats, reservation for Scheduled Castes/Women, and other matters relating to the Legislative Assembly shall be regulated by Parliament's law[cite: 1093]. The Legislative Assembly has power to make laws for the NCT with respect to matters in the State List or Concurrent List, except for Entries 1, 2, and 18 of the State List (Public Order, Police, and Land)[cite: 1094]. Parliament retains the power to make laws on any matter for the NCT[cite: 1094]. If a law made by the Legislative Assembly is repugnant to a law made by Parliament, the Parliament's law shall prevail[cite: 1094]. There shall be a Council of Ministers (COM), not exceeding ten percent of the Assembly members, with the Chief Minister at the head, to aid and advise the Lieutenant Governor (LG)[cite: 1094]. In case of difference of opinion between the LG and Ministers, the LG shall refer the matter to the President for a decision and may take immediate action pending that decision[cite: 1094]. The CM and Ministers are appointed by the President[cite: 1095]. The COM is collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly[cite: 1095].

sub_sections.text: Delhi is renamed National Capital Territory (NCT) and the administrator is the Lieutenant Governor (LG)[cite: 1093].
Establishes a Legislative Assembly and provides for seat regulation, including reservation for Scheduled Castes and women[cite: 1093].
Legislative power over State List/Concurrent List matters, excluding Public Order, Police, and Land[cite: 1094].
Repugnancy Clause: Parliament's law prevails over the Legislative Assembly's law[cite: 1094].
Council of Ministers (max 10%) to aid/advise the LG; LG refers differences to the President and may take immediate action pending decision[cite: 1094].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Sixty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1991[cite: 1093]. Clauses (2)(ba), (bb), (bc) inserted by the Constitution (One-hundred and Sixth Amendment) Act, 2023[cite: 1093].

article_title: Provision in case of failure of constitutional machinery.
content: If the President, based on a report from the Lieutenant Governor (LG) or otherwise, is satisfied that a situation has arisen where the administration of the NCT cannot be carried on in accordance with Article 239AA or that it is necessary/expedient to do so, the President may suspend the operation of any provision of Article 239AA or any law made pursuant to it and make necessary incidental/consequential provisions[cite: 1096].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Sixty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1991[cite: 1095].

article_title: Power of administrator to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Legislature.
content: If the Legislature of the Union territory of Puducherry is in recess and the administrator is satisfied that immediate action is necessary, he may promulgate Ordinances[cite: 1096]. No such Ordinance shall be promulgated except after obtaining instructions from the President[cite: 1096]. An Ordinance must be laid before the Legislature and ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly (or sooner if disapproved)[cite: 1097]. An Ordinance may be withdrawn by the administrator after obtaining instructions from the President[cite: 1097]. An Ordinance making a provision that the Legislature would not be validly enacted shall be void[cite: 1097].

sub_sections.text: Administrator's power to promulgate Ordinances during recess (requires President's instructions)[cite: 1096].
Ordinance effect and duration (ceases six weeks after reassembly)[cite: 1097].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-seventh Amendment) Act, 1971[cite: 1096]. Clause (4), inserted by the 38th Amendment, was omitted by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1098].

article_title: Power of President to make regulations for certain Union territories.
content: The President may make regulations for the peace, progress and good government of the Union territories of: the Andaman and Nicobar Islands; Lakshadweep; Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu; and Puducherry[cite: 1097]. For Puducherry, the President shall not make any regulation once a Legislative body is created and functioning (Proviso)[cite: 1097]. Any regulation so made may repeal or amend any Act made by Parliament or any other law applicable to the Union territory and shall have the same force as an Act of Parliament[cite: 1098].

sub_sections.text: President's power to make regulations for certain Union territories (listed)[cite: 1097].
Limits the President's power when a Legislature is functioning in Puducherry, and restores the power during dissolution/suspension[cite: 1097, 1098].
Regulations can repeal/amend Acts of Parliament and have the same force[cite: 1098].

amendments_notes: Article 240 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1097]. Entries have been substituted/omitted for various UTs due to their reorganization or attainment of statehood[cite: 1097, 1098].

article_title: High Courts for Union territories.
content: Parliament may by law constitute a High Court for a Union territory or declare any court in such territory to be a High Court[cite: 1098]. Chapter V of Part VI (relating to High Courts in States) shall apply to these High Courts, subject to modifications Parliament may provide[cite: 1098]. Existing High Courts exercising jurisdiction over a Union territory immediately before the Seventh Amendment, 1956, shall continue to exercise such jurisdiction[cite: 1098]. Parliament's power to extend or exclude the jurisdiction of a High Court of a State to or from any Union territory is not derogated[cite: 1098].

sub_sections.text: Parliament may constitute a High Court for a Union territory or declare an existing court as a High Court[cite: 1098].
Existing High Courts maintaining jurisdiction over UTs continue to do so[cite: 1098].

amendments_notes: Clauses (3) and (4) substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1098].

article_title: [Coorg.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1098].

article_title: Definitions.
content: Defines key terms for this Part: 'district' is a district in a State; 'Gram Sabha' is a body of persons registered in the electoral rolls relating to a village; 'intermediate level' is a level between the village and district levels specified by the Governor; 'Panchayat' is an institution of self-government for rural areas constituted under Article 243B; 'Panchayat area' is the territorial area of a Panchayat; 'Population' is the population as ascertained at the last preceding census with relevant figures published; and 'village' is a village or group of villages specified by the Governor.

sub_sections.text: Definition of 'district'.
Definition of 'Gram Sabha'.
Definition of 'intermediate level'.
Definition of 'Panchayat'.
Definition of 'Panchayat area'.
Definition of 'Population'.
Definition of 'village'.

amendments_notes: Part IX, including Article 243, was inserted by the Constitution (Seventy-third Amendment) Act, 1992.

article_title: Gram Sabha.
content: A Gram Sabha may exercise such powers and perform such functions at the village level as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide.

article_title: Constitution of Panchayats.
content: Panchayats shall be constituted in every State at the village, intermediate and district levels. However, Panchayats at the intermediate level may not be constituted in a State having a population not exceeding twenty lakhs.

sub_sections.text: Panchayats must be constituted at village, intermediate, and district levels.
Intermediate level Panchayats are optional for States with a population not exceeding twenty lakhs.

article_title: Composition of Panchayats.
content: The State Legislature may make provisions with respect to the composition of Panchayats, ensuring the ratio between population and elected seats is generally uniform throughout the State. All seats are filled by direct election from territorial constituencies (wards), with a generally uniform population/seat ratio within the Panchayat area. The State Legislature may provide for the representation of Chairpersons of Panchayats (at a lower level in a higher level Panchayat), and members of Parliament/State Legislature representing constituencies that wholly or partly comprise the Panchayat area. All members, whether elected or non-elected, have the right to vote in meetings. The Chairperson of a village-level Panchayat is elected as the Legislature provides, and the Chairperson of an intermediate/district-level Panchayat is elected by and from amongst the elected members thereof.

sub_sections.text: State Legislature provides for composition, ensuring a uniform ratio of population to elected seats (Proviso).
All seats filled by direct election from territorial constituencies (wards).
Provisions for representation of Chairpersons of lower levels in higher levels, and representation of MPs/MLAs/MLCs.
All members (elected/non-elected) have the right to vote in meetings.
Chairpersons election method (village level: as Legislature provides; intermediate/district level: elected by and from elected members).

article_title: Reservation of seats.
content: Seats are reserved for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) in every Panchayat based on the proportion of their population to the total population of the area (allotted by rotation). Not less than one-third of the reserved seats for SCs and STs must be reserved for women of those groups. Not less than one-third of the total seats for direct election must be reserved for women (including SC/ST women), also by rotation. The offices of Chairpersons are reserved for SCs, STs, and women as the Legislature provides (proportional to population; not less than one-third for women, by rotation). This mandatory reservation (excluding women's reservation of offices) ceases on the expiration of the period specified in Article 334. The State Legislature may make provision for reservation of seats/offices for backward classes.

sub_sections.text: Reservation for SCs and STs based on population ratio (by rotation).
Not less than one-third of reserved seats for SC/ST reserved for women of those groups.
Not less than one-third of total seats for direct election reserved for women (including SC/ST women, by rotation).
Reservation of offices of Chairpersons for SCs, STs, and women (by law/proportion/rotation).
Mandatory reservation ceases on expiration of the period specified in Article 334.
State Legislature may provide for reservation for backward classes.

article_title: Duration of Panchayats, etc.
content: Every Panchayat shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting, unless sooner dissolved. An amendment to law cannot dissolve an existing Panchayat before the expiration of its five-year duration. An election to constitute a Panchayat must be completed before the expiration of its duration or before the expiration of six months from the date of its dissolution (unless the remainder of the period is less than six months). A Panchayat constituted upon dissolution shall continue only for the remainder of the period.

sub_sections.text: Duration is five years (unless sooner dissolved).
Law amendments cannot cause premature dissolution of an existing Panchayat.
Mandatory election completion: (a) before term expiry, or (b) within six months of dissolution (unless remainder is less than six months).
Panchayat constituted after dissolution serves only the remainder of the term.

article_title: Disqualifications for membership.
content: A person is disqualified for membership if disqualified by or under any law for elections to the State Legislature (provided the minimum age is twenty-one years, not twenty-five), or if disqualified by or under any law made by the State Legislature. Any question regarding a member's disqualification shall be referred for the decision of an authority and in a manner provided for by the State Legislature.

sub_sections.text: Disqualification under State Legislature election laws (minimum age 21, not 25).
Disqualification by or under law made by the State Legislature.
Question of disqualification referred to an authority prescribed by the State Legislature.

article_title: Powers, authority and responsibilities of Panchayats.
content: The State Legislature may, by law, endow Panchayats with powers and authority to enable them to function as institutions of self-government. Such law may contain provisions for the devolution of powers and responsibilities regarding: the preparation of plans for economic development and social justice; and the implementation of schemes for economic development and social justice, including those related to matters listed in the Eleventh Schedule.

sub_sections.text: State Legislature may endow powers for Panchayats to function as institutions of self-government, including devolution of powers and responsibilities for:
Preparation of plans for economic development and social justice.
Implementation of schemes for economic development and social justice (including those listed in the Eleventh Schedule).

article_title: Powers to impose taxes by, and Funds of, the Panchayats.
content: The State Legislature may, by law: authorize a Panchayat to levy, collect and appropriate taxes, duties, tolls and fees; assign State-levied taxes, duties, tolls and fees to a Panchayat; provide for grants-in-aid to the Panchayats from the Consolidated Fund of the State; and provide for the constitution of Funds for crediting and withdrawing all moneys received by or on behalf of the Panchayats.

sub_sections.text: Authorize Panchayats to levy and collect taxes/duties/tolls/fees.
Assign State-levied taxes/duties/tolls/fees to Panchayats.
Provide for grants-in-aid from the Consolidated Fund of the State.
Provide for the constitution of Panchayat Funds.

article_title: Constitution of Finance Commission to review financial position.
content: The Governor of a State shall, within one year from the commencement of the 73rd Amendment Act (1992) and every fifth year thereafter, constitute a Finance Commission (FC) to review the financial position of the Panchayats and make recommendations to the Governor regarding: the distribution of net proceeds of State taxes between the State and Panchayats (and allocation between levels of Panchayats); the determination of taxes, duties, tolls and fees that may be assigned to Panchayats; and grants-in-aid from the State's Consolidated Fund. The State Legislature may provide for the FC's composition and member qualifications. The FC determines its own procedure. The Governor causes every FC recommendation and an explanatory memorandum of action taken to be laid before the State Legislature.

sub_sections.text: Governor constitutes a Finance Commission every five years.
FC recommendations on tax distribution, assignment of taxes, grants-in-aid, measures to improve finances, and other sound finance matters.
Governor causes recommendations and action taken memorandum to be laid before the State Legislature.

article_title: Audit of accounts of Panchayats.
content: The State Legislature may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the Panchayats and the auditing of such accounts.

article_title: Elections to the Panchayats.
content: The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to the Panchayats shall be vested in a State Election Commission (SEC) consisting of a State Election Commissioner (SEC) appointed by the Governor. The conditions of service and tenure of office of the SEC are determined by the Governor by rule, subject to law by the State Legislature. The SEC shall not be removed except like a High Court Judge, and his conditions of service cannot be varied to his disadvantage. The Governor must make necessary staff available to the SEC upon request. The State Legislature may make provision with respect to all matters relating to elections to the Panchayats.

sub_sections.text: Elections vested in a State Election Commission (SEC), whose Commissioner is appointed by the Governor.
SEC removal procedure (like a High Court Judge) and protection against adverse variation of service conditions.
State Legislature may make laws for election matters.

article_title: Application to Union territories.
content: The provisions of this Part apply to Union territories (UTs), with references to the Governor of a State construed as references to the Administrator of the UT, and references to the State Legislature construed as references to the Legislative Assembly (if one exists). The President may direct that this Part applies to any UT or part thereof subject to specified exceptions and modifications.

sub_sections.text: Part IX applies to Union territories (with necessary construction changes).
President may apply the Part with exceptions/modifications.

article_title: Part not to apply to certain areas.
content: This Part shall not apply to the Scheduled Areas and tribal areas referred to in Article 244. It also shall not apply to the States of Nagaland, Meghalaya and Mizoram, nor to the hill areas in Manipur for which District Councils exist. Article 243D (reservation of seats for SCs) shall not apply to the State of Arunachal Pradesh. Notwithstanding this, the Legislature of the excluded States may extend this Part by resolution (special majority), and Parliament may extend the provisions of this Part to the Scheduled/tribal areas subject to exceptions/modifications, without this being deemed an amendment under Article 368.

sub_sections.text: Excludes Scheduled Areas and tribal areas (Art. 244).
