Excludes Nagaland, Meghalaya, Mizoram, and certain hill areas of Manipur.
Article 243D (SC reservation) does not apply to Arunachal Pradesh.
Legislature of excluded States can extend the Part by a special majority resolution.
Parliament can extend the Part to Scheduled/Tribal areas with modifications (not considered a 368 amendment).

amendments_notes: Clause (3A) inserted by the Constitution (Eighty-third Amendment) Act, 2000.

article_title: Continuance of existing laws and Panchayats.
content: Existing laws relating to Panchayats inconsistent with this Part continue for one year from the commencement of the 73rd Amendment Act, 1992, or until amended/repealed, whichever is earlier. Existing Panchayats continue until the expiration of their duration, unless sooner dissolved by a resolution of the State Legislature.

sub_sections.text: Inconsistent existing laws continue for one year or until repealed.
Existing Panchayats continue until the expiration of their term or sooner dissolution by Legislature resolution.

article_title: Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters.
content: The validity of any law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats cannot be called in question in any court. No election to any Panchayat shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to an authority and in a manner provided for by or under a law made by the State Legislature.

sub_sections.text: Courts cannot question the validity of laws relating to delimitation or allotment of seats.
Elections can only be questioned by an election petition to the prescribed authority.

article_title: Definitions.
content: Defines key terms for this Part: 'authorised person' is a person referred to in article 243ZQ; 'board' means the board of directors or governing body of a co-operative society; 'co-operative society' means a society registered under any law relating to co-operative societies; 'multi-State co-operative society' means a society with objects not confined to one State; 'office bearer' means an elected person like a President, Vice-President, Chairperson, Secretary, or Treasurer; 'Registrar' means the Central Registrar (for multi-State) or the Registrar appointed by the State Government; 'State Act' means any law made by the Legislature of a State; and 'State level co-operative society' means a co-operative society with area of operation extending to the whole of a State.

sub_sections.text: Definition of 'board'[cite: 1117].
Definition of 'co-operative society'[cite: 1117].
Definition of 'multi-State co-operative society'[cite: 1117].
Definition of 'Registrar' (Central/State)[cite: 1117].

amendments_notes: Part IXB, including Article 243ZH, was inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-seventh Amendment) Act, 2011, s.  4 (w.e.f. 15-2-2012)[cite: 1117].

article_title: Incorporation of co-operative societies.
content: Subject to the provisions of this Part, the Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the incorporation, regulation and winding up of co-operative societies based on the principles of voluntary formation, democratic member-control, member-economic participation and autonomous functioning[cite: 1117].

article_title: Number and term of members of board and its office bearers.
content: The board shall consist of such number of directors as the State Legislature may provide by law, provided the maximum number shall not exceed twenty-one[cite: 1118].  The State Legislature shall provide for the reservation of one seat for the Scheduled Castes or Scheduled Tribes and two seats for women on the board of every co-operative society consisting of individuals as members[cite: 1118].  The term of office for elected members and office bearers is five years from the date of election, with the term of office bearers being conterminous with the board[cite: 1118].  The board may fill a casual vacancy by nomination from the same class, if the remainder of the term is less than half of its original term[cite: 1118].  The Legislature shall make provisions for co-option of members (max two, non-voting) having experience in banking, management, finance, or specialisation[cite: 1118].  Functional directors are members of the board and are excluded for the purpose of counting the maximum number of directors[cite: 1118].

sub_sections.text: Board size determined by State law (max 21 directors)[cite: 1118].
Reservation of one SC/ST seat and two women seats[cite: 1118].
Term of office is five years[cite: 1118].
Provision for co-option of expert members (max two, non-voting)[cite: 1118].

article_title: Election of members of board.
content: The election of a board must be conducted before the expiry of the term to ensure the newly elected members assume office immediately[cite: 1119].  The superintendence, direction and control of elections vest in an authority or body provided by the State Legislature by law[cite: 1119].  The State Legislature may provide for the procedure and guidelines for the conduct of such elections[cite: 1119].

sub_sections.text: Mandatory election before term expiry[cite: 1119].
Elections vested in an authority/body specified by State law[cite: 1119].

article_title: Supersession and suspension of board and interim management.
content: No board shall be superseded or kept under suspension for a period exceeding six months[cite: 1119].  Supersession is permitted in cases of persistent default, negligence, acts prejudicial to the society's interest, stalemate in functions, or failure to conduct elections[cite: 1119, 1120].  Supersession is prohibited where there is no Government shareholding, loan, financial assistance, or guarantee[cite: 1120].  For co-operative banks (other than multi-State), the maximum period of suspension is one year[cite: 1120].  Upon supersession, the appointed administrator must arrange elections within the specified period[cite: 1120].

sub_sections.text: Maximum supersession/suspension period is six months (one year for co-operative banks)[cite: 1119, 1120].
Supersession prohibited if there is no Government financial support[cite: 1120].
Administrator must hold elections within the period specified[cite: 1120].

article_title: Audit of accounts of co-operative societies.
content: The State Legislature may make provisions for the maintenance and auditing of accounts at least once every financial year[cite: 1120].  The Legislature shall lay down minimum qualifications and experience for auditors/auditing firms[cite: 1120].  Auditing is done by an auditor/firm appointed by the general body from a panel approved by the State Government[cite: 1120].  Accounts must be audited within six months of the close of the financial year[cite: 1120].  The audit report of an apex co-operative society must be laid before the State Legislature[cite: 1120].

sub_sections.text: Mandatory audit at least once per financial year[cite: 1120].
Legislature lays down minimum qualifications for auditors[cite: 1120].
Audit must be completed within six months of the close of the financial year[cite: 1120].
Audit report of apex society must be laid before the State Legislature[cite: 1120].

article_title: Convening of general body meetings.
content: The State Legislature may make provisions that the annual general body meeting of every co-operative society shall be convened within a period of six months of the close of the financial year to transact prescribed business[cite: 1120].

article_title: Right of a member to get information.
content: The State Legislature may provide for access by every member to the books, information, and accounts of the co-operative society relating to their business[cite: 1121].  The Legislature may make provisions to ensure member participation (minimum meeting attendance, utilizing minimum services)[cite: 1121].  The Legislature may also provide for co-operative education and training for its members[cite: 1121].

sub_sections.text: Legislature may provide for member's access to information[cite: 1121].
Legislature may provide for member participation requirements[cite: 1121].

article_title: Returns.
content: Every co-operative society must file returns to the authority designated by the State Government within six months of the close of every financial year, including: annual activity report; audited statement of accounts; plan for surplus disposal; list of amendments to bye-laws; declaration of general body meeting date/elections due; and any other information required by the Registrar[cite: 1121].

sub_sections.text: Mandatory filing of returns within six months, listing specific documents and information[cite: 1121].

article_title: Offences and penalties.
content: The State Legislature may make provisions for offenses relating to co-operative societies and penalties for them[cite: 1122].  Specific acts that must be included as offenses are: wilfully making a false return or furnishing false information; wilfully disobeying any summons or order; an employer failing to pay deducted amounts to the society within fourteen days; an officer/custodian wilfully failing to hand over custody of records to an authorised person; and adopting any corrupt practice in elections[cite: 1122].

sub_sections.text: State Legislature may make provisions for offenses and penalties[cite: 1122].
List of specific acts/omissions that must be included as offenses[cite: 1122].

article_title: Application to multi-State co-operative societies.
content: The provisions of this Part apply to multi-State co-operative societies, with references to 'Legislature of a State,' 'State Act,' or 'State Government' construed as references to 'Parliament,' 'Central Act,' or 'the Central Government,' respectively[cite: 1122].

article_title: Application to Union territories.
content: The provisions of this Part apply to Union territories (UTs)[cite: 1122].  In UTs without a Legislative Assembly, references to the State Legislature are references to the Administrator[cite: 1122].  In UTs with a Legislative Assembly, the reference is to that Assembly[cite: 1122].  The President may direct that the provisions of this Part shall not apply to any UT or part thereof[cite: 1122].

article_title: Continuance of existing laws.
content: Existing laws relating to co-operative societies inconsistent with this Part shall continue in force until amended or repealed, or until the expiration of one year from the commencement of the 97th Amendment Act, 2011, whichever is less[cite: 1122].

article_title: Administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas.
content: The provisions of the Fifth Schedule shall apply to the administration and control of the Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in any State other than the States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram[cite: 1123].  The provisions of the Sixth Schedule shall apply to the administration of the tribal areas in the States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram[cite: 1123].

sub_sections.text: Fifth Schedule applies to Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in States, excluding Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram[cite: 1123].
Sixth Schedule applies to the administration of tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram[cite: 1123].

amendments_notes: States listed in clause (1) and (2) substituted/amended multiple times by Acts, including the North-Eastern Areas (Reorganisation) Act, 1971, and the State of Mizoram Act, 1986[cite: 1123].

article_title: Formation of an autonomous State comprising certain tribal areas in Assam and creation of local Legislature or Council of Ministers or both therefor.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may, by law, form within the State of Assam an autonomous State comprising all or any of the tribal areas specified in Part I of the table appended to paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule and create therefor a body to function as a Legislature, or a Council of Ministers, or both[cite: 1123, 1124].  Such a law may specify legislative matters (State List/Concurrent List) for the autonomous State, define its executive power, provide for the assignment of Assam taxes to it, and contain incidental provisions[cite: 1124].  An amendment to this law regarding legislative or executive matters requires a two-thirds majority of members present and voting in each House of Parliament[cite: 1124].  Any such law is not deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368[cite: 1124].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to form an autonomous State within Assam (from tribal areas of the Sixth Schedule, Part I) and create a Legislature and/or Council of Ministers[cite: 1123, 1124].
Details of the law's provisions, including legislative powers, executive extent, and tax assignment[cite: 1124].
Special majority (two-thirds present and voting) required in Parliament for amending legislative or executive powers of the autonomous State[cite: 1124].
The law is not considered a Constitutional amendment under Article 368[cite: 1124].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-second Amendment) Act, 1969[cite: 1123].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Extent of laws made by Parliament and by the Legislatures of States.
content: Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India, and the Legislature of a State may make laws for the whole or any part of the State. No law made by Parliament shall be deemed to be invalid on the ground that it would have extra-territorial operation.

sub_sections.text: Parliament can make laws for the whole or any part of India;  State Legislature can make laws for the whole or any part of the State[cite: 1125].
Parliamentary law is not invalid on the ground of extra-territorial operation[cite: 1125].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Subject-matter of laws made by Parliament and by the Legislatures of States.
content: Notwithstanding anything in clauses (2) and (3), Parliament has exclusive power to make laws with respect to any matters in List I (Union List) in the Seventh Schedule[cite: 1125].  Notwithstanding anything in clause (3), Parliament and the Legislature of any State also have power to make laws with respect to any matters in List III (Concurrent List) in the Seventh Schedule[cite: 1125].  Subject to clauses (1) and (2), the Legislature of any State has exclusive power to make laws with respect to any matters in List II (State List) in the Seventh Schedule[cite: 1125].  Parliament has power to make laws for any part of the territory of India not included in a State, even if the matter is enumerated in the State List[cite: 1125].

sub_sections.text: Parliament has exclusive power over List I (Union List) matters[cite: 1125].
Parliament and State Legislatures have concurrent power over List III (Concurrent List) matters[cite: 1125].
State Legislature has exclusive power over List II (State List) matters[cite: 1125].
Parliament can legislate for any territory not included in a State (even on State List matters)[cite: 1125].

amendments_notes: Omission of references to 'Part A or Part B of the First Schedule' by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1125].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Special provision with respect to goods and services tax.
content: Notwithstanding anything contained in articles 246 and 254, Parliament and the Legislature of every State have power to make laws with respect to goods and services tax imposed by the Union or by such State[cite: 1125].  Parliament has exclusive power to make laws with respect to goods and services tax where the supply takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce[cite: 1126].  This provision shall, in respect of goods and services tax referred to in clause (5) of article 279A, take effect from the date recommended by the Goods and Services Tax Council[cite: 1126].

sub_sections.text: Parliament and every State Legislature have power to legislate with respect to GST[cite: 1125].
Parliament has exclusive power over GST in the course of inter-State trade or commerce[cite: 1126].
Application of this article to GST under Article 279A(5) is determined by the Goods and Services Tax Council recommendation[cite: 1126].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1125].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of Parliament to provide for the establishment of certain additional courts.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of any additional courts for the better administration of laws made by Parliament or of any existing laws with respect to a matter enumerated in the Union List[cite: 1126].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Residuary powers of legislation.
content: Subject to article 246A, Parliament has exclusive power to make any law with respect to any matter not enumerated in the Concurrent List or State List[cite: 1126].  This power includes the power of making any law imposing a tax not mentioned in either of those Lists[cite: 1126].

sub_sections.text: Parliament has exclusive residuary power[cite: 1126].
Residuary power includes the power to impose unenumerated taxes[cite: 1126].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) amended to be subject to Article 246A by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1126].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of Parliament to legislate with respect to a matter in the State List in the national interest.
content: If the Council of States declares by a two-thirds majority resolution that it is necessary or expedient in the national interest for Parliament to legislate with respect to Goods and Services Tax (Art. 246A) or any State List matter specified in the resolution, Parliament may make laws on that matter[cite: 1126].  Such a resolution remains in force for a maximum of one year but can be renewed for further one-year periods by subsequent resolutions[cite: 1126].  A law made by Parliament under this power ceases to have effect after six months once the resolution ceases to be in force, except regarding actions taken before that period[cite: 1126].

sub_sections.text: Parliament may legislate on State List matters if the Council of States passes a two-thirds majority resolution declaring it necessary in the national interest[cite: 1126].
The resolution is valid for up to one year but may be extended[cite: 1126].
Parliamentary law made under this power ceases after six months of the resolution lapsing[cite: 1126].

amendments_notes: Reference to Goods and Services Tax (Art. 246A) inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1126].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of Parliament to legislate with respect to any matter in the State List if a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation.
content: While a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, Parliament has the power to make laws for the whole or any part of India with respect to Goods and Services Tax (Art. 246A) or any of the matters enumerated in the State List[cite: 1127].  Any law made by Parliament under this power, which it would not otherwise have been competent to make, ceases to have effect on the expiration of six months after the Proclamation has ceased to operate, except regarding actions taken before that period[cite: 1127].

sub_sections.text: Parliament may legislate on State List matters during an Emergency[cite: 1127].
Parliamentary law made under this power ceases after six months of the Emergency ending[cite: 1127].

amendments_notes: Reference to Goods and Services Tax (Art. 246A) inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1127].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Inconsistency between laws made by Parliament under articles 249 and 250 and laws made by the Legislatures of States.
content: The powers of a State Legislature to make laws are not restricted by Articles 249 and 250[cite: 1127].  However, if any State law is repugnant to a Parliamentary law made under Article 249 or 250, the Parliamentary law shall prevail, and the State law shall be inoperative to the extent of the repugnancy, but only for the period the Parliamentary law continues to have effect[cite: 1127].

sub_sections.text: State law is inoperative if repugnant to a Parliamentary law made under Article 249 or 250, only for the duration the Parliamentary law is in effect[cite: 1127].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of Parliament to legislate for two or more States by consent and adoption of such legislation by any other State.
content: If the Legislatures of two or more States consider it desirable for Parliament to legislate on a matter over which Parliament has no power (except under Arts. 249 and 250), and they pass resolutions to that effect, Parliament may pass an Act regulating that matter for those States[cite: 1127].  This Act can be adopted by any other State by passing a resolution[cite: 1127].  An Act so passed by Parliament can only be amended or repealed by Parliament in the same manner, and cannot be amended or repealed by the Legislature of a State to which it applies[cite: 1128].

sub_sections.text: Parliament can legislate on State List matters for two or more States if the States consent by resolution[cite: 1127].
Such an Act can only be amended or repealed by Parliament, not by the concerned State Legislatures[cite: 1128].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Legislation for giving effect to international agreements.
content: Notwithstanding the distribution of legislative powers, Parliament has the power to make any law for the whole or any part of India for implementing any treaty, agreement, or convention with any other country or any decision made at an international conference, association, or body[cite: 1128].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Inconsistency between laws made by Parliament and laws made by the Legislatures of States.
content: If a State law is repugnant to a Parliamentary law (which Parliament is competent to enact) or to an existing law on a Concurrent List matter, the Parliamentary/existing law prevails, and the State law is void to the extent of the repugnancy[cite: 1128].  If a State law on a Concurrent List matter contains a repugnant provision but has been reserved for and received the President's assent, the State law prevails in that State[cite: 1128].  However, Parliament is not prevented from enacting a subsequent law with respect to the same matter, including a law amending or repealing the State law[cite: 1128].

sub_sections.text: General rule: Parliamentary law prevails over repugnant State law on Concurrent List matters[cite: 1128].
Exception: State law prevails if it receives the President's assent, despite repugnancy to an earlier Parliamentary law[cite: 1128].
Parliament retains the power to enact subsequent law on the same matter, overriding the State law[cite: 1128].

amendments_notes: Omission of references to 'Part A or Part B of the First Schedule' by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1128].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Requirements as to recommendations and previous sanctions to be regarded as matters of procedure only.
content: No Act of Parliament or a State Legislature, or any provision therein, shall be invalid merely because a required recommendation or previous sanction (of the Governor, Rajpramukh, or President) was not given, if assent to that Act was given by the Governor (where Governor's recommendation was needed), or by the President (where President's recommendation/sanction was needed)[cite: 1128, 1129].

sub_sections.text: Failure to meet the requirement of recommendation or previous sanction is only a procedural defect, cured by subsequent assent[cite: 1128, 1129].

amendments_notes: Omission of references to 'Part A or Part B of the First Schedule' by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1128].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Obligation of States and the Union.
content: The executive power of every State shall be exercised to ensure compliance with laws made by Parliament and existing laws applying in that State[cite: 1129].  The executive power of the Union extends to giving such directions to a State as may appear necessary to the Government of India for that purpose[cite: 1129].

sub_sections.text: State must ensure compliance with Union and existing laws[cite: 1129].
Union can give directions to the State to ensure compliance[cite: 1129].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Control of the Union over States in certain cases.
content: The executive power of every State must be exercised so as not to impede or prejudice the exercise of the Union's executive power[cite: 1129].  The Union's executive power extends to giving directions to a State for this purpose[cite: 1129].  The Union may also give directions regarding the construction and maintenance of means of communication declared to be of national or military importance[cite: 1129].  The Union may also give directions regarding measures to be taken for the protection of railways within the State[cite: 1130].  If a State incurs extra costs in carrying out these Union directions (Arts. 257(2) or 257(3)), the Government of India shall pay the State an agreed sum (or one determined by an arbitrator appointed by the CJI) for the extra costs[cite: 1130].

sub_sections.text: State's executive power must not prejudice Union's executive power (Union can give directions)[cite: 1129].
Union can direct States on construction/maintenance of nationally/militarily important communications[cite: 1129].
Union can direct States on measures for railway protection[cite: 1130].
Union must pay for extra costs incurred by a State in carrying out directions under clauses (2) and (3)[cite: 1130].

amendments_notes: Article 257A was inserted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and omitted by the 44th Amendment, 1978[cite: 1130].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of the Union to confer powers, etc., on States in certain cases.
content: The President may, with the consent of a State Government, entrust functions to that Government or its officers relating to any matter to which the Union's executive power extends[cite: 1130].  A Parliamentary law applying in any State may confer powers and impose duties upon the State or its officers, even if the matter is one on which the State Legislature has no power to make laws[cite: 1130].  The Government of India must pay the State an agreed sum (or one determined by an arbitrator appointed by the CJI) for extra costs incurred by the State in connection with the exercise of these conferred powers and duties[cite: 1130].

sub_sections.text: President (with State consent) may entrust Union functions to State Government/officers[cite: 1130].
Parliamentary law may confer powers/duties on State Government/officers, even on matters outside State's legislative power[cite: 1130].
Union must pay the State for extra costs incurred in exercising the conferred powers/duties[cite: 1130].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of the States to entrust functions to the Union.
content: The Governor of a State may, with the consent of the Government of India, entrust functions to that Government or its officers relating to any matter to which the executive power of the State extends[cite: 1130].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1130].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: [Armed Forces in States in Part B of the First Schedule.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1130].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Jurisdiction of the Union in relation to territories outside India.
content: The Government of India may, by agreement with the Government of any territory not part of India, undertake any executive, legislative or judicial functions vested in the government of such territory, subject to any law relating to the exercise of foreign jurisdiction[cite: 1130].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Public acts, records and judicial proceedings.
content: Full faith and credit shall be given throughout the territory of India to public acts, records and judicial proceedings of the Union and of every State[cite: 1131].  Parliament shall provide by law the manner and conditions for proving such acts/records and their effect[cite: 1131].  Final judgments or orders delivered by civil courts in India shall be executable anywhere within that territory according to law[cite: 1131].

sub_sections.text: Full faith and credit given to public acts, records, and judicial proceedings[cite: 1131].
Final judgments/orders of civil courts are executable throughout India[cite: 1131].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Adjudication of disputes relating to waters of inter-State rivers or river valleys.
content: Parliament may by law provide for the adjudication of any dispute or complaint with respect to the use, distribution or control of the waters of, or in, any inter-State river or river valley[cite: 1131].  Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may by law provide that neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall exercise jurisdiction in respect of any such dispute or complaint[cite: 1131].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to provide for adjudication of inter-State river water disputes[cite: 1131].
Parliament may exclude the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court and other courts in respect of such disputes[cite: 1131].

part_title: RELATIONS BETWEEN THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Provisions with respect to an inter-State Council.
content: If the President deems it necessary for public interests, he may by order establish an Inter-State Council[cite: 1131].  The Council is charged with the duty of: inquiring into and advising upon disputes between States; investigating and discussing subjects of common interest to States/Union; and making recommendations for better co-ordination of policy and action[cite: 1131].  The President defines its duties, organization, and procedure[cite: 1131].

sub_sections.text: President may establish an Inter-State Council for co-ordination between States[cite: 1131].
Council's duties relate to disputes, common subjects investigation, and recommending co-ordination[cite: 1131].

article_title: Interpretation.
content: In this Part, 'Finance Commission' means a Finance Commission constituted under article 280[cite: 1132].
amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1132].

article_title: Taxes not to be imposed save by authority of law.
content: No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law[cite: 1132].

article_title: Consolidated Funds and public accounts of India and of the States.
content: All revenues received by the Government of India and all loans/moneys received in loan repayment form the 'Consolidated Fund of India'[cite: 1132].  Similarly, all revenues received by the Government of a State and all loans/moneys received in loan repayment form the 'Consolidated Fund of the State'[cite: 1132].  All other public moneys received by or on behalf of the Government of India or a State are credited to the respective 'public account'[cite: 1132].  No moneys shall be appropriated out of the Consolidated Fund of India or a State except in accordance with law and for the purposes and in the manner provided in this Constitution[cite: 1132].

sub_sections.text: Constitution of the Consolidated Funds of India and of the States (includes revenues and loans)[cite: 1132].
Constitution of the Public Accounts of India and of the States (for other public moneys)[cite: 1132].
Moneys can only be appropriated from the Consolidated Fund according to law and Constitutional provisions[cite: 1132].

article_title: Contingency Fund.
content: Parliament may by law establish a 'Contingency Fund of India' (as an imprest) to enable the President to make advances for unforeseen expenditure, pending authorization by Parliament[cite: 1132].  The Legislature of a State may establish a 'Contingency Fund of the State' for the Governor to make advances for unforeseen expenditure, pending authorization by the State Legislature[cite: 1133].

sub_sections.text: Parliament may establish the Contingency Fund of India for the President's use[cite: 1132].
State Legislature may establish the Contingency Fund of the State for the Governor's use[cite: 1133].

article_title: Duties levied by the Union but collected and appropriated by the States.
content: Such stamp duties as are mentioned in the Union List shall be levied by the Government of India but shall be collected by the Government of India in Union territories, and by the States in other cases[cite: 1133].  The proceeds in any financial year of any such duty leviable within any State shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India, but shall be assigned to that State[cite: 1133].

sub_sections.text: Stamp duties are levied by the Union but collected by the Union (in UTs) or the States (in States)[cite: 1133].
Proceeds from duties leviable within a State are assigned to that State and do not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India[cite: 1133].

amendments_notes: The reference to 'duties of excise on medicinal and toilet preparations' was omitted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1133].

article_title: [Service tax levied by Union and collected and appropriated by the Union and the States.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1133].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Eighty-eighth Amendment) Act, 2003, and omitted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1133].

article_title: Taxes levied and collected by the Union but assigned to the States.
content: Taxes on the sale or purchase of goods and taxes on the consignment of goods (except as provided in article 269A) are levied and collected by the Government of India but are assigned to the States[cite: 1134].  These net proceeds shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India, but shall be assigned to the States within which the tax is leviable, distributed according to principles formulated by Parliament by law[cite: 1134].  Parliament may formulate principles for determining when a sale, purchase, or consignment of goods takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce[cite: 1134].

sub_sections.text: Inter-State sale/purchase and consignment taxes (excluding 269A) are levied and collected by the Union but assigned to the States[cite: 1134].
Net proceeds (excluding UT proceeds) are assigned to the levying States and distributed by Parliamentary law[cite: 1134].
Parliament may formulate principles for determining inter-State commerce[cite: 1134].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and (2) substituted by the Constitution (Eightieth Amendment) Act, 2000[cite: 1134].  Exception for Article 269A inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1134].

article_title: Levy and collection of goods and services tax in course of inter-State trade or commerce.
content: GST on inter-State supply of goods or services (or both) shall be levied and collected by the Government of India and apportioned between the Union and the States by Parliamentary law based on the recommendations of the Goods and Services Tax Council[cite: 1134].  The amount apportioned to a State shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India[cite: 1135].  Parliament may formulate principles for determining the place of supply and when inter-State supply takes place[cite: 1135].

sub_sections.text: GST on inter-State supply levied/collected by Union and apportioned based on GST Council recommendations[cite: 1134].
State's apportioned share does not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India[cite: 1135].
Parliament formulates principles for determining place and time of supply[cite: 1135].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1134].

article_title: Taxes levied and distributed between the Union and the States.
content: All taxes and duties referred to in the Union List (except those in Articles 268, 269, and 269A, surcharge under Art. 271, and cesses) shall be levied and collected by the Government of India and distributed between the Union and the States[cite: 1135].  This distribution also applies to the GST collected by the Union (Art. 246A(1)) and amounts used/apportioned under Articles 246A(2) and 269A[cite: 1135].  A prescribed percentage of the net proceeds shall be assigned to the States and distributed among them as prescribed[cite: 1136].  'Prescribed' means by President's order (after considering the Finance Commission's recommendations if one is constituted)[cite: 1136].

sub_sections.text: General rule: Union List taxes (excluding exceptions) levied/collected by the Union and distributed between the Union and States[cite: 1135].
Provisions ensuring GST collected by the Union is also distributed[cite: 1135].
Distribution percentage to States (as prescribed)[cite: 1136].
Definition of 'prescribed' (by President's order, based on FC advice)[cite: 1136].

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Eightieth Amendment) Act, 2000[cite: 1135].  Amended by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016, to include GST provisions[cite: 1135].

article_title: Surcharge on certain duties and taxes for purposes of the Union.
content: Notwithstanding anything in articles 269 and 270, Parliament may at any time increase any of the duties or taxes referred to in those articles (except the goods and services tax under article 246A) by a surcharge for purposes of the Union, and the whole proceeds of any such surcharge shall form part of the Consolidated Fund of India[cite: 1136].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to levy a surcharge (excluding GST under Art. 246A) for Union purposes, with proceeds forming part of the Consolidated Fund of India[cite: 1136].

amendments_notes: Exception for GST (Article 246A) inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1136].

article_title: [Taxes which are levied and collected by the Union and may be distributed between the Union and the States.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1136].
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Eightieth Amendment) Act, 2000[cite: 1136].

article_title: Grants in lieu of export duty on jute and jute products.
content: Certain prescribed sums shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India each year as grants-in-aid to the revenues of Assam, Bihar, Odisha, and West Bengal, in lieu of assignment of any share of the export duty on jute and jute products[cite: 1136].  These sums shall continue so long as the duty is levied, or for ten years from the commencement of the Constitution, whichever is earlier[cite: 1137].  'Prescribed' has the same meaning as in Article 270[cite: 1137].

sub_sections.text: Mandatory grants-in-aid to Assam, Bihar, Odisha, and West Bengal in lieu of jute export duty share[cite: 1136].
Grants continue for a maximum of ten years or until the duty ceases[cite: 1137].

amendments_notes: State name 'Orissa' substituted with 'Odisha' by Act 15 of 2011[cite: 1136].

article_title: Prior recommendation of President required to Bills affecting taxation in which States are interested.
content: No Bill or amendment which imposes or varies any tax or duty in which States are interested (tax proceeds assigned to States, or sums payable to States based on net proceeds), or which varies the meaning of 'agricultural income' for income-tax purposes, or which affects the principles of money distribution to States, or which imposes a surcharge for Union purposes, shall be introduced or moved in either House of Parliament except on the recommendation of the President[cite: 1137].

sub_sections.text: Requires President's prior recommendation for Bills affecting State taxation interests or distribution principles[cite: 1137].
Definition of 'tax or duty in which States are interested'[cite: 1137].

article_title: Grants from the Union to certain States.
content: Parliament may by law provide sums (charged on the Consolidated Fund of India) as grants-in-aid of the revenues of such States as Parliament determines to be in need of assistance, with different sums fixed for different States[cite: 1137].  Grants are mandated for schemes promoting the welfare of Scheduled Tribes in a State or raising the level of administration in Scheduled Areas[cite: 1137].  Special grants are also provided for Assam in respect of its tribal areas[cite: 1138].  Until Parliament makes law, the President exercises these powers by order, but only after considering the Finance Commission's recommendations[cite: 1138].

sub_sections.text: Grants-in-aid to States in need of assistance[cite: 1137].
Mandatory grants for ST welfare/Scheduled Area administration costs[cite: 1137].
President exercises this power until Parliament legislates, acting on FC recommendations[cite: 1138].

amendments_notes: Clause (1A) inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-second Amendment) Act, 1969, regarding the autonomous State in Assam[cite: 1138].

article_title: Taxes on professions, trades, callings and employments.
content: A State law relating to taxes for the benefit of the State/local authority on professions, trades, callings or employments is not invalid merely on the ground that it relates to a tax on income[cite: 1138].  The total amount payable by any one person in respect of such taxes shall not exceed two thousand and five hundred rupees per annum[cite: 1139].  The State Legislature's power to make such laws does not limit Parliament's power to make laws with respect to taxes on income arising from professions, trades, etc.[cite: 1139].

sub_sections.text: State/local taxes on professions, trades, etc., are not income taxes[cite: 1138].
Maximum annual tax ceiling of Rs.  2,500 per person[cite: 1139].
State's power does not limit Parliament's power to tax income[cite: 1139].

amendments_notes: Maximum tax ceiling substituted by the Constitution (Sixtieth Amendment) Act, 1988[cite: 1139].

article_title: Savings.
content: Any taxes, duties, cesses or fees being lawfully levied by a State/local authority immediately before the commencement of this Constitution may continue to be levied and applied for the same purposes, notwithstanding that those taxes are mentioned in the Union List, until Parliament makes a law to the contrary[cite: 1139].

sub_sections.text: Savings provision allowing continuation of pre-Constitution taxes/duties levied by States, even if now in the Union List[cite: 1139].

article_title: [Agreement with States in Part B of the First Schedule with regard to certain financial matters.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1139].
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1139].

article_title: Calculation of 'net proceeds', etc.
content: 'Net proceeds' means the proceeds of any tax or duty reduced by the cost of collection[cite: 1139].  The net proceeds shall be ascertained and certified by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, whose certificate is final[cite: 1139].  Subject to this, Parliament or the President may provide for the manner in which proceeds are calculated and payments/adjustments are made[cite: 1139].

sub_sections.text: Definition of 'net proceeds' and the final certification role of the CAG[cite: 1139].
Provision for rules on calculation, payment, and adjustment of proceeds[cite: 1139].

article_title: Goods and Services Tax Council.
content: The President shall constitute the Goods and Services Tax Council (GST Council) within sixty days of the commencement of the 101st Amendment Act[cite: 1140].  The Council consists of the Union Finance Minister (Chairperson), the Union Minister of State in charge of Revenue or Finance (Member), and the Minister in charge of Finance or Taxation (or other nominated Minister) from each State Government (Members)[cite: 1140].  Members choose a Vice-Chairperson from amongst the State Ministers[cite: 1140].  The GST Council makes recommendations to the Union and States on GST matters, including taxes to be subsumed, exemptions, rates, model laws, and special provisions for certain States[cite: 1141].  The Council recommends the date for levying GST on petroleum crude, diesel, petrol, natural gas, and aviation turbine fuel[cite: 1141].  The quorum is one-half of the total Members[cite: 1141].  Decisions are taken at a meeting by a majority of not less than three-fourths of the weighted votes: Union vote has a weightage of one-third; votes of all State Governments together have a weightage of two-thirds[cite: 1141].  The Council establishes a mechanism to adjudicate disputes between the Union and States[cite: 1142].

sub_sections.text: President constitutes the Goods and Services Tax Council (GST Council)[cite: 1140].
Composition of the GST Council (Union Finance Minister, Union Minister of State, and State Ministers)[cite: 1140].
Council's function: recommending on rates, exemptions, laws, etc.[cite: 1141].
Voting procedure requires a three-fourths majority of weighted votes (Union: 1/3 weight; States: 2/3 weight)[cite: 1141].
Council establishes a dispute adjudication mechanism[cite: 1142].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016[cite: 1140].

article_title: Finance Commission.
content: The President shall constitute a Finance Commission (FC) within two years from the commencement of this Constitution and thereafter at the expiration of every fifth year (or earlier)[cite: 1142].  The FC consists of a Chairman and four other members appointed by the President[cite: 1142].  Parliament may determine the qualifications and manner of selection for members[cite: 1142].  The FC's duty is to recommend to the President concerning: the distribution of shared taxes between the Union and States and allocation among States; the principles governing grants-in-aid; measures to augment the Consolidated Fund of a State to supplement resources of Panchayats (based on State FC recommendations) [cite: 1142, 1143] ; measures to augment the Consolidated Fund of a State to supplement resources of Municipalities (based on State FC recommendations) [cite: 1143] ; and any other matter referred by the President[cite: 1143].  The FC determines its own procedure and powers as conferred by Parliament[cite: 1143].

sub_sections.text: President constitutes a Finance Commission every five years[cite: 1142].
FC recommends on vertical and horizontal tax distribution, and grants-in-aid[cite: 1142].
FC recommends measures to augment State funds for Panchayats[cite: 1142, 1143].
FC recommends measures to augment State funds for Municipalities[cite: 1143].

amendments_notes: Clauses (3)(bb) and (3)(c) inserted by the 73rd and 74th Amendments, 1992, respectively[cite: 1142, 1143].

article_title: Recommendations of the Finance Commission.
content: The President shall cause every recommendation made by the Finance Commission, along with an explanatory memorandum on the action taken thereon, to be laid before each House of Parliament[cite: 1143].

article_title: Expenditure defrayable by the Union or a State out of its revenues.
content: The Union or a State may make any grants for any public purpose, even if the purpose is not one with respect to which Parliament or the Legislature of the State may make laws[cite: 1143].

sub_sections.text: Power to make discretionary grants (even outside legislative competence) for a public purpose[cite: 1143].

article_title: Custody, etc., of Consolidated Funds, Contingency Funds and moneys credited to the public accounts.
content: The custody, payment, and withdrawal of moneys related to the Consolidated Fund of India, Contingency Fund of India, and the Public Account of India shall be regulated by law made by Parliament (or by President's rules until then)[cite: 1143].  The custody, payment, and withdrawal of moneys related to the Consolidated Fund of a State, Contingency Fund of a State, and the Public Account of the State shall be regulated by law made by the State Legislature (or by Governor's rules until then)[cite: 1143].

sub_sections.text: Regulation of Union Funds and Public Account (by Parliament/President's rules)[cite: 1143].
Regulation of State Funds and Public Account (by State Legislature/Governor's rules)[cite: 1143, 1144].

article_title: Custody of suitors' deposits and other moneys received by public servants and courts.
content: All moneys received by or deposited with: (a) any officer (Union or State) in their official capacity (other than revenues/public moneys); or (b) any court to the credit of any cause, matter, etc., shall be paid into the public account of India or the public account of the State, as the case may be[cite: 1144].

sub_sections.text: Certain deposits and moneys received by public servants or courts are credited to the Public Account[cite: 1144].

article_title: Exemption of property of the Union from State taxation.
content: The property of the Union shall be exempt from all taxes imposed by a State or by any authority within a State, unless Parliament by law otherwise provides[cite: 1144].  However, until Parliament provides otherwise, a State authority may levy any tax on Union property to which it was liable or treated as liable immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, provided that tax continues to be levied in that State[cite: 1144].

sub_sections.text: Union property is generally exempt from State taxation[cite: 1144].
Savings provision allowing continuation of pre-Constitution taxes on Union property[cite: 1144].

article_title: Restrictions as to imposition of tax on the sale or purchase of goods.
content: No law of a State shall impose a tax on the supply of goods or of services or both, where such supply takes place outside the State; or in the course of the import of the goods or services or both into, or export out of, the territory of India[cite: 1144].  Parliament may by law formulate principles for determining when a supply of goods or of services or both takes place outside the State or in the course of import/export[cite: 1144].

sub_sections.text: Restrictions on State tax power: No tax on supply occurring (a) outside the State, or (b) during import or export[cite: 1144].
Parliament formulates principles for determining where/when supply takes place[cite: 1144].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) and (2) substituted/amended by the 6th and 101st Amendments, reflecting the shift from 'sale or purchase' to 'supply' in line with GST[cite: 1144].

article_title: Exemption from taxes on electricity.
content: No law of a State shall impose a tax on the consumption or sale of electricity (unless Parliament provides otherwise) which is: consumed by the Government of India, or sold to the Government of India for consumption; or consumed in the construction, maintenance or operation of any railway by the Government of India or a railway company, or sold to them for such consumption[cite: 1145].  Any State law imposing a tax on the sale of electricity must ensure that the price charged to the Government of India or railway companies is less by the amount of the tax than the price charged to other consumers of a substantial quantity[cite: 1145].

sub_sections.text: Exemption of Union/Railway consumption/sale of electricity from State tax[cite: 1145].
State law imposing electricity tax must adjust the price charged to the Union/Railways[cite: 1145].

article_title: Exemption from taxation by States in respect of water or electricity in certain cases.
content: No law of a State in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall impose a tax in respect of water or electricity stored, generated, consumed, distributed or sold by any authority established by existing law or Parliamentary law for regulating/developing any inter-State river or river-valley (unless the President by order otherwise provides)[cite: 1145].  A State Legislature may impose such a tax by law, but it must receive the President's assent, and any subsequent rules/orders made under that law must also have the President's previous consent[cite: 1145].

sub_sections.text: Restriction on pre-Constitution State laws taxing water/electricity produced by inter-State river/river-valley authorities (unless President orders otherwise)[cite: 1145].
State law imposing this tax requires President's assent, and subsequent rules setting rates require President's consent[cite: 1145].

article_title: Exemption of property and income of a State from Union taxation.
content: The property and income of a State shall be exempt from Union taxation[cite: 1146].  However, the Union is not prevented from imposing any tax in respect of a trade or business carried on by or on behalf of a State Government, or any property/income related thereto, to the extent Parliament by law provides[cite: 1146].  This exception does not apply to any trade or business which Parliament may declare to be incidental to the ordinary functions of Government[cite: 1146].

sub_sections.text: State property and income are exempt from Union taxation[cite: 1146].
Union may tax State trade or business property/income, subject to Parliamentary law[cite: 1146].
Clause (2) exception does not apply to government's ordinary functions (as declared by Parliament)[cite: 1146].

article_title: Adjustment in respect of certain expenses and pensions.
content: Where expenses of any court or Commission, or pensions payable to or in respect of a person, are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the Union or a State, and the court, Commission, or person has served the separate needs of the other (Union/State), a contribution shall be charged on and paid out of the Consolidated Fund of the other (Union/State) in respect of the expenses or pension[cite: 1146].  The contribution is based on agreement or determined by an arbitrator appointed by the Chief Justice of India[cite: 1146].

sub_sections.text: Mechanism for adjustment of shared expenses/pensions between the Union and States, determined by agreement or CJI-appointed arbitrator[cite: 1146].

article_title: Annual payment to certain Devaswom Funds.
content: A sum of forty-six lakhs and fifty thousand rupees shall be charged on and paid out of the Consolidated Fund of the State of Kerala every year to the Travancore Devaswom Fund[cite: 1147].  A sum of thirteen lakhs and fifty thousand rupees shall be charged on and paid out of the Consolidated Fund of the State of Tamil Nadu every year to the Devaswom Fund established in that State for the maintenance of Hindu temples and shrines in the transferred territories[cite: 1147].

sub_sections.text: Mandatory annual payments from Kerala and Tamil Nadu Consolidated Funds to specified Devaswom Funds[cite: 1147].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1147].

article_title: [Privy purse sums of Rulers.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1147].
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971[cite: 1147].

article_title: Borrowing by the Government of India.
content: The executive power of the Union extends to borrowing upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of India within such limits as Parliament may fix by law, and to the giving of guarantees within such limits[cite: 1147].

sub_sections.text: Union's power to borrow against the Consolidated Fund of India and give guarantees, subject to limits fixed by Parliament's law[cite: 1147].

article_title: Borrowing by States.
content: A State's executive power extends to borrowing within India upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of the State, within limits fixed by the State Legislature[cite: 1147].  The Government of India may make loans to any State or give guarantees for State loans (if Union limits under Art. 292 are not exceeded), with sums required charged on the Consolidated Fund of India[cite: 1147].  A State cannot raise any loan without the consent of the Government of India if any part of a loan made or guaranteed by the Government of India (or its predecessor) is still outstanding[cite: 1147].  Consent may be granted subject to conditions imposed by the Government of India[cite: 1147].

sub_sections.text: State's power to borrow within India against the State Consolidated Fund, subject to State Legislature limits[cite: 1147].
Union's power to grant loans or guarantees to States (charged on Consolidated Fund of India)[cite: 1147].
State requires Union consent to raise loans if a Union loan/guarantee is outstanding[cite: 1147].

article_title: Succession to property, assets, rights, liabilities and obligations in certain cases.
content: As from the commencement of this Constitution: (a) all property and assets vested in His Majesty for the purposes of the Government of the Dominion of India or of each Governors Province vest respectively in the Union and the corresponding State; and (b) all rights, liabilities, and obligations of the Government of the Dominion of India and of each Governor's Province (whether arising from contract or otherwise) become the respective rights, liabilities, and obligations of the Government of India and the corresponding State[cite: 1147, 1148].  This is subject to adjustments made due to the creation of Pakistan or the provinces of West Bengal, East Bengal, West Punjab, and East Punjab[cite: 1148].

sub_sections.text: Succession to property and assets of the Dominion and Governors Provinces by the Union and corresponding States[cite: 1147].
Succession to rights, liabilities, and obligations of the Dominion and Governors Provinces by the Union and corresponding States[cite: 1148].

article_title: Succession to property, assets, rights, liabilities and obligations in other cases.
content: As from the commencement of this Constitution, all property and assets vested in any Indian State corresponding to a Part B State vest in the Union if held for Union List purposes.  All rights, liabilities, and obligations of the Government of any Indian State corresponding to a Part B State become those of the Government of India if the purpose for which they were acquired/incurred relates to Union List matters, subject to any agreement with that State[cite: 1148].  Subject to this, the Government of each Part B State is the successor of the Government of the corresponding Indian State regarding all other property, assets, rights, liabilities, and obligations[cite: 1148, 1149].

sub_sections.text: Succession to property, assets, rights, liabilities, and obligations of Indian States (corresponding to Part B States) by the Union (if relating to Union List matters)[cite: 1148].
The Government of the Part B State succeeds to all other property, etc.[cite: 1149].

article_title: Property accruing by escheat or lapse or as bona vacantia.
content: Any property in India that would have accrued to His Majesty or to the Ruler of an Indian State by escheat (reversion of property to state), lapse, or as bona vacantia (ownerless goods) shall vest in the State where it is situated, and in any other case, vest in the Union[cite: 1149].  Property in the possession/control of the Union or a State Government at the date of accrual vests in the Union or that State, depending on whose purposes it was used/held for[cite: 1149].

sub_sections.text: Property accruing by escheat, lapse, or as bona vacantia vests in the State (if situated in a State) or the Union (in other cases)[cite: 1149].

article_title: Things of value within territorial waters or continental shelf and resources of the exclusive economic zone to vest in the Union.
content: All lands, minerals, and other things of value underlying the ocean within the territorial waters, or the continental shelf, or the exclusive economic zone of India shall vest in the Union and be held for Union purposes[cite: 1149].  All other resources of the exclusive economic zone also vest in the Union[cite: 1149].  The limits of the territorial waters, continental shelf, exclusive economic zone, and other maritime zones shall be specified by or under law made by Parliament[cite: 1149].

sub_sections.text: Lands, minerals, and things of value in territorial waters, continental shelf, and EEZ vest in the Union[cite: 1149].
All other resources of the EEZ vest in the Union[cite: 1149].
Limits of zones are specified by Parliamentary law[cite: 1149].

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Fortieth Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 1149].

article_title: Power to carry on trade, etc.
content: The executive power of the Union and of each State extends to carrying on any trade or business, and to the acquisition, holding, and disposal of property and making contracts for any purpose[cite: 1149].  The Union's executive power for trade/business/other purposes (where Parliament cannot make laws) is subject to legislation by the State[cite: 1150].  The State's executive power for trade/business/other purposes (where the State Legislature cannot make laws) is subject to legislation by Parliament[cite: 1150].

sub_sections.text: Executive power of Union and States extends to trade, property, and contracts[cite: 1149].
Mutual restrictions on these executive powers based on legislative competence[cite: 1150].

amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1149].

article_title: Contracts.
content: All contracts made in the exercise of the executive power of the Union or of a State must be expressed to be made by the President or the Governor, respectively, and executed by such persons and in such manner as directed/authorised by them[cite: 1150].  Neither the President nor the Governor (nor the executing person) shall be personally liable in respect of any contract or assurance made for the purposes of the Constitution or prior Government enactments[cite: 1150].

sub_sections.text: Formal requirement for Government contracts (expressed in name of President/Governor and executed by authorized person)[cite: 1150].
Protection against personal liability for the President, Governor, and the executing person[cite: 1150].

article_title: Suits and proceedings.
content: The Government of India may sue or be sued by the name of the Union of India, and the Government of a State may sue or be sued by the name of the State[cite: 1150].  They may sue or be sued in relation to their respective affairs in the like cases as the Dominion of India and the corresponding Provinces or Indian States might have sued or been sued if the Constitution had not been enacted[cite: 1150].  Where legal proceedings are pending against the Dominion of India or a Province/Indian State at the commencement of the Constitution, the Union of India or the corresponding State shall be substituted as the party[cite: 1150, 1151].

sub_sections.text: Union/State capacity to sue and be sued (mode of action and scope determined by pre-Constitution practices)[cite: 1150].
Substitution of the Union or corresponding State in pending legal proceedings[cite: 1150, 1151].

article_title: Persons not to be deprived of property save by authority of law.
content: No person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law[cite: 1151].
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1151].

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: Freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse.
content: Subject to the other provisions of this Part, trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free[cite: 1151].

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: Power of Parliament to impose restrictions on trade, commerce and intercourse.
content: Parliament may by law impose such restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse between one State and another or within any part of the territory of India as may be required in the public interest[cite: 1151].

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: Restrictions on the legislative powers of the Union and of the States with regard to trade and commerce.
content: Notwithstanding anything in article 302, neither Parliament nor the Legislature of a State shall have power to make any law giving, or authorising the giving of, any preference to one State over another, or making, or authorising the making of, any discrimination between one State and another, by virtue of any entry relating to trade and commerce in any of the Lists in the Seventh Schedule[cite: 1151].  However, this restriction does not prevent Parliament from making any law giving preference or making discrimination if it is declared by such law that it is necessary to do so for the purpose of dealing with a situation arising from scarcity of goods in any part of the territory of India[cite: 1151].

sub_sections.text: Neither Parliament nor a State Legislature can give preference to one State over another, or discriminate between States, regarding trade and commerce entries in the Lists[cite: 1151].
Parliament can make a law giving preference/discrimination if necessary to deal with scarcity of goods in any part of India[cite: 1151].

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: Restrictions on trade, commerce and intercourse among States.
content: Notwithstanding anything in article 301 or article 303, the Legislature of a State may by law impose on goods imported from other States or the Union territories any tax to which similar goods manufactured or produced in that State are subject, so, however, as not to discriminate between imported and locally manufactured goods [cite: 1151, 1152] ; and impose such reasonable restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse with or within that State as may be required in the public interest[cite: 1152].  No Bill or amendment for imposing such reasonable restrictions shall be introduced or moved in the Legislature of a State without the previous sanction of the President[cite: 1152].

sub_sections.text: State Legislature can impose equal, non-discriminatory tax on imported goods (from other States/UTs) as levied on local goods[cite: 1151, 1152].
State Legislature can impose reasonable restrictions required in the public interest[cite: 1152].
A Bill for imposing reasonable restrictions requires the President's previous sanction[cite: 1152].

amendments_notes: Reference to 'Union territories' inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: Saving of existing laws and laws providing for State monopolies.
content: Nothing in articles 301 and 303 shall affect the provisions of any existing law except as the President may by order otherwise direct[cite: 1152].  Furthermore, nothing in article 301 shall affect the operation of any law made before the commencement of the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955, in so far as it relates to, or prevent Parliament or the Legislature of a State from making any law relating to, any such matter as is referred to in sub-clause (ii) of clause (6) of article 19 (State trading/monopolies)[cite: 1152].
amendments_notes: Substituted by the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955.

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: [Power of certain States in Part B of the First Schedule to impose restrictions on trade and commerce.]
content: This article was omitted[cite: 1152].
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1152].

part_title: TRADE, COMMERCE AND INTERCOURSE WITHIN THE TERRITORY OF INDIA
article_title: Appointment of authority for carrying out the purposes of articles 301 to 304.
content: Parliament may by law appoint such authority as it considers appropriate for carrying out the purposes of articles 301 to 304, and confer on the authority so appointed such powers and duties as it thinks necessary[cite: 1152].

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Interpretation.
content: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression 'State' does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
amendments_notes: The exclusion of the State of Jammu and Kashmir was substituted for the original definition by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Recruitment and conditions of service of persons serving the Union or a State.
content: Acts of the appropriate Legislature may regulate the recruitment and conditions of service of persons appointed to public services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or any State, subject to the provisions of this Constitution. Until provision is made by such an Act, the President (for Union affairs) or the Governor (for State affairs) may make rules regulating recruitment and conditions of service, and such rules shall have effect subject to the provisions of any such Act.

sub_sections.text: Recruitment and conditions of service regulated by Acts of the appropriate Legislature.
President/Governor can make interim rules until such Act is made.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Tenure of office of persons serving the Union or a State.
content: Every person who is a member of a defence service, civil service of the Union, all-India service, or holds any post connected with defence or any civil post under the Union, holds office during the pleasure of the President. Every person who is a member of a civil service of a State or holds any civil post under a State holds office during the pleasure of the Governor of the State. Notwithstanding this pleasure doctrine, a contract under which a non-permanent civil servant (not from a defence, all-India, or civil service) is appointed may provide for compensation if the post is abolished or if he is required to vacate for reasons unconnected with misconduct.

sub_sections.text: Tenure under the Union is held during the pleasure of the President; tenure under a State is held during the pleasure of the Governor.
Provision for compensation in case of contract appointments that are terminated early (for non-misconduct reasons).

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Dismissal, removal or reduction in rank of persons employed in civil capacities under the Union or a State.
content: No person who is a member of a civil service of the Union/State or an all-India service, or holds a civil post under the Union/State, shall be dismissed or removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed. No such person shall be dismissed, removed or reduced in rank except after an inquiry informing him of the charges and giving him a reasonable opportunity of being heard. After inquiry, the penalty may be imposed based on evidence, and further representation on the penalty proposed is not necessary. The inquiry requirement does not apply where: (a) a person is convicted on a criminal charge; (b) the authority is satisfied it is not reasonably practicable to hold such inquiry (to be recorded in writing); or (c) the President or Governor is satisfied that in the interest of the security of the State it is not expedient to hold such inquiry. If a question arises as to whether it is reasonably practicable to hold an inquiry, the decision of the empowered authority is final.

sub_sections.text: Protection against dismissal/removal by a subordinate authority (must be by the appointing authority or higher).
Mandatory inquiry and reasonable opportunity of being heard before penalty.
No further representation needed on the penalty proposed.
Three exceptions to the inquiry rule (criminal conviction, impracticality, security of the State).
Authority's decision on practicability of inquiry is final.

amendments_notes: Clauses (2) and (3) substituted by the Constitution (Fifteenth Amendment) Act, 1963. The Proviso regarding representation on penalty was inserted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: All-India services.
content: Notwithstanding the provisions regarding States and Union-State relations, if the Council of States declares by a resolution supported by two-thirds of members present and voting that it is necessary/expedient in the national interest, Parliament may by law provide for the creation of one or more All-India Services (including an All-India Judicial Service) common to the Union and the States, and regulate the recruitment and conditions of service. The Indian Administrative Service and the Indian Police Service are deemed to be services created under this article. The All-India Judicial Service shall not include any post inferior to that of a district judge (Article 236). The law establishing the All-India Judicial Service may amend Chapter VI of Part VI (Subordinate Courts), and such a law is not deemed an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of Article 368.

sub_sections.text: Creation of All-India Services (common to Union and States) by Parliament if mandated by a Council of States resolution (two-thirds majority).
Existing AIS and IPS are deemed created under this article.
All-India Judicial Service excludes posts inferior to district judge.
Law creating AIJS may amend Part VI, Chapter VI, and is not a formal 368 amendment.

amendments_notes: Reference to Chapter VI of Part VI and All-India Judicial Service inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power of Parliament to vary or revoke conditions of service of officers of certain services.
content: Parliament may by law vary or revoke (prospectively or retrospectively) the conditions of service (remuneration, leave, pension, disciplinary rights) of persons who were appointed by the Secretary of State/Secretary of State in Council to a civil service of the Crown before the commencement of this Constitution and continue to serve thereafter. This power also applies to the pensions of such retired persons. However, this power does not apply to vary the conditions of service to the disadvantage of those holding high constitutional offices (like Supreme Court/High Court Judges, CAG, UPSC/PSC Chairman, or Chief Election Commissioner) after their appointment to such posts, except in so far as those conditions are applicable by reason of their pre-Constitution appointment. The Supreme Court and other courts shall not have jurisdiction over certain disputes arising out of pre-Constitution covenants, agreements, or rights under Article 314 (as originally enacted).

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to vary/revoke conditions of service/pensions for former Secretary of State appointees (ICS/IP).
Protection of service conditions for high constitutional office holders.
Bar on court jurisdiction regarding disputes arising from pre-Constitution covenants/agreements (related to such appointees).

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-eighth Amendment) Act, 1972.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Transitional provisions.
content: Until other provision is made under this Constitution, all laws in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution and applicable to any public service or post which continues to exist (as an All-India Service or as service/post under the Union/State) shall continue in force so far as consistent with the provisions of this Constitution.

sub_sections.text: Continuation of existing service laws until new provisions are made.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: [Provision for protection of existing officers of certain services.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Twenty-eighth Amendment) Act, 1972.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Public Service Commissions for the Union and for the States.
content: There shall be a Public Service Commission (PSC) for the Union (UPSC) and a PSC for each State (SPSC). Two or more States may agree to have one Joint State Public Service Commission (JPSC) by passing a resolution in their Legislatures. The UPSC may agree to serve all or any of the needs of a State if requested by the Governor and approved by the President.

sub_sections.text: Provision for a Union PSC and a PSC for each State.
Provision for a Joint State PSC (JPSC) by agreement and Parliamentary law.
UPSC may serve the needs of a State (on Governor's request and President's approval).

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Appointment and term of office of members.
content: The Chairman and other members of the UPSC/JPSC are appointed by the President, and those of an SPSC by the Governor. Approximately one-half of the members must be persons who have held office under the Government of India or a State for at least ten years. Members hold office for a term of six years or until attaining the age of sixty-five years (UPSC) or sixty-two years (SPSC/JPSC), whichever is earlier. A member may resign (to the President/Governor) or be removed (Article 317). A member is ineligible for re-appointment to that office upon expiration of the term.

sub_sections.text: Appointment procedure (President for UPSC/JPSC; Governor for SPSC).
Requirement for roughly half the members to have 10 years of public service experience.
Provision for an acting Chairman when the Chairman's office is vacant or he is unable to perform duties.
Term of office: 6 years or age limit (65 for UPSC; 62 for SPSC/JPSC).
Ineligibility for re-appointment to the same office.

amendments_notes: Clause (1A) inserted by the Constitution (Fifteenth Amendment) Act, 1963. Age limit for SPSC/JPSC changed from sixty to sixty-two by the 41st Amendment, 1976.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Removal and suspension of a member of a Public Service Commission.
content: A Chairman or member of a PSC can only be removed from office by order of the President on the ground of misbehaviour, after the Supreme Court, on reference by the President, has inquired and reported that the member ought to be removed. The President (UPSC/JPSC) or Governor (SPSC) may suspend the member in respect of whom a reference has been made to the Supreme Court until the President passes orders on receipt of the report.
