Notwithstanding the inquiry, the President may remove a member if he: is adjudged an insolvent; engages in paid employment outside the duties of his office; or is unfit to continue due to infirmity of mind or body. Being concerned or interested in any government contract or agreement is deemed misbehaviour for the purpose of removal under the SC inquiry procedure.

sub_sections.text: Removal procedure by President's order after Supreme Court inquiry (misbehaviour).
Suspension power of the President/Governor pending SC report.
Removal power of the President without SC inquiry (insolvency, outside employment, or infirmity).
Definition of misbehaviour (involvement in government contracts) for the purpose of clause (1).

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power to make regulations as to conditions of service of members and staff of the Commission.
content: The President (UPSC/JPSC) or the Governor (SPSC) may make regulations determining the number of members, their conditions of service, and the number/conditions of service of the staff. The conditions of service of a member of a PSC shall not be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.

sub_sections.text: President/Governor makes regulations for size, member/staff conditions of service.
Conditions of service for members cannot be varied to their disadvantage after appointment.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Prohibition as to the holding of offices by members of Commission on ceasing to be such members.
content: Restrictions on further employment after ceasing office: (a) UPSC Chairman is ineligible for any further employment under the Union or a State. (b) SPSC Chairman is eligible for Chairman/member of UPSC or Chairman of any other SPSC, but ineligible for any other Union/State employment. (c) UPSC member (other than Chairman) is eligible for UPSC Chairman or SPSC Chairman, but ineligible for any other Union/State employment. (d) SPSC member (other than Chairman) is eligible for Chairman/member of UPSC or Chairman of that or any other SPSC, but ineligible for any other Union/State employment.

sub_sections.text: UPSC Chairman is barred from all further government employment.
SPSC Chairman is eligible for higher PSC roles but barred from other government employment.
UPSC member is eligible for PSC Chairmanship roles but barred from other government employment.
SPSC member is eligible for UPSC/PSC roles but barred from other government employment.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Functions of Public Service Commissions.
content: The UPSC/SPSC conduct examinations for appointments to Union/State services. UPSC assists States in joint recruitment schemes if requested. The UPSC/SPSC shall be consulted on: recruitment methods, principles for appointments/promotions/transfers, disciplinary matters, claims for defense costs in legal proceedings, and claims for injury pensions. PSCs must advise on any matter referred to them by the President/Governor. The President/Governor may make regulations specifying matters where consultation with the PSC is not necessary (regulations must be laid before the respective Legislature). PSC consultation is not required regarding the manner of making reservations for backward classes (Art. 16(4)) or giving effect to Scheduled Caste/Tribe claims (Art. 335).

sub_sections.text: Conduct of examinations for appointments.
Matters on which the PSCs must be consulted (recruitment, promotion, discipline, legal costs, pensions).
President/Governor may specify matters where consultation is not necessary.
No consultation required on matters of reservation (Art. 16(4)) or SC/ST claims (Art. 335).

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Power to extend functions of Public Service Commissions.
content: An Act made by Parliament or a State Legislature may provide for the exercise of additional functions by the UPSC or SPSC concerning the services of the Union/State and also concerning the services of any local authority or other body corporate/public institution.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Expenses of Public Service Commissions.
content: The expenses of the UPSC or SPSC, including salaries, allowances, and pensions of members or staff, shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India or, as the case may be, the Consolidated Fund of the State.

sub_sections.text: Expenses of the PSCs are charged on the respective Consolidated Fund.

part_title: SERVICES UNDER THE UNION AND THE STATES
article_title: Reports of Public Service Commissions.
content: The UPSC must present an annual report to the President, who tables it before each House of Parliament, along with a memorandum explaining cases where the Commission's advice was not accepted and the reasons for non-acceptance. A State Commission must present an annual report to the Governor, who tables it before the State Legislature, along with a similar explanatory memorandum.

sub_sections.text: UPSC annual report presented to the President and laid before Parliament.
SPSC/JPSC annual report presented to the Governor and laid before the State Legislature.

article_title: Administrative tribunals.
content: Parliament may, by law, provide for the adjudication or trial by administrative tribunals of disputes and complaints with respect to recruitment and conditions of service of persons appointed to public services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or of any State or of any local or other authority or any corporation owned or controlled by the Government[cite: 1163].  Such a law may provide for the establishment of separate administrative tribunals for the Union and for each State (or two or more States)[cite: 1163].  It may specify the jurisdiction, powers (including contempt power), and authority exercised by the tribunals[cite: 1163].  It may exclude the jurisdiction of all courts, except the Supreme Court under Article 136, with respect to these disputes[cite: 1163].  The law may also provide for the transfer of pending cases, repeal/amend orders under Article 371D, and contain supplemental/incidental/consequential provisions[cite: 1163].  The provisions of this article have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of this Constitution or in any other law[cite: 1164].

sub_sections.text: Parliament may provide for Administrative Tribunals for service disputes.
Law may establish separate Union and State tribunals.
Law may exclude jurisdiction of all courts except the Supreme Court (Art. 136).
This article prevails over other constitutional provisions/laws.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976, s.  46 (w.e.f. 3-1-1977)[cite: 1163].

article_title: Tribunals for other matters.
content: The appropriate Legislature (Parliament or State Legislature) may, by law, provide for the adjudication or trial by tribunals of any disputes, complaints, or offences with respect to specified matters over which that Legislature has power to make laws[cite: 1164].  These matters include: levy/assessment/collection/enforcement of any tax; foreign exchange/import/export; industrial and labour disputes; land reforms; ceiling on urban property; elections to Legislatures (excluding Arts. 329 and 329A); production/supply/distribution of foodstuffs and essential goods; rent/rent control/tenancy issues; and offenses/matters incidental thereto[cite: 1164, 1165].  A law made under this power may provide for a hierarchy of tribunals, specify their jurisdiction/powers (including contempt power), exclude the jurisdiction of all courts except the Supreme Court (Art. 136), provide for case transfers, and contain supplemental provisions[cite: 1165].  The provisions of this article have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of this Constitution or in any other law[cite: 1165].  'Appropriate Legislature' is defined as Parliament or a State Legislature competent to make laws on that matter[cite: 1165].

sub_sections.text: Appropriate Legislature may provide for tribunals for specified matters.
List of matters covered (taxes, foreign exchange, labour disputes, land reforms, price control, elections, etc.).
Law may exclude jurisdiction of all courts except the Supreme Court (Art. 136).
This article prevails over other constitutional provisions/laws.
Definition of 'appropriate Legislature'.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 1163].  'Rent' and tenancy issues inserted by the 75th Amendment, 1993[cite: 1164].

article_title: Superintendence, direction and control of elections to be vested in an Election Commission.
content: The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to Parliament, to the Legislature of every State, and to the offices of President and Vice-President shall be vested in a Commission (Election Commission). The Election Commission consists of the Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) and such number of other Election Commissioners (ECs) as the President may fix. The appointment of the CEC and other ECs shall be made by the President, subject to Parliamentary law. The CEC acts as Chairman when other ECs are appointed. The President may also appoint Regional Commissioners to assist the Election Commission. The conditions of service and tenure are determined by the President by rule, subject to Parliamentary law. The CEC can only be removed in the manner and on the grounds as a Supreme Court Judge. Other ECs or Regional Commissioners can only be removed on the recommendation of the CEC. The President or Governor of a State shall make necessary staff available to the Election Commission upon request.

sub_sections.text: Election authority: Superintendence, direction, and control of elections (Parliament, State Legislatures, President, Vice-President) vested in the Election Commission.
Composition: Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) and other Election Commissioners (ECs) appointed by the President.
CEC acts as Chairman when other ECs are appointed.
President may appoint Regional Commissioners to assist the EC.
CEC removal procedure (like a Supreme Court Judge); other ECs/Regional Commissioners removed only on CEC's recommendation.
President/Governor must make staff available to the EC upon request.

amendments_notes: Reference to appointment of election tribunals was omitted by the Constitution (Nineteenth Amendment) Act, 1966.

article_title: No person to be ineligible for inclusion in, or to claim to be included in a special, electoral roll on grounds of religion, race, caste or sex.
content: There shall be one general electoral roll for every territorial constituency for election to Parliament or a State Legislature, and no person shall be ineligible for inclusion in, or claim to be included in a special electoral roll for any such constituency on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex or any of them.

sub_sections.text: Mandate for a single general electoral roll; prohibition of discrimination based on religion, race, caste, or sex for inclusion.

article_title: Elections to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assemblies of States to be on the basis of adult suffrage.
content: Elections to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assembly of every State shall be on the basis of adult suffrage. Every citizen of India who is not less than eighteen years of age (on the fixed date) and is not otherwise disqualified (on grounds of non-residence, unsoundness of mind, crime or corrupt/illegal practice) shall be entitled to be registered as a voter.

sub_sections.text: Elections based on adult suffrage; voting age is not less than eighteen years; disqualification determined by appropriate Legislature law.

amendments_notes: Age limit reduced from twenty-one years to eighteen years by the Constitution (Sixty-first Amendment) Act, 1988.

article_title: Power of Parliament to make provision with respect to elections to Legislatures.
content: Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Parliament may from time to time by law make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, elections to either House of Parliament or to a House of a State Legislature, including the preparation of electoral rolls, the delimitation of constituencies and all other necessary matters.

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to legislate on all election matters for both Union and State Legislatures.

article_title: Power of Legislature of a State to make provision with respect to elections to such Legislature.
content: Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and in so far as provision in that behalf is not made by Parliament, the Legislature of a State may from time to time by law make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, the elections to its House(s), including the preparation of electoral rolls and all other necessary matters.

sub_sections.text: State Legislature's residual power to legislate on election matters for its own Legislature, provided Parliament has not done so.

article_title: Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters.
content: The validity of any law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats (made under Art. 327 or 328) shall not be called in question in any court. No election to Parliament or a State Legislature shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as may be provided for by or under any law made by the appropriate Legislature.

sub_sections.text: Courts cannot question the validity of laws relating to delimitation or allotment of seats.
Elections can only be questioned by an election petition to the prescribed authority.

amendments_notes: Initial words amended by the Constitution (Thirty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1975, and the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978.

article_title: [Special provision as to elections to Parliament in the case of Prime Minister and Speaker.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Thirty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1975, and omitted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978.

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the House of the People.
content: Seats shall be reserved in the House of the People for the Scheduled Castes; the Scheduled Tribes except the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam; and the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam[cite: 1169].  The number of seats reserved for the SCs or STs in any State or Union territory shall be proportional to the ratio of their population to the total population of that State or Union territory[cite: 1169].  The number of seats reserved for STs in the autonomous districts of Assam must be proportional to their population in the State[cite: 1170].  'Population' means the last preceding published census figure, currently referring to the 2001 census until figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published[cite: 1170].

sub_sections.text: Reservation of seats for SCs and STs (including a specific clause for autonomous districts of Assam) in the House of the People[cite: 1169].
The number of reserved seats is determined by the proportion of the SC/ST population to the total population[cite: 1169].
The number of reserved seats for STs in the autonomous districts of Assam must be at least proportional to their population[cite: 1170].
Definition of 'population' (currently referring to the 2001 census until the census after 2026)[cite: 1170].

amendments_notes: Clause (1)(b) substituted by the Constitution (Fifty-first Amendment) Act, 1984[cite: 1169].  Clause (3) and the Explanation inserted by later amendments[cite: 1170].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Reservation of seats for women in the House of the People.
content: Seats shall be reserved for women in the House of the People[cite: 1170].  As nearly as may be, one-third of the total number of seats reserved for SCs and STs (under Article 330(2)) shall be reserved for women belonging to those groups[cite: 1170].  As nearly as may be, one-third (including the SC/ST women's seats) of the total seats filled by direct election to the House of the People shall be reserved for women[cite: 1170].

sub_sections.text: Seats reserved for women in the House of the People[cite: 1170].
One-third reservation for SC/ST women within the SC/ST quota[cite: 1170].
One-third reservation for women in total direct election seats[cite: 1170].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Sixth Amendment) Act, 2023[cite: 1170].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Representation of the Anglo-Indian Community in the House of the People.
content: Notwithstanding anything in Article 81, the President may, if he is of opinion that the Anglo-Indian community is not adequately represented in the House of the People, nominate not more than two members of that community to the House of the People[cite: 1170].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assemblies of the States.
content: Seats shall be reserved for the SCs and STs (excluding STs in the autonomous districts of Assam) in the Legislative Assembly (LA) of every State[cite: 1170, 1171].  Seats are also reserved for the autonomous districts in the LA of Assam[cite: 1171].  The number of reserved seats is proportional to the ratio of the SC/ST population to the total population of the State[cite: 1171].  Special provisions regarding seat reservation for STs are in place for Arunachal Pradesh, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, and Tripura until the census after 2026 takes effect[cite: 1171, 1172]. The constituencies for the seats reserved for any autonomous district of Assam shall not comprise any area outside that district.  Generally, no person who is not an ST member of any autonomous district of Assam is eligible for election from a constituency of that district, with a proviso for maintaining representation in the Bodoland Territorial Areas District[cite: 1172].

sub_sections.text: Reservation of seats for SCs and STs in State Legislative Assemblies[cite: 1170, 1171].
Seats reserved for autonomous districts in the LA of Assam[cite: 1171].
The number of reserved seats is proportional to the SC/ST population[cite: 1171].
Special provisions regarding reservation percentages for STs in specific North-Eastern States[cite: 1171].
Reserved constituencies in Assam's autonomous districts exclude outside areas[cite: 1172].
General ineligibility for non-STs from autonomous districts of Assam to contest reserved seats, with an exception for the Bodoland Territorial Areas District[cite: 1172].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) amended by the Constitution (Fifty-first Amendment) Act, 1984[cite: 1171].  Clauses (3A) and (3B) inserted by the 57th and 72nd Amendments, respectively[cite: 1171].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Reservation of seats for women in the Legislative Assemblies of the States.
content: Seats shall be reserved for women in the Legislative Assembly of every State[cite: 1172].  As nearly as may be, one-third of the total number of seats reserved for SCs and STs (under Article 332(3)) shall be reserved for women belonging to those groups[cite: 1172].  As nearly as may be, one-third (including the SC/ST women's seats) of the total seats filled by direct election in the LA of every State shall be reserved for women[cite: 1172].

sub_sections.text: Seats reserved for women in the Legislative Assemblies of States[cite: 1172].
One-third reservation for SC/ST women within the SC/ST quota[cite: 1172].
One-third reservation for women in total direct election seats[cite: 1172].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Sixth Amendment) Act, 2023[cite: 1172].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Representation of the Anglo-Indian community in the Legislative Assemblies of the States.
content: Notwithstanding anything in Article 170, the Governor of a State may, if he is of opinion that the Anglo-Indian community needs representation and is not adequately represented in the Legislative Assembly of the State, nominate one member of that community to the Assembly[cite: 1172].
amendments_notes: Provision for 'one member' substituted for 'such number of members as he considers appropriate' by the Constitution (Twenty-third Amendment) Act, 1969[cite: 1172].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Reservation of seats and special representation to cease after certain period.
content: The provisions relating to the reservation of seats for SCs and STs in the House of the People and State LAs, and the representation of the Anglo-Indian community by nomination, shall cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of eighty years in respect of clause (a) and seventy years in respect of clause (b) from the commencement of the Constitution[cite: 1173].  This does not affect any representation in the existing House or Assembly until its dissolution[cite: 1173].

sub_sections.text: SC/ST seat reservation ceases after eighty years from commencement[cite: 1173].
Anglo-Indian nomination ceases after seventy years from commencement[cite: 1173].

amendments_notes: The periods were extended multiple times.  The current periods (80 years for (a) and 70 years for (b)) were set by the Constitution (One hundred and fourth Amendment) Act, 2019[cite: 1173].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Reservation of seats for women take effect.
content: The reservation of seats for women (under Arts. 239AA, 330A, and 332A) shall come into effect after a delimitation exercise is undertaken for this purpose after the relevant figures for the first census taken after the commencement of the Constitution (One Hundred and Sixth Amendment) Act, 2023 have been published[cite: 1173].  This reservation shall cease on the expiration of a period of fifteen years from such commencement[cite: 1173].  Seats reserved for women shall continue until Parliament determines otherwise by law[cite: 1173].  Rotation of seats reserved for women shall take effect after each subsequent delimitation exercise as Parliament may determine by law[cite: 1173].  This article does not affect any representation in the then existing House/Assembly until its dissolution[cite: 1173].

sub_sections.text: Women's reservation takes effect after delimitation based on the first census after the 106th Amendment (2023), and ceases after fifteen years from such commencement[cite: 1173].
Reserved seats for women shall continue until Parliament provides by law[cite: 1173].
Rotation of reserved seats takes effect after each subsequent delimitation[cite: 1173].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Sixth Amendment) Act, 2023[cite: 1173].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Claims of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes to services and posts.
content: The claims of the members of the SCs and STs shall be taken into consideration, consistently with the maintenance of efficiency of administration, in making appointments to services and posts under the Union or a State[cite: 1173].  Nothing in this article prevents the making of any provision in favour of SCs and STs for relaxation in qualifying marks or lowering the standards of evaluation, for reservation in matters of promotion to any class or classes of services or posts[cite: 1174].

sub_sections.text: SC/ST claims considered consistently with administrative efficiency for appointments[cite: 1173].
The proviso allows relaxation in marks or lowering of evaluation standards for SC/ST in appointments/promotions[cite: 1174].

amendments_notes: Proviso inserted by the Constitution (Eighty-second Amendment) Act, 2000[cite: 1174].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Special provision for Anglo-Indian community in certain services.
content: During the first two years after the commencement of the Constitution, appointments of Anglo-Indian community members to posts in the railway, customs, postal, and telegraph services were made on the pre-Constitution basis. During every succeeding period of two years, the number of reserved posts was to be reduced by ten per cent. All such reservations were to cease at the end of ten years from commencement.  This article does not bar the appointment of Anglo-Indians to other posts if qualified on merit[cite: 1174].

sub_sections.text: Gradual reduction and cessation of reservations for Anglo-Indians in certain services over ten years from commencement[cite: 1174].
Anglo-Indians can be appointed to other posts based on merit[cite: 1174].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Special provision with respect to educational grants for the benefit of Anglo-Indian community.
content: During the first three financial years after commencement, the Union and each State made the same educational grants for the Anglo-Indian community as in the financial year ending March 31, 1948[cite: 1174].  During every succeeding period of three years, the grants were to be reduced by ten per cent[cite: 1174].  Such grants, to the extent they are a special concession, ceased at the end of ten years from commencement[cite: 1174].  No educational institution is entitled to receive grants under this article unless at least forty per cent. of the annual admissions are made available to members of other communities[cite: 1174].

sub_sections.text: Gradual reduction and cessation of special educational grants for the Anglo-Indian community over ten years[cite: 1174].
Condition for receiving grants: at least 40% of admissions must be open to other communities[cite: 1174].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: National Commission for Scheduled Castes.
content: There shall be a National Commission for the Scheduled Castes (NCSC)[cite: 1175].  The Commission consists of a Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members, whose conditions of service and tenure are determined by the President by rule[cite: 1175].  It shall be the NCSC's duty to: investigate and monitor safeguards for SCs; inquire into specific complaints; participate in and advise on the socio-economic development planning of SCs; present annual and other reports to the President; make recommendations; and discharge other functions specified by the President[cite: 1175, 1176].  The President causes reports to be laid before Parliament (with action taken)[cite: 1176].  Reports concerning a State are forwarded to the Governor and laid before the State Legislature[cite: 1176].  The Commission has the powers of a civil court for investigation/inquiry (e.g., summoning persons, production of documents)[cite: 1176].  The Union and State Governments must consult the Commission on all major policy matters affecting SCs[cite: 1176].  References to SCs include the Anglo-Indian community[cite: 1176].

sub_sections.text: Establishment of the National Commission for Scheduled Castes (NCSC)[cite: 1175].
Duties of the NCSC (investigation, monitoring, advising, reporting)[cite: 1175].
NCSC has the powers of a civil court for inquiries[cite: 1176].
Governments must consult the NCSC on major policy matters[cite: 1176].

amendments_notes: Article 338 substituted by the 65th Amendment, 1990. Clauses (1), (2), (5), (6), (7), (8), and (9) were substituted by the 89th Amendment, 2003, removing the Scheduled Tribes from this article[cite: 1175, 1176].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: National Commission for Scheduled Tribes.
content: There shall be a National Commission for the Scheduled Tribes (NCST)[cite: 1176].  The Commission consists of a Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members, whose conditions of service and tenure are determined by the President by rule[cite: 1177].  It shall be the NCST's duty to: investigate and monitor safeguards for STs; inquire into specific complaints; participate in and advise on the socio-economic development planning of STs; present annual and other reports to the President; make recommendations; and discharge other functions specified by the President[cite: 1177].  The President causes reports to be laid before Parliament (with action taken)[cite: 1177].  Reports concerning a State are forwarded to the Governor and laid before the State Legislature[cite: 1177].  The Commission has the powers of a civil court for investigation/inquiry[cite: 1178].  The Union and State Governments must consult the Commission on all major policy matters affecting STs[cite: 1178].

sub_sections.text: Establishment of the National Commission for Scheduled Tribes (NCST)[cite: 1176].
Duties of the NCST (investigation, monitoring, advising, reporting)[cite: 1177].
NCST has the powers of a civil court for inquiries[cite: 1178].
Governments must consult the NCST on major policy matters[cite: 1178].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Eighty-ninth Amendment) Act, 2003[cite: 1176].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: National Commission for Backward Classes.
content: There shall be a National Commission for Backward Classes (NCBC)[cite: 1178].  The Commission consists of a Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members, whose conditions of service and tenure are determined by the President by rule[cite: 1178].  The NCBC's duty is to: investigate and monitor safeguards for socially and educationally backward classes (SEBCs); inquire into specific complaints; participate in and advise on the socio-economic development of SEBCs; present annual and other reports to the President; make recommendations; and discharge other functions specified by the President[cite: 1179].  The President causes reports to be laid before Parliament, and reports concerning a State are forwarded to the Governor and laid before the State Legislature[cite: 1179].  The Commission has the powers of a civil court for investigation/inquiry[cite: 1179].  The Union and State Governments must consult the Commission on all major policy matters affecting SEBCs[cite: 1179].  This clause does not apply for the purposes of Article 342A(3)[cite: 1180].

sub_sections.text: Establishment of the National Commission for Backward Classes (NCBC)[cite: 1178].
Duties of the NCBC (investigation, monitoring, advising, reporting on SEBCs)[cite: 1179].
NCBC has the powers of a civil court for inquiries[cite: 1179].
Governments must consult the NCBC on major policy matters affecting SEBCs[cite: 1179].
Consultation clause does not apply for purposes of Article 342A(3)[cite: 1180].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Second Amendment) Act, 2018[cite: 1178].  Proviso to clause (9) inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Fifth Amendment) Act, 2021[cite: 1180].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Control of the Union over the administration of Scheduled Areas and the welfare of Scheduled Tribes.
content: The President may at any time, and shall at the expiration of ten years from the commencement of the Constitution, appoint a Commission to report on the administration of the Scheduled Areas and the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes in the States[cite: 1180].  The Union's executive power extends to giving directions to a State regarding the drawing up and execution of schemes essential for the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes in the State[cite: 1180].

sub_sections.text: President's power to appoint a Commission to report on Scheduled Area administration and ST welfare[cite: 1180].
Union's executive power extends to giving directions to States for ST welfare schemes[cite: 1180].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Appointment of a Commission to investigate the conditions of backward classes.
content: The President may by order appoint a Commission to investigate the conditions of socially and educationally backward classes (SEBCs) in India and the difficulties they face, making recommendations on steps to be taken by the Union/States and grants to be made[cite: 1180].  The Commission shall report to the President, who shall cause a copy of the report and an explanatory memorandum of action taken to be laid before each House of Parliament[cite: 1180, 1181].

sub_sections.text: President's power to appoint a Commission to investigate the conditions of SEBCs[cite: 1180].
President causes the report and action taken memorandum to be laid before Parliament[cite: 1181].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Scheduled Castes.
content: The President may, with respect to any State or Union territory, and after consultation with the Governor (if it is a State), by public notification, specify the castes, races or tribes, or groups within them, which shall be deemed to be Scheduled Castes in relation to that State or Union territory[cite: 1181].  Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of SCs specified in the notification, but save as aforesaid, the notification cannot be varied by any subsequent notification[cite: 1181].

sub_sections.text: President specifies the list of Scheduled Castes (SC) by public notification (after consultation with the Governor in case of a State)[cite: 1181].
Parliament may modify the SC list by law; otherwise, the initial notification cannot be varied[cite: 1181].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) amended by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951[cite: 1181].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Scheduled Tribes.
content: The President may, with respect to any State or Union territory, and after consultation with the Governor (if it is a State), by public notification, specify the tribes or tribal communities, or parts of or groups within them, which shall be deemed to be Scheduled Tribes in relation to that State or Union territory[cite: 1181].  Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of STs specified in the notification, but save as aforesaid, the notification cannot be varied by any subsequent notification[cite: 1181].

sub_sections.text: President specifies the list of Scheduled Tribes (ST) by public notification (after consultation with the Governor in case of a State)[cite: 1181].
Parliament may modify the ST list by law; otherwise, the initial notification cannot be varied[cite: 1181].

amendments_notes: Clause (1) amended by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951[cite: 1181].

part_title: SPECIAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO CERTAIN CLASSES
article_title: Socially and educationally backward classes.
content: The President may, with respect to any State or Union territory, and after consultation with the Governor (if it is a State), by public notification, specify the socially and educationally backward classes (SEBCs) in the Central List which shall for the purposes of the Central Government be deemed to be SEBCs in relation to that State or Union territory[cite: 1182].  Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the Central List of SEBCs, but save as aforesaid, the notification cannot be varied by any subsequent notification[cite: 1182].  The 'Central List' is defined as the list prepared and maintained by and for the Central Government[cite: 1182].  Every State or Union territory may, by law, prepare and maintain, for its own purposes, a list of SEBCs, entries in which may be different from the Central List[cite: 1182].

sub_sections.text: President specifies the Central List of SEBCs by public notification (after consultation with the Governor in case of a State) for the purposes of the Central Government[cite: 1182].
Parliament may modify the Central List by law; otherwise, the initial notification cannot be varied[cite: 1182].
Definition of 'Central List'[cite: 1182].
States/UTs may, by law, prepare and maintain their own separate list of SEBCs[cite: 1182].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Second Amendment) Act, 2018. Clause (1) and (2) and a new Clause (3) and Explanation were subsequently substituted/inserted by the Constitution (One Hundred and Fifth Amendment) Act, 2021[cite: 1182].

article_title: Official language of the Union.
content: The official language of the Union shall be Hindi in Devanagari script. The form of numerals to be used for official purposes shall be the international form of Indian numerals. Notwithstanding this, for a period of fifteen years from the commencement of the Constitution, the English language shall continue to be used for all official purposes. The President may, during this period, authorize the use of the Hindi language in addition to English and the Devanagari form of numerals in addition to the international form. Notwithstanding anything in this article, Parliament may by law provide for the use, after the said period of fifteen years, of the English language or the Devanagari form of numerals for such purposes as may be specified.

sub_sections.text: Official language is Hindi in Devanagari script; numerals are the international form of Indian numerals.
English language continues to be used for all official purposes for fifteen years from commencement.
Parliament may, by law, provide for the continued use of English or Devanagari numerals after the fifteen-year period.

article_title: Commission and Committee of Parliament on official language.
content: The President shall constitute a Commission on official language at the expiration of five years and ten years from commencement. The Commission consists of a Chairman and other members representing the different languages specified in the Eighth Schedule. The Commission recommends to the President on: the progressive use of Hindi; restrictions on the use of English; language for purposes mentioned in Article 348 (SC/HC/Bills); form of numerals; and language for Union-State communication. The Commission must consider India's industrial, cultural, and scientific advancement, and the interests of non-Hindi speaking areas regarding public services. A Committee is constituted, consisting of thirty members (20 from the House of the People, 10 from the Council of States) elected by proportional representation. The Committee examines the Commission's recommendations and reports its opinion to the President. The President may issue directions based on the whole or any part of the Committee's report.

sub_sections.text: President constitutes the Official Language Commission (OLC) after 5 and 10 years of commencement (members represent Eighth Schedule languages).
OLC duties: recommendations on progressive use of Hindi, restriction of English, language for legal texts (Art. 348), and numerals.
OLC must regard cultural/scientific advancement and interests of non-Hindi speakers.
Constitution of the Committee of Parliament (30 members) on official language.
President issues directions after considering the Committee's report.

article_title: Official language or languages of a State.
content: Subject to Articles 346 and 347, the Legislature of a State may by law adopt any one or more of the languages in use in the State or Hindi as the language(s) to be used for all or any of the official purposes of that State. Until the Legislature otherwise provides by law, the English language shall continue to be used for those official purposes for which it was being used immediately before the commencement of this Constitution.

sub_sections.text: State Legislature may adopt any regional language or Hindi as the official language(s).
English continues to be used until the Legislature provides otherwise.

article_title: Official language for communication between one State and another or between a State and the Union.
content: The language authorized for use in the Union for official purposes shall be the official language for communication between one State and another State and between a State and the Union. However, if two or more States agree that the Hindi language should be the official language for communication between such States, that language may be used for such communication.

sub_sections.text: Union's official language is the language for inter-State and Union-State communication.
Two or more States may agree to use Hindi for communication between themselves.

article_title: Special provision relating to language spoken by a section of the population of a State.
content: On demand, if the President is satisfied that a substantial proportion of the population of a State desires the use of any language spoken by them to be officially recognized by that State, he may direct that such language shall also be officially recognized throughout that State or any part thereof for such purpose as he may specify.

sub_sections.text: President's power to provide for the official recognition of a language spoken by a substantial section of a State's population.

article_title: Language to be used in the Supreme Court and in the High Courts and for Acts, Bills, etc.
content: Until Parliament by law otherwise provides: (a) all proceedings in the Supreme Court and in every High Court; (b) the authoritative texts of all Bills introduced in Parliament/State Legislatures, all Acts passed, all Ordinances promulgated, and all orders/rules/regulations/bye-laws issued under the Constitution or any law, shall be in the English language. Notwithstanding this, the Governor of a State may, with the previous consent of the President, authorize the use of Hindi or any other official language of the State in proceedings in the High Court having its principal seat in that State, but this authorization does not apply to judgments, decrees or orders. Where a State Legislature has prescribed a language other than English for use in Bills, Acts, Ordinances, or rules/regulations/bye-laws, an English translation published under the authority of the Governor in the Official Gazette shall be deemed to be the authoritative English text.

sub_sections.text: Mandate for English language use in: (a) proceedings in the SC and HCs; (b) authoritative texts of Bills, Acts, Ordinances, and rules/orders.
Governor may authorize the use of Hindi or State official language in HC proceedings (with President's consent), but not for judgments/decrees/orders.
English translation published by the Governor is the authoritative English text where a State Legislature uses another language for laws/rules.

article_title: Special procedure for enactment of certain laws relating to language.
content: During the period of fifteen years from the commencement of the Constitution, no Bill or amendment making provision for the language to be used for any of the purposes mentioned in Article 348(1) (SC/HC/Laws) shall be introduced or moved in either House of Parliament without the previous sanction of the President. The President shall not give his sanction except after considering the recommendations of the Official Language Commission and the report of the Committee of Parliament (Art. 344).

sub_sections.text: Special procedural restriction (President's prior sanction after OLC/Committee consultation) for language laws concerning Art. 348(1) during the first fifteen years.

article_title: Language to be used in representations for redress of grievances.
content: Every person shall be entitled to submit a representation for the redress of any grievance to any officer or authority of the Union or a State in any of the languages used in the Union or in the State, as the case may be.

article_title: Facilities for instruction in mother-tongue at primary stage.
content: It shall be the endeavour of every State and every local authority within the State to provide adequate facilities for instruction in the mother-tongue at the primary stage of education to children belonging to linguistic minority groups. The President may issue directions to any State for securing the provision of such facilities.

sub_sections.text: Endeavour of States/local authorities to provide instruction in mother-tongue at the primary stage for linguistic minorities.
President may issue directions to the State to secure this provision.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: Special Officer for linguistic minorities.
content: There shall be a Special Officer for linguistic minorities appointed by the President. The Special Officer's duty is to investigate all matters relating to the safeguards provided for linguistic minorities under the Constitution and report to the President upon those matters. The President shall cause all such reports to be laid before each House of Parliament and sent to the Governments of the States concerned.

sub_sections.text: Provision for a Special Officer for linguistic minorities appointed by the President.
Duty of the Special Officer to investigate safeguards and report to the President (reports laid before Parliament and sent to concerned States).

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: Directive for development of the Hindi language.
content: It shall be the duty of the Union to promote the spread of the Hindi language, to develop it so that it may serve as a medium of expression for all the elements of the composite culture of India and to secure its enrichment by assimilating, without interfering with its genius, the forms, style and expressions used in Hindustani and in the other languages of India specified in the Eighth Schedule, and by drawing, wherever necessary or desirable, for its vocabulary, primarily on Sanskrit and secondarily on other languages.

sub_sections.text: Union's duty to promote Hindi as a medium for India's composite culture, drawing vocabulary primarily from Sanskrit and secondarily from other languages.

article_title: Proclamation of Emergency.
content: If the President is satisfied that a grave emergency exists whereby the security of India or any part thereof is threatened by war, external aggression, or armed rebellion, he may, by Proclamation, make a declaration to that effect (for the whole or specified part of India)[cite: 1188].  A Proclamation can be made before the actual occurrence of war, aggression, or rebellion if there is imminent danger thereof[cite: 1188].  The President shall not issue a Proclamation (or variation) unless the decision of the Union Cabinet has been communicated to him in writing[cite: 1188].  Every Proclamation must be laid before each House of Parliament and ceases to operate after one month unless approved by resolutions of both Houses[cite: 1188].  An approved Proclamation ceases after six months unless continued by subsequent resolutions of both Houses[cite: 1189].  A resolution for approval or continuance requires a majority of the total membership of that House and a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting[cite: 1189].  The President must revoke the Proclamation if the House of the People passes a resolution disapproving it[cite: 1189].  The President has the power to issue different Proclamations on different grounds (war, aggression, armed rebellion, or imminent danger thereof)[cite: 1190].

sub_sections.text: President's power to proclaim an Emergency (based on war, external aggression, or armed rebellion) for the whole or part of India[cite: 1188].
Proclamation can be issued before actual occurrence, if danger is imminent[cite: 1188].
Proclamation requires a written decision of the Union Cabinet[cite: 1188].
Parliamentary approval required within one month (resolution by both Houses)[cite: 1188].
Duration of approved Proclamation is six months (extendable by resolutions)[cite: 1189].
Approval/continuance resolution requires a special majority (absolute majority + two-thirds present and voting)[cite: 1189].
Revocation is mandatory if the House of the People passes a disapproval resolution[cite: 1189].

amendments_notes: The basis for Emergency changed from 'internal disturbance' to 'armed rebellion' by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1188].  Clauses (2) to (8) were substituted or inserted by the 44th Amendment[cite: 1188, 1189].

article_title: Effect of Proclamation of Emergency.
content: While a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation: (a) the executive power of the Union extends to giving directions to any State as to the manner in which the State's executive power is to be exercised[cite: 1190]; (b)  Parliament's power to make laws extends to conferring powers and imposing duties on the Union or its authorities regarding any matter, even if it is not in the Union List[cite: 1190].  If the Proclamation is only in a part of India, the Union's executive and legislative powers under this article also extend to any other State if and in so far as the security of India is threatened by activities in the part under Proclamation[cite: 1191].

sub_sections.text: Union's executive power extends to giving directions to States[cite: 1190].
Parliament can legislate on State matters and confer powers on the Union, even outside the Union List[cite: 1190].
Extension of Union powers to States not under Proclamation if security is threatened by the area under Proclamation[cite: 1191].

amendments_notes: Proviso added by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 1191].

article_title: Application of provisions relating to distribution of revenues while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation.
content: While an Emergency Proclamation is in operation, the President may by order direct that all or any of the provisions of Articles 268 to 279 (relating to distribution of revenues) shall have effect subject to such exceptions or modifications as he thinks fit[cite: 1191].  Such an order cannot extend beyond the expiration of the financial year in which the Proclamation ceases to operate[cite: 1191].  Every order must be laid before each House of Parliament[cite: 1191].

sub_sections.text: President may modify provisions relating to the distribution of revenues (Arts. 268-279) during Emergency.
Order must be laid before Parliament.

article_title: Duty of the Union to protect States against external aggression and internal disturbance.
content: It shall be the duty of the Union to protect every State against external aggression and internal disturbance and to ensure that the Government of every State is carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution[cite: 1191].

article_title: Provisions in case of failure of constitutional machinery in States.
content: If the President, on receipt of a report from the Governor or otherwise, is satisfied that the Government of a State cannot be carried on in accordance with this Constitution, he may issue a Proclamation[cite: 1191].  The Proclamation may: (a) assume all or any of the functions of the State Government and powers of the Governor/other State authorities (excluding the Legislature and the High Court)[cite: 1192]; (b)  declare that the State Legislature's powers shall be exercisable by or under the authority of Parliament [cite: 1192] ; and (c) make incidental and consequential provisions, including suspending the operation of any constitutional provisions relating to any State body/authority[cite: 1192].  Every Proclamation must be laid before Parliament and ceases after two months unless approved by resolutions of both Houses[cite: 1192].  An approved Proclamation ceases after six months from its issue date unless continued by subsequent resolutions of both Houses, subject to a maximum duration of three years[cite: 1193].  Continuation beyond one year requires: (a) a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation in India or the State, AND (b) the Election Commission certifies that continuation is necessary due to difficulties in holding State general elections[cite: 1194].

sub_sections.text: President's power to issue a Proclamation based on failure of constitutional machinery (President's Rule)[cite: 1191].
Effects of the Proclamation, including assumption of State functions and transfer of legislative power to Parliament (excluding High Court powers)[cite: 1192].
Parliamentary approval required within two months[cite: 1192].
Duration is six months per approval, max three years in total[cite: 1193].
Conditions for continuing the Proclamation beyond one year (Emergency + EC certificate)[cite: 1194].

amendments_notes: Duration periods were modified by the 42nd Amendment, 1976, and the 44th Amendment, 1978. Clause (5) was substituted by the 44th Amendment[cite: 1194].

article_title: Exercise of legislative powers under Proclamation issued under article 356.
content: Where a Proclamation under Article 356 declares that the State Legislature's powers are exercisable by or under Parliament's authority: (a) Parliament may confer the power of the State Legislature to make laws on the President, and may authorize the President to delegate this power[cite: 1194]; (b)  Parliament or the President/other authority may make laws conferring powers and imposing duties on the Union/its authorities [cite: 1194] ; and (c) the President may authorize expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of the State when the House of the People is not in session, pending Parliament's sanction[cite: 1194].  Any law made in exercise of the State Legislature's power continues in force after the Proclamation ceases, until altered, repealed, or amended by a competent Legislature or authority[cite: 1195].

sub_sections.text: Consequences of legislative power transfer (Parliament/President/delegate can make laws; President can authorize expenditure)[cite: 1194].
Continuance of laws made under this article after the Proclamation ends[cite: 1195].

amendments_notes: Clause (2) substituted by the Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 1195].

article_title: Suspension of provisions of article 19 during emergencies.
content: While a Proclamation of Emergency (based on war or external aggression) is in operation, nothing in Article 19 (freedoms) restricts the power of the State (as defined in Part III) to make any law or take any executive action. Any law so made ceases to have effect when the Proclamation ceases to operate, except regarding actions taken before that period. If the Proclamation is in operation only in a part of India, this power extends to other States/UTs if the security of India is threatened by activities in the area under Proclamation.  This provision only applies to a law/executive action that explicitly contains a recital stating it is in relation to the Proclamation of Emergency[cite: 1195, 1196].

sub_sections.text: Suspension of Article 19 during an Emergency based on war or external aggression[cite: 1195].
Extension of effect to non-Proclaimed areas if security is threatened[cite: 1195].
Protection applies only to laws/actions containing an explicit recital of connection to the Emergency[cite: 1196].

amendments_notes: Original text was renumbered as clause (1) and amended, and clause (2) was inserted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1195, 1196].

article_title: Suspension of the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part III during emergencies.
content: Where a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, the President may by order declare that the right to move any court for the enforcement of such Fundamental Rights (except Articles 20 and 21) as may be mentioned in the order shall remain suspended for the period the Proclamation is in force (or shorter period)[cite: 1196]. While such an order is in operation, nothing in Part III conferring those rights restricts the State's power to make laws or take executive action.  Laws so made cease to have effect when the order ceases, except regarding prior actions taken[cite: 1197].  This suspension and protection applies only to laws/actions containing an explicit recital of connection to the Emergency[cite: 1197].  The order may extend to the whole or any part of India, but to non-Proclaimed areas only if the President is satisfied that security is threatened by the area under Proclamation[cite: 1197].  Every order must be laid before each House of Parliament[cite: 1197].

sub_sections.text: President may suspend the right to move courts for enforcement of Fundamental Rights (except Arts. 20 and 21)[cite: 1196].
Suspension of enforcement prevents judicial challenges to State laws/executive action related to those rights[cite: 1197].
Protection applies only to laws/actions containing an explicit recital[cite: 1197].
Order applies to whole/part of India (with condition for extending to non-Proclaimed areas)[cite: 1197].

amendments_notes: The exception for Articles 20 and 21 was inserted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1196].  Clause (1B) inserted by the 44th Amendment[cite: 1197].

article_title: [Application of this Part to the State of Punjab.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1988, and omitted by the Constitution (Sixty-third Amendment) Act, 1989[cite: 1197].

article_title: Provisions as to financial emergency.
content: If the President is satisfied that a situation has arisen whereby the financial stability or credit of India or any part thereof is threatened, he may by a Proclamation make a declaration to that effect (Financial Emergency)[cite: 1197].  The Proclamation may be revoked or varied by a subsequent Proclamation[cite: 1197].  It ceases after two months unless approved by Parliament[cite: 1198].  During the operation of the Proclamation, the Union's executive authority extends to directing any State to observe specified canons of financial propriety and giving other necessary directions[cite: 1198].  These directions may include a provision requiring the reduction of salaries/allowances of all/any class of State employees, and reserving all Money Bills/Financial Bills for the President's consideration[cite: 1198].  The President may also issue directions for the reduction of salaries and allowances of all/any class of Union employees, including the Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts[cite: 1198].

sub_sections.text: President's power to proclaim a Financial Emergency if financial stability/credit is threatened[cite: 1197].
Proclamation is revocable/variable and requires Parliamentary approval within two months[cite: 1198].
Union's executive authority extends to directing States to observe financial propriety[cite: 1198].
Union directions may require reduction of State salaries and reservation of State Money Bills/Financial Bills for President's consideration[cite: 1198].
President may direct reduction of salaries for Union employees, including Judges[cite: 1198].

amendments_notes: Clause (2) substituted and Clause (5) omitted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1197, 1198].

article_title: Protection of President and Governors and Rajpramukhs.
content: The President, or the Governor or Rajpramukh of a State, shall not be answerable to any court for the exercise and performance of the powers and duties of his office or for any act done or purporting to be done by him in the exercise and performance of those powers and duties[cite: 1199].  However, the conduct of the President may be brought under review by any court, tribunal or body appointed or designated by either House of Parliament for the investigation of a charge under article 61[cite: 1199].  Also, nothing restricts the right of any person to bring appropriate proceedings against the Government of India or a State Government[cite: 1199].  No criminal proceedings shall be instituted or continued against the President, or the Governor of a State, in any court during his term of office[cite: 1199].  No process for the arrest or imprisonment of the President, or the Governor of a State, shall issue from any court during his term of office[cite: 1199].  No civil proceedings shall be instituted against the President, or the Governor of a State, in any court regarding acts done by him in his personal capacity (before or after entering office) until the expiration of two months next after a written notice has been delivered to him[cite: 1199].

sub_sections.text: Immunity of the President/Governor/Rajpramukh from court answerability for official acts.
President's conduct reviewable for Article 61 impeachment charges[cite: 1199].
Right to bring proceedings against the Union/State Government is not restricted[cite: 1199].
Immunity from criminal proceedings during term of office[cite: 1199].
Immunity from arrest or imprisonment process during term of office[cite: 1199].
Requirement of two months' prior written notice for civil proceedings against the official in a personal capacity[cite: 1199].

amendments_notes: References to 'Rajpramukh' were omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1199].

article_title: Protection of publication of proceedings of Parliament and State Legislatures.
content: No person shall be liable to any proceedings (civil or criminal) in any court in respect of the publication in a newspaper of a substantially true report of any proceedings of either House of Parliament or a State Legislature, unless the publication is proved to have been made with malice[cite: 1200].  This protection does not apply to the publication of any report of the proceedings of a secret sitting[cite: 1200].  This clause also applies to reports or matters broadcast by wireless telegraphy[cite: 1200].  'Newspaper' includes a news agency report containing material for publication in a newspaper[cite: 1200].

sub_sections.text: Protection for publishing substantially true reports of proceedings (unless malice is proved)[cite: 1200].
Exclusion of reports of secret sittings from this protection[cite: 1200].
Protection extends to broadcasting by wireless telegraphy[cite: 1200].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978[cite: 1200].

article_title: Disqualification for appointment on remunerative political post.
content: A member of a House belonging to any political party who is disqualified for being a member of the House under paragraph 2 of the Tenth Schedule (defection) shall also be disqualified to hold any remunerative political post.  This disqualification lasts from the date of his disqualification until the expiration of his term of office or the date on which he is declared elected to a House, whichever is earlier[cite: 1200].  'Remunerative political post' means any office under the Government of India or a State, or under a body wholly or partially owned by the Government, where the salary/remuneration is paid out of public revenue or by such body (excluding compensatory salary/remuneration)[cite: 1201].

sub_sections.text: A member disqualified under the Tenth Schedule is also disqualified from holding a remunerative political post[cite: 1200].
Definition of 'remunerative political post'[cite: 1201].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-first Amendment) Act, 2003[cite: 1200].

article_title: [Rights and privileges of Rulers of Indian States.]
content: This article was omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971[cite: 1201].

article_title: Bar to interference by courts in disputes arising out of certain treaties, agreements, etc.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution (but subject to Article 143), neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall have jurisdiction in any dispute arising out of any provision of a pre-commencement treaty, agreement, covenant, engagement, sanad or other similar instrument entered into by any Ruler of an Indian State, or in any dispute regarding any right/liability arising out of Constitutional provisions relating to such instruments[cite: 1201].  'Indian State' and 'Ruler' are defined as they were recognized before the commencement of the Constitution[cite: 1201].

sub_sections.text: Bar on judicial interference (including SC) in disputes arising out of pre-commencement instruments with Rulers of Indian States[cite: 1201].
Definitions of 'Indian State' and 'Ruler'[cite: 1201].

article_title: Recognition granted to Rulers of Indian States to cease and privy purses to be abolished.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution or any law, on and from the commencement of the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971: (a) any person recognized as a Ruler of an Indian State or his successor shall cease to be so recognized; and (b) privy purse is abolished and all related rights, liabilities and obligations are extinguished, meaning the Rulers or their successors shall not be paid any sum as privy purse[cite: 1201, 1202].

sub_sections.text: Recognition of Rulers and their successors ceased from the date of the 26th Amendment Act, 1971[cite: 1201].
Privy purse is abolished, and related rights/liabilities are extinguished[cite: 1202].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971[cite: 1201].

article_title: Special provisions as to major ports and aerodromes.
content: The President may by public notification direct that: (a) any law made by Parliament or a State Legislature shall not apply to any major port or aerodrome, or shall apply subject to specified exceptions/modifications; or (b) any existing law shall cease to have effect in any major port or aerodrome (except as to past actions), or shall have effect subject to specified exceptions/modifications[cite: 1202].  'Major port' means a port declared to be a major port by law and includes all areas within its limits[cite: 1202].  'Aerodrome' means aerodrome as defined for the purposes of enactments relating to airways, aircraft, and air navigation[cite: 1202].

sub_sections.text: President's power to modify the application of new laws to major ports/aerodromes[cite: 1202].
President's power to modify the application of existing laws to major ports/aerodromes[cite: 1202].
Definitions of 'major port' and 'aerodrome'[cite: 1202].

article_title: Effect of failure to comply with, or to give effect to, directions given by the Union.
content: Where any State has failed to comply with, or to give effect to, any directions given by the Union in the exercise of its executive power under any of the provisions of this Constitution, it shall be lawful for the President to hold that a situation has arisen in which the Government of the State cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution (triggering Art. 356, President's Rule)[cite: 1202].

sub_sections.text: Failure of a State to comply with Union directions justifies the President invoking failure of constitutional machinery (Art. 356)[cite: 1202].

article_title: Definitions.
content: This article provides definitions for terms used throughout the Constitution, including: 'agricultural income', 'Anglo-Indian' [cite: 1203] , 'article', 'borrow'/'loan', 'clause', 'corporation tax', 'debt'/'debt charges', 'estate duty', 'existing law' [cite: 1204] , 'Federal Court', 'goods' [cite: 1204] , 'goods and services tax' (GST) [cite: 1204] , 'guarantee', 'High Court', 'Indian State', 'Part', 'pension', 'Proclamation of Emergency', 'public notification', 'railway', 'Ruler' (as recognized before the 26th Amendment) [cite: 1205] , 'Schedule', 'Scheduled Castes' (Art. 341) [cite: 1205] , 'Scheduled Tribes' (Art. 342) [cite: 1205] , 'securities', 'Services', 'State' (for GST Articles) [cite: 1206] , 'socially and educationally backward classes' (SEBCs) [cite: 1206] , 'sub-clause', 'taxation'/'tax', 'tax on income', 'tax on the sale or purchase of goods' (including transfer of property/goods in works contract/hire-purchase/transfer of right to use/supply by unincorporated associations/supply of food/drink) [cite: 1207] , and 'Union territory'[cite: 1207].

sub_sections.text: Definition of 'an Anglo-Indian'[cite: 1203].
Definition of 'corporation tax'.
Definition of 'goods and services tax' (GST)[cite: 1204].
Definition of 'Ruler'[cite: 1205].
Definition of 'tax on the sale or purchase of goods' (expanded to include various transfers/supplies)[cite: 1206, 1207].

amendments_notes: Multiple clauses inserted, substituted, or omitted by various amendments (e.g., 7th, 26th, 40th, 42nd, 43rd, 46th, 101st, 102nd, 105th Amendments)[cite: 1204, 1205, 1206, 1207].

article_title: Interpretation.
content: Unless the context requires otherwise, the General Clauses Act, 1897, applies for the interpretation of this Constitution (subject to adaptations under Article 372)[cite: 1207].  References to Acts/laws of Parliament or a State Legislature include references to Ordinances made by the President or a Governor[cite: 1207].  'Foreign State' means any State other than India, but the President may declare any State not to be a foreign State for specified purposes[cite: 1207].

sub_sections.text: Application of the General Clauses Act, 1897, for interpretation[cite: 1207].
Acts/laws include Ordinances of the President/Governor[cite: 1207].
Definition of 'foreign State' (President can declare a State not to be a foreign State)[cite: 1207].

amendments_notes: References to 'Rajpramukh' were omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1207].  Clause (4) was added by the Constitution (Application to Jammu and Kashmir) Order, 2019[cite: 1207].

article_title: Power of Parliament to amend the Constitution and procedure therefor.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may in exercise of its constituent power amend by way of addition, variation or repeal any provision of this Constitution in accordance with the procedure laid down in this article[cite: 1208]. An amendment may be initiated only by introducing a Bill in either House of Parliament[cite: 1208]. The Bill must be passed in each House by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members of that House present and voting[cite: 1208]. It shall then be presented to the President who shall give his assent to the Bill, and thereupon the Constitution shall stand amended[cite: 1208]. If the amendment seeks to change specific entrenched provisions (like election of President, extent of Union/State executive power, the Lists in the Seventh Schedule, representation of States in Parliament, or the provisions of Article 368 itself), the amendment also requires ratification by the Legislatures of not less than one-half of the States by resolutions to that effect[cite: 1208]. Nothing in Article 13 (Fundamental Rights) shall apply to any amendment made under this article[cite: 1209]. For the removal of doubts, it is declared that there shall be no limitation whatever on the constituent power of Parliament to amend the provisions of this Constitution under this article[cite: 1209].

sub_sections.text: Parliament has constituent power to amend (add, vary, or repeal) any provision[cite: 1208].
Procedure for amendment: Bill initiation; passage by special majority (absolute majority + two-thirds present and voting); and Presidential assent[cite: 1208].
Requirement for ratification by at least half of State Legislatures for changes to entrenched provisions[cite: 1209].
Article 13 does not apply to amendments made under this article[cite: 1209].
Declaration that there is no limitation on the constituent power of Parliament to amend the Constitution[cite: 1209].

amendments_notes: The marginal heading was substituted by the Constitution (Twenty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1971[cite: 1208]. Clauses (1) and (3) inserted by the 24th Amendment, 1971[cite: 1208, 1209]. Clauses (4) and (5) inserted by the 42nd Amendment, 1976 (Clause 4 and 5 were subsequently declared invalid by the Supreme Court in the Minerva Mills case, 1980)[cite: 1209]. Clause 2(a) was substituted by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016 to include a reference to Article 279A (GST Council)[cite: 1208].

article_title: Temporary power to Parliament to make laws with respect to certain matters in the State List as if they were matters in the Concurrent List.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament had the temporary power, during a period of five years from the commencement of this Constitution, to make laws with respect to: (a) trade and commerce within a State in, and the production, supply and distribution of, certain essential commodities (like cotton textiles, food-stuffs, coal, iron, steel, and mica); and (b) offences against laws with respect to these matters, jurisdiction of courts (except the Supreme Court), and fees. Any law made by Parliament under this power ceased to have effect on the expiration of the said five-year period, except regarding actions taken before that period.

sub_sections.text: Temporary five-year power for Parliament to legislate on certain matters (listed in (a)) in the State List as if they were in the Concurrent List.
Laws made under this power lapsed after the five-year period, except for prior actions.

amendments_notes: Part heading substituted by the Constitution (Thirteenth Amendment) Act, 1962.

article_title: Temporary provisions with respect to the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
content: This Article originally provided that the provisions of Article 238 would not apply to Jammu and Kashmir (J&K). Parliament's power to make laws for J&K was limited to: (i) Union/Concurrent List matters corresponding to the Instrument of Accession (in consultation with the State Government); and (ii) such other matters in the Lists (with the concurrence of the State Government). Only Article 1 and Article 370 applied to J&K. Other Constitutional provisions applied subject to exceptions/modifications specified by the President (with consultation/concurrence). The President could, by public notification, declare this Article to cease to be operative or operate with exceptions/modifications, provided the recommendation of the Constituent Assembly of the State (now Legislative Assembly) was necessary. **Note:** In August 2019, the President declared all clauses of Article 370 inoperative, except a single modified clause stating that all provisions of the Constitution, as amended from time to time, without any modifications or exceptions, shall apply to the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

sub_sections.text: Original limitation on Parliament's legislative power over J&K (to matters in the Instrument of Accession or other matters with concurrence).
Original provision for application of the Constitution (only Art. 1 and Art. 370 automatically applied).
President's power to declare the article inoperative (required recommendation of the State Assembly).

amendments_notes: The article's operative text was fundamentally changed by C.O. 273 (August 2019), rendering most of the original clauses inoperative and applying the entire Constitution to the region.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the States of Maharashtra and Gujarat.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may by order provide for any special responsibility of the Governor for: (a) the establishment of separate development boards for Vidarbha, Marathwada, and the rest of Maharashtra, and Saurashtra, Kutch and the rest of Gujarat (with an annual report to the State Legislative Assembly); (b) the equitable allocation of funds for developmental expenditure over these areas; and (c) an equitable arrangement providing adequate facilities for technical education, vocational training, and adequate opportunities for employment in services under the State Government in respect of all the said areas.

sub_sections.text: Special responsibility for establishing separate development boards in specified regions of Maharashtra and Gujarat.
Special responsibility for equitable allocation of developmental funds.
Special responsibility for equitable arrangement for technical education and employment opportunities.

amendments_notes: Article 371 substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956. Clause (1) (relating to Andhra Pradesh) omitted by the 32nd Amendment, 1973. The Bombay Reorganisation Act, 1960, applied the remaining provisions to Maharashtra and Gujarat.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the State of Nagaland.
content: No Act of Parliament regarding: (i) religious/social practices of the Nagas; (ii) Naga customary law/procedure; (iii) administration of civil/criminal justice involving Naga customary law; or (iv) ownership and transfer of land/resources, shall apply to the State of Nagaland unless the Legislative Assembly of Nagaland resolves to do so. The Governor has a special responsibility for law and order (for so long as internal disturbances continue, acting in his individual judgment after consulting the Council of Ministers). The Governor ensures equitable allocation of Union funds. A Regional Council for the Tuensang district (since dissolved) was mandated with the Governor holding final decision-making power in his discretion regarding Tuensang affairs. The article also included provisions for the composition of the Nagaland LA and transitional arrangements for the Tuensang district.

sub_sections.text: Parliamentary law on specific subjects (customary law, land ownership, etc.) requires Nagaland Assembly resolution to apply.
Governor's special responsibility for law and order (acting in individual judgment).
Governor ensures equitable allocation of Union funds.
Governor's final decision in discretion on all matters relating to the Tuensang district.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Thirteenth Amendment) Act, 1962.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the State of Assam.
content: The President may, by order, provide for the constitution and functions of a committee of the Legislative Assembly of Assam, consisting of members elected from the tribal areas (Sixth Schedule, Part I) and such other members as specified in the order, and for the modifications to be made in the rules of procedure of the Assembly for the constitution and proper functioning of such committee.

sub_sections.text: President's power to constitute a committee of the Legislative Assembly for Assam (for tribal areas).

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-second Amendment) Act, 1969.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the State of Manipur.
content: The President may, by order, provide for the constitution and functions of a committee of the Legislative Assembly of Manipur, consisting of members elected from the Hill Areas of that State, for modifications to the rules of business/procedure, and for any special responsibility of the Governor to secure the proper functioning of the committee. The Governor must report annually to the President regarding the administration of the Hill Areas, and the Union's executive power extends to giving directions to the State on that administration. 'Hill Areas' means areas declared as such by the President.
