sub_sections.text: President's power to constitute a committee of the Legislative Assembly for Manipur (for Hill Areas), and special responsibility of the Governor.
Governor reports annually to the President on Hill Areas administration (Union can give directions).

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Twenty-seventh Amendment) Act, 1971.

article_title: Special provisions with respect to the State of Andhra Pradesh or the State of Telangana.
content: The President may by order provide, having regard to the requirement of each State, for equitable opportunities and facilities for people belonging to different parts of Andhra Pradesh or Telangana in matters of public employment and education, with different provisions for various parts. The order may require the organization of posts into different local cadres; specify local areas for direct recruitment/admission to Universities/educational institutions; and specify the extent/conditions for preference/reservation in employment/admission for candidates from the local area. The President may also provide for the constitution of an Administrative Tribunal to exercise jurisdiction over service matters (appointment, seniority, conditions of service), superseding the jurisdiction of the High Court (except the Supreme Court). The Administrative Tribunal's order becomes effective upon State Government confirmation or after three months, though the State Government may modify or annul the order. Prior irregular appointments made in the region before the 32nd Amendment are validated. The provisions of this article prevail over any other constitutional provision/law.

sub_sections.text: President may provide for equitable opportunities in public employment and education in Andhra Pradesh/Telangana.
The order may specify: local cadres, local areas for recruitment/admission, and preference/reservation based on residence/study.
President may constitute an Administrative Tribunal for service matters (replacing HC jurisdiction).
High Court shall not have superintendence over the Administrative Tribunal.
This article prevails over other constitutional provisions/laws.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Thirty-second Amendment) Act, 1973. Amended by the Andhra Pradesh Reorganisation Act, 2014, to include Telangana. Clause (5) has been declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.

article_title: Establishment of Central University in Andhra Pradesh.
content: Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of a University in the State of Andhra Pradesh.
amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Thirty-second Amendment) Act, 1973.

article_title: Special provisions with respect to the State of Sikkim.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, special provisions are made for Sikkim: The LA consists of not less than thirty members. The existing Assembly and its members are deemed to be the LA. The LA's term (originally five years) was deemed to be four years from the appointed day (26-4-1975). Sikkim is allotted one seat in the House of the People. Parliament may make provisions for seat reservation and delimitation in the LA to protect the rights/interests of different sections of the population. The Governor has a special responsibility for peace and equitable arrangement for social/economic advancement, acting in his discretion subject to Presidential directions. All property/assets vested in the Government of Sikkim before the appointed day vest in the State Government. The existing High Court is deemed the HC for Sikkim. All existing laws/courts/authorities continue. The President may order adaptations/modifications of existing laws. The Supreme Court/other courts lack jurisdiction over disputes arising out of pre-accession treaties/agreements. The President may extend any enactment in force in a State in India to Sikkim. The President may remove difficulties by order (within two years from the appointed day). All prior acts/actions taken in relation to Sikkim are validated.

sub_sections.text: LA size: not less than thirty members.
LA duration: deemed to be four years from the appointed day (26-4-1975).
Parliament may provide for reservation/delimitation in the LA to protect different sections of the population.
Governor's special responsibility for peace and equitable advancement (acting in discretion).
Bar on judicial interference over pre-accession treaties/agreements.
President's power to remove difficulties (max two years).

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Thirty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1975.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the State of Mizoram.
content: No Act of Parliament regarding: (i) religious/social practices of the Mizos; (ii) Mizo customary law/procedure; (iii) administration of civil/criminal justice involving Mizo customary law; or (iv) ownership and transfer of land, shall apply to the State of Mizoram unless the Legislative Assembly resolves to apply it. This restriction does not apply to any Central Act in force in the Union territory of Mizoram immediately before the commencement of the 53rd Amendment Act, 1986. The Legislative Assembly shall consist of not less than forty members.

sub_sections.text: Parliamentary law on specific subjects (customary law, land ownership, etc.) requires Mizoram Assembly resolution to apply.
LA size: not less than forty members.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-third Amendment) Act, 1986.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the State of Arunachal Pradesh.
content: The Governor of Arunachal Pradesh shall have special responsibility with respect to law and order in the State, acting in his individual judgment after consulting the Council of Ministers. The President may direct that the Governor shall cease to have this responsibility if satisfied it is no longer necessary. The Legislative Assembly shall consist of not less than thirty members.

sub_sections.text: Governor's special responsibility for law and order (acting in individual judgment).
LA size: not less than thirty members.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-fifth Amendment) Act, 1986.

article_title: Special provision with respect to the State of Goa.
content: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Goa shall consist of not less than thirty members.

sub_sections.text: LA size: not less than thirty members.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1987.

article_title: Special provisions with respect to State of Karnataka.
content: The President may, by order, provide for any special responsibility of the Governor for: (a) the establishment of a separate development board for the Hyderabad-Karnataka region (with an annual report to the State Legislative Assembly); (b) equitable allocation of funds for developmental expenditure over the region; and (c) equitable opportunities and facilities for people belonging to the region in matters of public employment, education, and vocational training. An order may provide for: reservation of a proportion of seats in education/training institutions for students belonging to that region by birth/domicile; and identification of posts and reservation of a proportion of such posts in State Government/controlled bodies for persons belonging to that region.

sub_sections.text: Special responsibility for establishing a development board for Hyderabad-Karnataka region.
Special responsibility for equitable allocation of developmental funds.
Special responsibility for equitable opportunities in employment, education, and training.
Order may provide for reservation of seats in education/training and reservation of posts for the region.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-eighth Amendment) Act, 2012.

article_title: Continuance in force of existing laws and their adaptation.
content: Notwithstanding the repeal of certain enactments (Art. 395), all laws in force in India immediately before the commencement of the Constitution continue in force until altered, repealed, or amended by a competent Legislature/authority. The President may, for the purpose of bringing any existing law into accord with the Constitution, make adaptations and modifications (repeal or amendment), and the law shall have effect subject to these changes. The President's power to adapt laws ceased after three years from the commencement of the Constitution. 'Law in force' includes laws passed before commencement but not repealed, even if not in operation in all areas.

sub_sections.text: Continuation of existing laws.
President's power to adapt and modify existing laws to conform to the Constitution.
President's power to adapt ceased after three years from commencement.
Definition of 'law in force'.

amendments_notes: Clause (3)(a) period extended from two years to three years by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951.

article_title: Power of the President to adapt laws.
content: For the purpose of bringing any law in force in India immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, into accord with the Constitution as amended by that Act, the President may by order made before the first day of November, 1957, make adaptations and modifications (repeal or amendment). Such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court. This shall not prevent a competent Legislature/authority from subsequently repealing or amending any law adapted or modified by the President.

sub_sections.text: President's power to adapt laws to conform to the Seventh Amendment (deadline was November 1, 1957).
Legislature retains the power to repeal or amend adapted laws.

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: Power of President to make order in respect of persons under preventive detention in certain cases.
content: Until Parliament makes provision under Article 22(7) (preventive detention duration/procedure), or until the expiration of one year from the commencement of the Constitution (whichever is earlier), Article 22 has effect as if references to 'Parliament' were references to the 'President' and references to 'law made by Parliament' were references to an 'order made by the President'.

sub_sections.text: Temporary substitution of 'President' for 'Parliament' in Article 22 for preventive detention provisions (max one year from commencement).

article_title: Provisions as to Judges of the Federal Court and proceedings pending in the Federal Court or before His Majesty in Council.
content: Judges of the Federal Court become Judges of the Supreme Court at commencement (unless they elect otherwise), entitled to the salaries/rights under Article 125. All suits, appeals, and proceedings pending in the Federal Court are transferred to the Supreme Court. The exercise of jurisdiction by His Majesty in Council to dispose of appeals/petitions continues to be valid, and any order made by it after commencement has the effect of an SC order. The jurisdiction of the Privy Council authority in a Part B State ceases, and pending appeals/proceedings are transferred to the Supreme Court. Parliament may make further provision by law.

sub_sections.text: Federal Court Judges become Supreme Court Judges.
Pending Federal Court proceedings transferred to the Supreme Court.
Final orders of His Majesty in Council (Privy Council) made after commencement are treated as SC orders.
Jurisdiction of Part B State Privy Council authority ceases (pending appeals transferred to SC).

article_title: Courts, authorities and officers to continue to function subject to the provisions of the Constitution.
content: All courts of civil, criminal and revenue jurisdiction, all authorities and all officers (judicial, executive and ministerial) throughout the territory of India, shall continue to exercise their respective functions subject to the provisions of this Constitution.

sub_sections.text: Continuation of all existing courts, authorities, and officers, subject to the new Constitution.

article_title: Provisions as to Judges of High Courts.
content: Judges of a High Court in any Province become Judges of the High Court in the corresponding State at commencement (unless they elect otherwise), entitled to salaries/rights under Article 221. A non-citizen Judge is eligible for appointment as Chief Justice of such High Court or another High Court. Judges of a High Court in any Indian State (Part B State) become Judges of the High Court in the corresponding State and continue in office for a period determined by the President, subject to the age limit in Article 217(1). 'Judge' does not include an acting or additional Judge.

sub_sections.text: Judges of Provincial HCs become Judges of corresponding State HCs.
Non-citizen Judges are eligible for appointment as CJ or other Judge.
Judges of HCs in Indian States (Part B States) continue for a President-determined period.
'Judge' excludes acting or additional Judges.

amendments_notes: The provision regarding eligibility of non-citizen Judges was added by the Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951.

article_title: Provisions as to Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.
content: The Auditor-General of India becomes the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India at commencement (unless he elects otherwise), entitled to the salaries/rights under Article 148(3). He continues to hold office until the expiration of his term of office as determined by the provisions applicable to him immediately before commencement.

sub_sections.text: Auditor-General becomes the CAG of India, maintaining pre-Constitution terms of office, salary, and rights.

article_title: Provisions as to Public Service Commissions.
content: Members of the Public Service Commission for the Dominion of India become members of the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC). Members of a PSC of a Province or group of Provinces become members of the corresponding SPSC or JPSC. They continue to hold office until the expiration of their pre-Constitution term of office (notwithstanding Articles 316(1) and (2)).

sub_sections.text: Dominion PSC members become UPSC members.
Provincial PSC members become SPSC/JPSC members.
Members continue to hold office for their pre-Constitution term.

article_title: Special provision as to duration of Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly.
content: Notwithstanding anything in Article 172, the Legislative Assembly of Andhra Pradesh (as constituted under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956) continued for a period of five years from the date referred to in section 29 of that Act, and no longer, and the expiration of that period caused dissolution.

sub_sections.text: Special five-year duration for the initial Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly (post-1956 reorganisation).

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: [Provisions as to provisional Parliament, President, Ministers, and Legislatures.]
content: Articles 379 to 386, which contained temporary provisions regarding the Provisional Parliament, the Provisional President, the Council of Ministers, and Provisional Legislatures for the States, were omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: [Special provision as to determination of population, money matters, and President's power to amend Schedules.]
content: Articles 387 to 391, relating to temporary matters like population determination for elections, money/expenditure matters, and the President's power to amend the First and Fourth Schedules, were omitted.
amendments_notes: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.

article_title: Power of the President to remove difficulties.
content: The President may, for the purpose of removing any difficulties (particularly relating to the transition from the Government of India Act, 1935, to this Constitution), by order direct that this Constitution shall have effect subject to such adaptations, whether by way of modification, addition or omission, as he deems necessary or expedient. No such order shall be made after the first meeting of Parliament duly constituted. Every order made must be laid before Parliament. The powers conferred on the President by this article (and Arts. 324, 367(3), and 391) were exercisable by the Governor-General of the Dominion of India before the commencement of the Constitution.

sub_sections.text: President's power to remove transitional difficulties by adaptation/modification of the Constitution (Cessation: first meeting of Parliament).
Powers of the President under this and other articles were exercisable by the Governor-General before commencement.

part_title: SHORT TITLE, COMMENCEMENT, AUTHORITATIVE TEXT IN HINDI AND REPEALS
article_title: Short title.
content: This Constitution may be called the Constitution of India[cite: 1232].

part_title: SHORT TITLE, COMMENCEMENT, AUTHORITATIVE TEXT IN HINDI AND REPEALS
article_title: Commencement.
content: Article 394 and articles 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 60, 324, 366, 367, 379, 380, 388, 391, 392 and 393 came into force at once[cite: 1232].  The remaining provisions of this Constitution came into force on the twenty-sixth day of January, 1950, which day is referred to as the commencement of this Constitution[cite: 1232].

sub_sections.text: Specified articles came into force immediately[cite: 1232].
The remaining provisions came into force on 26th January, 1950[cite: 1232].

part_title: SHORT TITLE, COMMENCEMENT, AUTHORITATIVE TEXT IN HINDI AND REPEALS
article_title: Authoritative text in the Hindi language.
content: The President shall cause to be published under his authority the translation of this Constitution in the Hindi language, signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly, with necessary modifications to conform to the language, style, and terminology of authoritative Hindi texts of Central Acts, and incorporating all amendments made before such publication[cite: 1232].  The translation in Hindi of every amendment made in English shall also be published[cite: 1232].  The translation of the Constitution and its amendments published under this article shall be construed to have the same meaning as the original[cite: 1232].  If any difficulty arises in construction, the President shall cause it to be revised suitably[cite: 1232].  The translation published under this article shall be deemed to be the authoritative text thereof in the Hindi language for all purposes[cite: 1232].

sub_sections.text: President causes publication of the Hindi translation of the Constitution (signed by Constituent Assembly members, modified to match official Hindi legal terminology, and incorporating all prior amendments)[cite: 1232].
Hindi translation of every amendment made in English shall also be published[cite: 1232].
The Hindi translation is construed to have the same meaning as the original, with the President revising suitably if construction difficulties arise[cite: 1232].
The translation published under this article is deemed the authoritative text in the Hindi language[cite: 1232].

amendments_notes: Inserted by the Constitution (Fifty-eighth Amendment) Act, 1987.

part_title: SHORT TITLE, COMMENCEMENT, AUTHORITATIVE TEXT IN HINDI AND REPEALS
article_title: Repeals.
content: The Indian Independence Act, 1947, and the Government of India Act, 1935 (together with all enactments amending or supplementing the latter Act, but not including the Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949), are hereby repealed[cite: 1232].

sub_sections.text: Repeals the Indian Independence Act, 1947, and the Government of India Act, 1935 (and supplementary enactments), but not the Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949[cite: 1232].

part_title: FIRST SCHEDULE - The States and Union Territories
article_title: List of States and their Territories [cite: 1233]
content: This section lists the States of India and defines their respective territories by referencing the relevant original provinces and subsequent State Reorganisation and Alteration of Boundaries Acts up to the latest amendments. [cite: 1233, 1234, 1235, 1236, 1237, 1238, 1239, 1240]

sub_sections.name: Andhra Pradesh
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Andhra State Act, 1953, sub-section (1) of section 3 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, the First Schedule to the Andhra Pradesh and Madras (Alteration of Boundaries) Act, 1959, and the Schedule to the Andhra Pradesh and Mysore (Transfer of Territory) Act, 1968, but excluding the territories specified in the Second Schedule to the Andhra Pradesh and Madras (Alteration of Boundaries) Act, 1959 and the territories specified in section 3 of the Andhra Pradesh Reorganisation Act, 2014. [cite: 1233]

sub_sections.name: Assam
sub_sections.territories: The territories which immediately before the commencement of this Constitution were comprised in the Province of Assam, the Khasi States and the Assam Tribal Areas, but excluding the territories specified in the Schedule to the Assam (Alteration of Boundaries) Act, 1951, and the territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 3 of the State of Nagaland Act, 1962, and the territories specified in sections 5, 6 and 7 of the North-Eastern Areas (Reorganisation) Act, 1971, and the territories referred to in Part I of the Second Schedule to the Constitution (One Hundredth Amendment) Act, 2015, notwithstanding anything contained in clause (a) of section 3 of the Constitution (Ninth Amendment) Act, 1960, so far as it relates to the territories referred to in Part I of the Second Schedule to the Constitution (One Hundredth Amendment) Act, 2015. [cite: 1233, 1234]

sub_sections.name: Bihar
sub_sections.territories: The territories which immediately before the commencement of this Constitution were either comprised in the Province of Bihar or were being administered as if they formed part of that Province and the territories specified in clause (a) of sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Bihar and Uttar Pradesh (Alteration of Boundaries) Act, 1968, but excluding the territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Bihar and West Bengal (Transfer of Territories) Act, 1956, and the territories specified in clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 3 of the first mentioned Act and the territories specified in section 3 of the Bihar Reorganisation Act, 2000. [cite: 1234]

sub_sections.name: Gujarat
sub_sections.territories: The territories referred to in sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Bombay Reorganisation Act, 1960. [cite: 1234]

sub_sections.name: Kerala
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 5 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956. [cite: 1234]

sub_sections.name: Madhya Pradesh
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 9 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 and the First Schedule to the Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh (Transfer of Territories) Act, 1959, but excluding the territories specified in section 3 of the Madhya Pradesh Reorganisation Act, 2000. [cite: 1234]

sub_sections.name: Tamil Nadu
sub_sections.territories: The territories which immediately before the commencement of this Constitution were either comprised in the Province of Madras or were being administered as if they formed part of that Province and the territories specified in section 4 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and the Second Schedule to the Andhra Pradesh and Madras (Alteration of Boundaries) Act, 1959, but excluding the territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 3 and sub-section (1) of section 4 of the Andhra State Act, 1953 and the territories specified in clause (b) of sub-section (1) of section 5, section 6 and clause (d) of sub-section (1) of section 7 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 and the territories specified in the First Schedule to the Andhra Pradesh and Madras (Alteration of Boundaries) Act, 1959. [cite: 1235]

sub_sections.name: Maharashtra
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 8 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, but excluding the territories referred to in sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Bombay Reorganisation Act, 1960. [cite: 1235]

sub_sections.name: Karnataka
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 7 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 but excluding the territory specified in the Schedule to the Andhra Pradesh and Mysore (Transfer of Territory) Act, 1968. [cite: 1235]

sub_sections.name: Odisha
sub_sections.territories: The territories which immediately before the commencement of this Constitution were either comprised in the Province of Orissa or were being administered as if they formed part of that Province. [cite: 1236]

sub_sections.name: Punjab
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in section 11 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 and the territories referred to in Part II of the First Schedule to the Acquired Territories (Merger) Act, 1960, but excluding the territories referred to in Part II of the First Schedule to the Constitution (Ninth Amendment) Act, 1960 and the territories specified in sub-section (1) of section 3, section 4 and sub-section (1) of section 5 of the Punjab Reorganisation Act, 1966. [cite: 1236]

sub_sections.name: Rajasthan
sub_sections.territories: The territories specified in section 10 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 but excluding the territories specified in the First Schedule to the Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh (Transfer of Territories) Act, 1959. [cite: 1236]

sub_sections.name: Uttar Pradesh

article_title: Emoluments, Allowances, and Privileges for President and Governors
content: There shall be paid to the President and to the Governors of the States emoluments. The President's emoluments per mensem were specified as 10,000 rupees (now five lakh rupees as per later law)[cite: 1243].  The Governor of a State's emoluments per mensem were specified as 5,500 rupees (now three lakh fifty thousand rupees as per later law)[cite: 1243].  The President and Governors are entitled to such allowances as were payable respectively to the Governor-General of the Dominion of India and to the Governors of the corresponding Provinces immediately before the commencement of the Constitution[cite: 1243].  They are entitled to the same privileges as the Governor-General and Governors of the corresponding Provinces were entitled to immediately before the commencement of the Constitution[cite: 1243].  While the Vice-President or any other person is discharging the functions of, or acting as, President, or any person is discharging the functions of the Governor, he shall be entitled to the same emoluments, allowances and privileges as the President or the Governor, as the case may be[cite: 1243].

sub_sections.text: Emoluments (specified rates for President/Governor)[cite: 1243].
Allowances as payable to the Governor-General/Provincial Governors before commencement[cite: 1243].
Privileges as enjoyed by the Governor-General/Provincial Governors before commencement[cite: 1243].
Entitlement to same emoluments, allowances, and privileges while acting as President or Governor[cite: 1243].

amendments_notes: Part B (Provisions as to the Rajpramukhs) was omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1243].  Note that salaries have been subsequently raised by Acts of Parliament (cited in the footnotes)[cite: 1243].

article_title: Salaries and Allowances for Presiding Officers
content: The Speaker of the House of the People and the Chairman of the Council of States shall be paid such salaries and allowances as were payable to the Speaker of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution[cite: 1244].  The Deputy Speaker of the House of the People and the Deputy Chairman of the Council of States shall be paid such salaries and allowances as were payable to the Deputy Speaker of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India immediately before such commencement[cite: 1244].  The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly and the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council of a State shall be paid salaries and allowances as were payable respectively to the corresponding officers of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of the corresponding Province immediately before the commencement of this Constitution[cite: 1244].  Where the corresponding Province had no Legislative Council, the Governor of the State shall determine the salaries and allowances for the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council[cite: 1244].

sub_sections.text: Salaries and allowances for the Speaker/Chairman and Deputy Speaker/Deputy Chairman of Parliament determined by pre-commencement Constituent Assembly rates[cite: 1244].
Salaries and allowances for the presiding officers of State Legislatures determined by pre-commencement Provincial rates[cite: 1244].

article_title: Salaries and Rights of Judges
content: Judges of the Supreme Court shall be paid salary at specified rates per mensem (Chief Justice at 10,000 rupees and other Judges at 9,000 rupees, subject to later revision by law)[cite: 1245].  If a Judge is receiving a pension from previous government service (other than disability/wound pension), his salary is reduced by the amount of that pension, and includes the pension equivalent of any commuted pension value or retirement gratuity received[cite: 1245].  Judges of the Supreme Court are entitled to the free use of an official residence[cite: 1245].  Judges receive reasonable allowances for travelling on duty and facilities as the President prescribes[cite: 1246].  Rights in respect of leave of absence and pension are governed by the provisions applicable to the Judges of the Federal Court immediately before the commencement of the Constitution[cite: 1246].  Judges of High Courts shall be paid salary at specified rates per mensem (Chief Justice at 9,000 rupees and other Judges at 8,000 rupees, subject to later revision by law)[cite: 1246, 1247].  Similar provisions apply regarding salary reduction due to prior pension/gratuity[cite: 1247].  Special pay provisions were included for Federal Court Judges who became Supreme Court Judges and for Chief Justices of Part B State High Courts who became Chief Justices of High Courts after the 7th Amendment[cite: 1246, 1247, 1248].  The privileges, allowances, and rights in respect of leave or pension of a Judge shall not be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment[cite: 1245, 1247].  'Actual service' is defined to include time spent on duty, functions undertaken at the President's request, vacations (excluding leave time), and joining time on transfer[cite: 1248].

sub_sections.text: SC Judges' salaries (with pension reduction formula)[cite: 1245].
SC Judges' right to an official residence[cite: 1245].
HC Judges' salaries (with pension reduction formula)[cite: 1246, 1247].
Definition of 'actual service'[cite: 1248].

amendments_notes: Salaries were raised by the Constitution (Fifty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1986, and further by the High Court and Supreme Court Judges (Salaries and Conditions of Service) Amendment Act, 2018[cite: 1245, 1246, 1247].

article_title: Salaries and Rights of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (CAG)
content: The Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (CAG) shall be paid a salary at the rate of four thousand rupees per mensem (now equal to the salary of a Supreme Court Judge by later law)[cite: 1249].  The person who became the CAG at the commencement of the Constitution (from the office of Auditor-General of India) was entitled to special pay equal to the difference between his old salary and the new rate[cite: 1249].  The rights in respect of leave of absence and pension and the other conditions of service of the CAG are governed by the provisions applicable to the Auditor-General of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution[cite: 1249].

sub_sections.text: CAG's salary (originally Rs. 4,000, now equal to a Supreme Court Judge)[cite: 1249].
CAG's conditions of service (leave, pension, etc.) governed by pre-commencement provisions[cite: 1249].

amendments_notes: The salary amount has been revised by Acts of Parliament (cited in the footnotes)[cite: 1249].

part_title: THIRD SCHEDULE - Forms of Oaths or Affirmations
article_title: Form of oath of office for a Minister for the Union.
content: The prescribed oath includes pledging true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established [cite: 1249] , upholding the sovereignty and integrity of India [cite: 1249] , faithfully and conscientiously discharging duties as a Minister for the Union [cite: 1249] , and doing right to all manner of people in accordance with the Constitution and the law, without fear or favour, affection or ill-will[cite: 1249].

sub_sections.text: Pledge to bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution and uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India.
Pledge to faithfully and conscientiously discharge duties as a Minister for the Union.
Pledge to do right to all people in accordance with the Constitution and law, without bias.

amendments_notes: The phrase 'that I will uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India,' was inserted by the Constitution (Sixteenth Amendment) Act, 1963[cite: 1249].

part_title: THIRD SCHEDULE - Forms of Oaths or Affirmations
article_title: Form of oath of secrecy for a Minister for the Union.
content: The prescribed oath involves pledging not to directly or indirectly communicate or reveal any matter that shall be brought under consideration or become known to the Minister for the Union, except as may be required for the due discharge of duties as such Minister[cite: 1249].

sub_sections.text: Pledge of secrecy regarding all matters known as a Minister, except as required for due discharge of duties.

content: The prescribed oath for a candidate involves pledging to bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and upholding the sovereignty and integrity of India[cite: 1250].

sub_sections.text: Pledge to bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution and uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India.

Pledge to faithfully discharge the duty as a member of Parliament.

part_title: FOURTH SCHEDULE - Allocation of seats in the Council of States
article_title: Allocation of Seats to States and Union Territories
content: This Schedule, pursuant to Articles 4(1) and 80(2), details the number of seats allotted in the Council of States to each State and Union territory. The total number of seats currently allocated is 233[cite: 1255].
amendments_notes: The Schedule was substituted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956[cite: 1253].  The entries have been extensively re-numbered and updated by various subsequent Reorganisation and Amendment Acts to reflect new States (e.g., Goa [cite: 1253] , Nagaland [cite: 1254] , Chhattisgarh [cite: 1254] , Jharkhand [cite: 1254] , Telangana [cite: 1253] ) and Union territories (e.g., Jammu and Kashmir, Ladakh - though Ladakh is not listed with a seat allocation in the table itself [cite: 1255]).

part_title: FIFTH SCHEDULE - Provisions as to the Administration and Control of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes
article_title: Interpretation, Executive Power, and Governor's Report
content: In this Schedule, the expression 'State' does not include the States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram[cite: 1256].  The executive power of a State extends to the Scheduled Areas therein[cite: 1256].  The Governor of each State having Scheduled Areas shall annually, or whenever required by the President, report to the President regarding the administration of the Scheduled Areas[cite: 1256, 1257].  The executive power of the Union extends to giving directions to the State as to the administration of these areas[cite: 1256].

sub_sections.text: Interpretation: 'State' excludes Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram[cite: 1256].
Executive power of a State extends to its Scheduled Areas[cite: 1256].
Governor reports annually (or when required) to the President on Scheduled Areas administration[cite: 1256, 1257].  Union can give directions to the State on this administration[cite: 1256].

article_title: Tribes Advisory Council and Law Application
content: A Tribes Advisory Council (TAC) must be established in each State having Scheduled Areas, and optionally in any State having Scheduled Tribes but no Scheduled Areas, consisting of not more than twenty members (about three-fourths are representatives of Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assembly)[cite: 1257].  The TAC advises on matters pertaining to the welfare and advancement of the Scheduled Tribes[cite: 1257].  The Governor makes rules regarding the composition, procedure, and officers of the TAC[cite: 1257].  The Governor may, by public notification, direct that any particular Act of Parliament or the State Legislature shall not apply to a Scheduled Area, or shall apply subject to specified exceptions and modifications[cite: 1257].  The Governor may make regulations for the peace and good government of any Scheduled Area, specifically to: prohibit/restrict the transfer of land by/among Scheduled Tribes; regulate the allotment of land to Scheduled Tribes; and regulate money-lending to Scheduled Tribes[cite: 1257, 1258].  The Governor's regulations may repeal or amend any existing law applicable to the area[cite: 1258].  All regulations must be submitted to the President for assent[cite: 1258].

sub_sections.text: Constitution of a Tribes Advisory Council (TAC) (max 20 members, majority from ST members of the LA)[cite: 1257].  TAC advises the Governor on ST welfare[cite: 1257].
Governor may exclude or modify the application of Union or State laws to a Scheduled Area[cite: 1257].
Governor may make regulations for peace and good government, specifically targeting: land transfer/allotment, and money-lending for Scheduled Tribes[cite: 1257, 1258].
Regulations require Presidential assent[cite: 1258].

article_title: Designation and Alteration of Scheduled Areas
content: Scheduled Areas means such areas as the President may by order declare to be Scheduled Areas[cite: 1258].  The President may at any time by order: direct that a whole/part of a Scheduled Area ceases to be one; increase the area of any Scheduled Area (after consulting the Governor); alter boundaries only by rectification; or, on alteration of State boundaries/establishment of a new State, declare any territory to be a Scheduled Area[cite: 1258, 1259].  The President may also rescind and make fresh orders (in consultation with the Governor) redefining the Scheduled Areas[cite: 1259].

sub_sections.text: Scheduled Areas are areas declared as such by the President's order[cite: 1258].
President's power to modify/alter Scheduled Areas (e.g., exclude area, increase area, alter boundaries, redefine areas)[cite: 1258, 1259].

amendments_notes: Provisions for increasing the area and rescinding/making fresh orders inserted by the Fifth Schedule to the Constitution (Amendment) Act, 1976[cite: 1258, 1259].

article_title: Amendment Power
content: Parliament may from time to time by law amend by way of addition, variation or repeal any of the provisions of this Schedule.  No such law shall be deemed to be an amendment of the Constitution for the purposes of article 368[cite: 1259].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to amend the Schedule by law[cite: 1259].
An amendment is not considered a Constitutional amendment under Article 368[cite: 1259].

article_title: Autonomous districts and autonomous regions.
content: Subject to this paragraph, the tribal areas in Parts I, II, IIA, and III of the appended table shall be an autonomous district[cite: 1260].  If there are different Scheduled Tribes in an autonomous district, the Governor may divide the area into autonomous regions[cite: 1260].  The Governor may, by public notification, include any area in, or exclude any area from, any Part of the table; create a new autonomous district; increase or diminish the area of any autonomous district; unite two or more autonomous districts; alter the name; or define the boundaries[cite: 1260].  Orders to create, increase/diminish, or unite districts require the consideration of a report from a Commission appointed under Paragraph 14[cite: 1261].

sub_sections.text: Tribal areas in the table are autonomous districts.
Governor may divide autonomous districts into autonomous regions.
Governor's power to modify districts and areas (creation, inclusion, exclusion, alteration of name/boundaries).

amendments_notes: References to States and parts of the table have been substituted multiple times.

article_title: Constitution of District Councils and Regional Councils.
content: There shall be a District Council for each autonomous district, consisting of not more than thirty members, of whom not more than four persons shall be nominated by the Governor and the rest shall be elected on the basis of adult suffrage[cite: 1261].  There shall be a separate Regional Council for each autonomous region[cite: 1262].  Each Council is a body corporate with perpetual succession and a common seal[cite: 1262].  The administration of a district is vested in its District Council (unless vested in a Regional Council)[cite: 1262].  Elected members of the District Council hold office for five years[cite: 1263].  The Governor makes initial rules for the first constitution of the Councils (consulting existing tribal organizations)[cite: 1262].  The Councils may make their own rules (with the Governor's approval) regarding composition, elections, procedure, subordinate bodies, and administration[cite: 1263, 1264].

sub_sections.text: District Council (max 30 members): max 4 nominated by Governor, rest elected by adult suffrage.
Each Council is a body corporate.
Administration is vested in the District or Regional Council.
Governor makes initial rules for constitution.
Elected members' term is five years (with emergency extension provision)[cite: 1263].
Councils may make rules (with Governor's approval).

amendments_notes: Sub-paragraph (1) and (6A) substituted/inserted by later Acts.

article_title: Powers of the District Councils and Regional Councils to make laws.
content: District and Regional Councils have the power to make laws on: the allotment/use of non-reserved forest land (for agriculture, grazing, residence, etc.) [cite: 1267] ; the management of non-reserved forest [cite: 1267] ; the use of canals/water-courses for agriculture; the regulation of jhum (shifting) cultivation; the establishment of village/town committees and their powers; other matters related to village/town administration (including police and health/sanitation); the appointment/succession of Chiefs or Headmen; the inheritance of property; marriage and divorce; and social customs[cite: 1267].  Laws regarding land use must not prevent compulsory acquisition of land for public purposes by the concerned State Government[cite: 1267].  All laws made under this paragraph must be submitted forthwith to the Governor and shall have no effect until assented to by him[cite: 1268].

sub_sections.text: Councils have legislative power over land, forests (non-reserved), water, shifting cultivation, village/town administration, traditional governance (Chiefs/Headmen), inheritance, marriage/divorce, and social customs.
Does not prevent compulsory acquisition of land for public purposes.
Laws require the Governor's assent to take effect.

amendments_notes: Clause (i) (marriage and divorce) substituted by the Assam Reorganisation (Meghalaya) Act, 1969. The operation of this paragraph is supplemented for certain Assam Councils by Paragraph 3A and 3B, details of which are in the source material[cite: 1264, 1265, 1266].

article_title: Administration of justice in autonomous districts and autonomous regions.
content: District and Regional Councils may constitute village councils or courts for the trial of suits and cases between all parties belonging to Scheduled Tribes (excluding certain major cases, see Para 5), removing the jurisdiction of other courts in the State[cite: 1268].  The Regional or District Council (or courts constituted by them) shall exercise the powers of a court of appeal in respect of all cases triable by a village council or court, excluding major cases (see Para 5)[cite: 1268].  The High Court shall have such jurisdiction over these suits and cases as the Governor may specify[cite: 1269].  Councils may make rules (with the Governor's approval) regulating the constitution, powers, and procedure of these councils/courts, and enforcement of their decisions[cite: 1269].

sub_sections.text: Councils may constitute village councils/courts for inter-Scheduled Tribe disputes.
Council/Council-courts serve as the court of appeal (excluding High Court and Supreme Court jurisdiction over these specific cases).
High Court jurisdiction is specified by the Governor.
Councils may make rules for the courts (with Governor's approval).

article_title: Conferment of powers under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, and the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, on the Regional and District Councils and on certain courts and officers for the trial of certain suits, cases and offences.
content: The Governor may confer on the District or Regional Council, or courts constituted by them, or any appointed officer, powers under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, or the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (now 1973 Code), for the trial of suits/cases arising out of specified laws, or for trial of offences punishable with death, transportation for life, or imprisonment for not less than five years under the Indian Penal Code or any other law applicable to the district/region[cite: 1270].  The Governor may withdraw or modify these conferred powers[cite: 1270].  Generally, the Civil and Criminal Procedure Codes do not apply to the trial of suits, cases, or offences in an autonomous district or region to which this paragraph applies[cite: 1270].

sub_sections.text: Governor may confer CPC/CrPC powers on Councils/courts/officers for specified civil/criminal trials.
The CPC and CrPC generally do not apply to the trials mentioned in this paragraph.

amendments_notes: Sub-paragraph (4) was inserted regarding the cessation of the Governor's power to confer certain powers after Paragraph 4(5) comes into effect.

article_title: Powers of the District Council to establish primary schools, etc.
content: The District Council may establish, construct, or manage primary schools, dispensaries, markets, cattle pounds, ferries, fisheries, roads, road transport and waterways in the district[cite: 1271].  The Council may, with the previous approval of the Governor, make regulations for their regulation and control, and may prescribe the language and manner of primary education imparted in the district's primary schools[cite: 1271].  The Governor may, with the consent of any District Council, entrust it with functions in relation to agriculture, animal husbandry, co-operative societies, and other matters to which the executive power of the State extends[cite: 1271].

sub_sections.text: District Council power to establish and manage public utilities (schools, dispensaries, roads, etc.) and regulate them (with Governor's approval).
Governor may entrust State executive functions to the District Council (with consent).

article_title: District and Regional Funds.
content: A District Fund and a Regional Fund shall be constituted for each respective Council, into which all moneys received during administration are credited[cite: 1271].  The Governor may make rules for the management of these Funds, including payment, withdrawal, and custody of moneys[cite: 1272].  The accounts of the Councils shall be kept in the form prescribed by the Comptroller and Auditor-General (CAG) with the President's approval[cite: 1272].  The CAG causes the accounts to be audited, and the audit reports are submitted to the Governor, who lays them before the Council[cite: 1272].

sub_sections.text: Constitution of District and Regional Funds.
Governor makes rules for Fund management.
Accounts kept in the form prescribed by the CAG/President.
CAG audits accounts; report laid before the Council by the Governor.

amendments_notes: Sub-paragraphs (2), (3), and (4) substituted for the original sub-paragraph (2).

article_title: Powers to assess and collect land revenue and to impose taxes.
content: District and Regional Councils have the power to assess and collect revenue in respect of lands (excluding reserved forest areas) in accordance with the principles followed by the Government of the State for land revenue generally[cite: 1272].  They also have the power to levy and collect taxes on lands and buildings, and tolls on persons resident within the areas[cite: 1272].  District Councils may also levy and collect taxes on: professions, trades, callings and employments; animals, vehicles and boats; entry of goods into a market, and tolls on passengers/goods carried in ferries; taxes for maintenance of schools, dispensaries, or roads; and taxes on entertainment and amusements[cite: 1273].  Regulations made for the levy and collection of these taxes must be submitted forthwith to the Governor and shall have no effect until assented to by him[cite: 1273].

sub_sections.text: Power to assess and collect land revenue.
Power to levy taxes on lands and buildings, and tolls on persons.
Additional taxes leviable by District Councils (professions, animals, markets, education, entertainment)[cite: 1273].
Tax regulations require the Governor's assent.

amendments_notes: Tax list in clause (3) amended by the Constitution (One Hundred and First Amendment) Act, 2016.

article_title: Licences or leases for the purpose of prospecting for, or extraction of, minerals.
content: The share of royalties accruing each year from mineral licences/leases granted by the Government of the State in autonomous districts, as agreed upon between the State Government and the District Council, shall be made over to the Council[cite: 1273].  Any dispute over the share of royalties shall be referred to the Governor, whose determination is final[cite: 1274].

sub_sections.text: Share of mineral royalties (as agreed) is made over to the District Council.
Disputes over royalty share are finally determined by the Governor.

article_title: Power of District Council to make regulations for the control of money-lending and trading by non-tribals.
content: The District Council may make regulations for the regulation and control of money-lending or trading within the district by persons other than Scheduled Tribes resident in the district[cite: 1274].  Regulations may, in particular, prescribe that a licence is mandatory for money-lending, set the maximum rate of interest, provide for accounts maintenance/inspection, and prescribe a licence for wholesale/retail business by non-ST residents[cite: 1274, 1275].  Such regulations require a three-fourths majority of the total membership of the District Council and must be submitted to the Governor for assent[cite: 1275].

sub_sections.text: Power to regulate money-lending and trading by non-tribals.
Specific regulatory powers (licensing, interest rates, accounts, business licensing).
Regulations require a three-fourths majority.
Regulations require the Governor's assent.

amendments_notes: Note: In Tripura and Mizoram, the requirement for regulations to cover 'non-tribals' has been omitted, extending the scope to all residents, but the primary PDF text focuses on non-tribals for general application.

article_title: Publication of laws, rules and regulations made under the Schedule.
content: All laws, rules and regulations made under this Schedule by a District Council or a Regional Council shall be published forthwith in the Official Gazette of the State and shall on such publication have the force of law[cite: 1275].

article_title: Application of Acts of Parliament and of the Legislature of the State of Assam to autonomous districts and autonomous regions in the State of Assam.
content: No Act of the Legislature of Assam regarding matters listed in Paragraph 3 (Council legislative subjects) or prohibiting/restricting non-distilled alcoholic liquor shall apply to any autonomous district/region in Assam unless the relevant District Council directs by public notification (with power to specify exceptions/modifications)[cite: 1276].  The Governor may direct that any other Act of Parliament or the Legislature of Assam shall not apply, or apply with exceptions/modifications, to an autonomous district/region[cite: 1276].  Any direction given by the Governor may be given retrospective effect[cite: 1276].

sub_sections.text: Assam Legislature Acts (on Council's subjects or liquor) require District Council notification to apply.
Governor may modify the application of other Parliament/Assam Legislature Acts.
Directions under this paragraph may have retrospective effect.

amendments_notes: Paragraph heading and text substituted by the North-Eastern Areas (Reorganisation) Act, 1971. The subject matters in clause (1)(a) have been updated by subsequent Assam amendments.

article_title: Application of Acts of Parliament and of the Legislature of Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram to autonomous districts and autonomous regions.
content: For **Meghalaya (12A)**, if a law/regulation made by a District/Regional Council is repugnant to a law made by the State Legislature (on the same matter under Para 3, 8, or 10), the State Legislature's law prevails, and the Council's law is void to the extent of repugnancy[cite: 1277].  The President may, by notification, modify the application of any Act of Parliament to autonomous areas in Meghalaya[cite: 1277].  For **Tripura (12AA)** and **Mizoram (12B)**, Parliament's Acts are modified by the President, and State Legislature Acts (on Council's subjects or liquor) require District Council notification to apply (similar to Assam)[cite: 1277, 1278, 1279].

sub_sections.text: Meghalaya Repugnancy Rule: State Legislature law prevails over Council law on Concurrent matters.
Tripura/Mizoram Legislature Acts (on Council's subjects or liquor) require District Council notification to apply.
President may modify the application of any Act of Parliament to Tripura and Mizoram areas.

amendments_notes: Paragraph 12A substituted by the North-Eastern Areas (Reorganisation) Act, 1971. Paragraphs 12AA and 12B inserted/substituted by the 49th Amendment, 1984, and the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution (Amendment) Act, 1988.

article_title: Estimated receipts and expenditure pertaining to autonomous districts to be shown separately in the annual financial statement.
content: The estimated receipts and expenditure pertaining to an autonomous district which are to be credited to, or made from, the Consolidated Fund of the State shall be first placed before the District Council for discussion and then shown separately in the annual financial statement (budget) of the State laid before the State Legislature[cite: 1279].

sub_sections.text: District-related estimates must be discussed by the District Council and shown separately in the State's annual financial statement.

article_title: Appointment of Commission to inquire into and report on the administration of autonomous districts and autonomous regions.
content: The Governor may at any time appoint a Commission to examine and report on any matter relating to the administration of autonomous districts/regions, including: boundary modifications (Para 1(3)(c-f)); provision of educational/medical facilities and communications; need for new/special legislation; and the administration of laws/rules/regulations made by the Councils[cite: 1280].  The report of every such Commission, along with the Governor's recommendations, shall be laid before the State Legislature by the Minister concerned, together with a memorandum regarding the action proposed to be taken by the State Government[cite: 1280].  The Governor may place one of his Ministers specially in charge of the welfare of the autonomous districts/regions[cite: 1280].

sub_sections.text: Governor's power to appoint a Commission to report on administration and welfare matters.
Commission's report and Governor's recommendations laid before the State Legislature.
Governor may appoint a Minister specially in charge of autonomous areas welfare.

article_title: Annulment or suspension of acts and resolutions of District and Regional Councils.
content: If the Governor is satisfied that an act or resolution of a Council is likely to endanger the safety of India or be prejudicial to public order, he may annul or suspend such act/resolution and take necessary steps (including the suspension of the Council and assumption of its powers) to prevent its commission/continuance/effect[cite: 1280, 1281].  Any such order, with the reasons, must be laid before the State Legislature and continues in force for twelve months unless revoked by the Legislature (renewable for further twelve-month periods by Legislative resolution)[cite: 1281].

sub_sections.text: Governor's power to annul/suspend Council acts/resolutions endangering India's safety or public order.
Governor's order must be laid before the State Legislature and is subject to its approval for continuation.

amendments_notes: Clause (1) amended to include 'prejudicial to public order' by the Assam Reorganisation (Meghalaya) Act, 1969.

article_title: Dissolution of a District or a Regional Council.
content: The Governor may, on the recommendation of a Commission (Para 14), order the dissolution of a Council and: (a) direct a fresh general election, or (b) assume administration himself or place it under a Commission/suitable body for a period not exceeding twelve months (with prior legislative approval)[cite: 1281].  No assumption of administration can be made without giving the Council an opportunity to present its views to the State Legislature[cite: 1281].  If the Governor is satisfied that the administration cannot be carried on in accordance with the Schedule, he may assume the functions/powers of the Council for a period not exceeding six months, extendable by further orders (max six months each)[cite: 1282].  Every such order must be laid before the State Legislature and ceases after thirty days of the Legislature first sitting, unless approved[cite: 1282].

sub_sections.text: Dissolution power based on Commission recommendation (followed by election or assumption of administration).
Governor's power to assume administration if it cannot be carried on (for up to six months, extendable).
Assumption of administration order requires legislative approval.

amendments_notes: Sub-paragraphs (2) and (3) added by the Assam Reorganisation (Meghalaya) Act, 1969.

article_title: Exclusion of areas from autonomous districts in forming constituencies in such districts.
content: For the purposes of elections to the Legislative Assembly of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, or Mizoram, the Governor may order that any area within an autonomous district shall not form part of any constituency to fill a seat reserved for that district, but shall form part of a constituency to fill an unreserved seat[cite: 1282].

sub_sections.text: Governor's power to exclude areas from reserved constituencies and include them in general constituencies for LA elections.

amendments_notes: Paragraph 17 amended to include Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram.

article_title: Transitional provisions.
content: As soon as possible after the commencement of the Constitution, the Governor was to take steps for the constitution of a District Council for each autonomous district.  Until a Council was constituted, the administration of the district was vested in the Governor[cite: 1283].  During this interim period, no Act of Parliament or the State Legislature applied unless directed by the Governor (with power to specify exceptions/modifications)[cite: 1283].  The Governor could make regulations for peace and good government, repealing/amending existing laws[cite: 1283].  All such regulations required the President's assent[cite: 1284].

sub_sections.text: Interim administration vested in the Governor until District Councils were constituted.
Governor modified application of laws during the interim period.
Governor made interim regulations for peace and good government.
Interim regulations required the President's assent.

amendments_notes: Sub-paragraph (4) was inserted for the Bodoland Territorial Areas District.

article_title: Tribal areas.
content: The areas specified in Parts I, II, IIA and III of the appended table are the tribal areas within the States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram, respectively[cite: 1284].  Any reference to a district in Parts I, II, or III of the table is construed as a reference to the territories comprised within the autonomous district of that name existing immediately before the North-Eastern Areas (Reorganisation) Act, 1971[cite: 1284].  **Part I** lists: The North Cachar Hills District, The Karbi Anglong District, and The Bodoland Territorial Areas District[cite: 1285].  **Part II** lists: Khasi Hills District, Jaintia Hills District, and The Garo Hills District[cite: 1285].  **Part IIA** lists: Tripura Tribal Areas District[cite: 1285].  **Part III** lists: The Chakma District, The Mara District, and The Lai District[cite: 1285].

sub_sections.text: Designation of autonomous areas by Part and State.
Interpretation of 'district' names (referring to pre-1971 boundaries/names).
Specific names of autonomous districts in: Part I (Assam), Part II (Meghalaya), Part IIA (Tripura), and Part III (Mizoram)[cite: 1285].

amendments_notes: Paragraph substituted/amended multiple times, most significantly by the North-Eastern Areas (Reorganisation) Act, 1971, and the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution (Amendment) Act, 2003.

article_title: Amendment of the Schedule.
content: Parliament may from time to time by law amend by way of addition, variation or repeal any of the provisions of this Schedule[cite: 1289].  No such law shall be deemed to be an amendment of the Constitution for the purposes of article 368[cite: 1289].

sub_sections.text: Parliament's power to amend the Schedule by law.
An amendment is not considered a Constitutional amendment under Article 368.

article_title: Matters of Union Legislative Jurisdiction (Parliament has exclusive power)
content: List I covers 97 matters (entries 1-96, including residuary powers at entry 97 [cite: 1296]) over which Parliament has exclusive power to make laws (Article 246(1) ). Key areas include Defence, Foreign Affairs, Railways, Currency, Banking, Union Taxes, and the Supreme Court.

sub_sections.text: Defence of India and every part thereof.
Naval, military and air forces; any other armed forces of the Union.

Deployment of any armed force of the Union or any other force subject to the control of the Union or any contingent or unit thereof in any State in aid of the civil power; powers, jurisdiction, privileges and liabilities of the members of such forces while on such deployment.

Delimitation of cantonment areas, local self-government in such areas, the constitution and powers within such areas of cantonment authorities and the regulation of house accommodation (including the control of rents) in such areas.
Naval, military and air force works.
Arms, firearms, ammunition and explosives.
Atomic energy and mineral resources necessary for its production.
Industries declared by Parliament by law to be necessary for the purpose of defence or for the prosecution of war.
Central Bureau of Intelligence and Investigation.
Preventive detention for reasons connected with Defence, Foreign Affairs, or the security of India; persons subjected to such detention.
Foreign affairs; all matters which bring the Union into relation with any foreign country.
Diplomatic, consular and trade representation.
United Nations Organisation.
Participation in international conferences, associations and other bodies and implementing of decisions made thereat.
Entering into treaties and agreements with foreign countries and implementing of treaties, agreements and conventions with foreign countries.
War and peace.
Foreign jurisdiction.
Citizenship, naturalisation and aliens.
Extradition.
Admission into, and emigration and expulsion from, India; passports and visas.
Pilgrimages to places outside India.
Piracies and crimes committed on the high seas or in the air; offences against the law of nations committed on land or the high seas or in the air.
Railways.
Highways declared by or under law made by Parliament to be national highways.
Shipping and navigation on inland waterways, declared by Parliament by law to be national waterways, as regards mechanically propelled vessels; the rule of the road on such waterways.

Maritime shipping and navigation, including shipping and navigation on tidal waters; provision of education and training for the mercantile marine and regulation of such education and training provided by States and other agencies.
Lighthouses, including lightships, beacons and other provision for the safety of shipping and aircraft.
Ports declared by or under law made by Parliament or existing law to be major ports, including their delimitation, and the constitution and powers of port authorities therein.

sub_sections.text_content: Port quarantine, including hospitals connected therewith; seamen's and marine hospitals.

sub_sections.text: Airways; aircraft and air navigation; provision of aerodromes; regulation and organisation of air traffic and of aerodromes; provision for aeronautical education and training and regulation of such education and training provided by States and other agencies.
Carriage of passengers and goods by railway, sea or air, or by national waterways in mechanically propelled vessels.
Posts and telegraphs; telephones, wireless, broadcasting and other like forms of communication.
Property of the Union and the revenue therefrom, but as regards property situated in a State subject to legislation by the State, save in so far as Parliament by law otherwise provides[cite: 1292].
Entry 33 was omitted[cite: 1292].
Courts of wards for the estates of Rulers of Indian States.
Public debt of the Union.
Currency, coinage and legal tender; foreign exchange.
Foreign loans.
Reserve Bank of India.
Post Office Savings Bank.
Lotteries organised by the Government of India or the Government of a State.
Trade and commerce with foreign countries; import and export across customs frontiers; definition of customs frontiers.
Inter-State trade and commerce.
Incorporation, regulation and winding up of trading corporations, including banking, insurance and financial corporations, but not including co-operative societies.
Incorporation, regulation and winding up of corporations, whether trading or not, with objects not confined to one State, but not including universities.
Banking.
Bills of exchange, cheques, promissory notes and other like instruments.
Insurance.
Stock exchanges and futures markets.
Patents, inventions and designs; copyright; trade-marks and merchandise marks.
Establishment of standards of weight and measure.
Establishment of standards of quality for goods to be exported out of India or transported from one State to another.
Industries, the control of which by the Union is declared by Parliament by law to be expedient in the public interest.
Regulation and development of oilfields and mineral oil resources; petroleum and petroleum products; other liquids and substances declared by Parliament by law to be dangerously inflammable.

Regulation of mines and mineral development to the extent to which such regulation and development under the control of the Union is declared by Parliament by law to be expedient in the public interest.
Regulation of labour and safety in mines and oilfields.

Regulation and development of inter-State rivers and river valleys to the extent to which such regulation and development under the control of the Union is declared by Parliament by law to be expedient in the public interest.
Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters.
Manufacture, supply and distribution of salt by Union agencies; regulation and control of manufacture, supply and distribution of salt by other agencies.
Cultivation, manufacture, and sale for export, of opium.
Sanctioning of cinematograph films for exhibition.
Industrial disputes concerning Union employees.

The institutions known at the commencement of this Constitution as the National Library, the Indian Museum, the Imperial War Museum, the Victoria Memorial and the Indian War Memorial, and any other like institution financed by the Government of India wholly or in part and declared by Parliament by law to be an institution of national importance.

The institutions known at the commencement of this Constitution as the Benares Hindu University, the Aligarh Muslim University and the Delhi University; the University established in pursuance of article 371E; any other institution declared by Parliament by law to be an institution of national importance[cite: 1293].
Institutions for scientific or technical education financed by the Government of India wholly or in part and declared by Parliament by law to be institutions of national importance.

Union agencies and institutions for professional, vocational or technical training, the promotion of special studies or research, or scientific or technical assistance in the investigation or detection of crime.
Co-ordination and determination of standards in institutions for higher education or research and scientific and technical institutions.
Ancient and historical monuments and records, and archaeological sites and remains, declared by or under law made by Parliament to be of national importance[cite: 1294].
The Survey of India, the Geological, Botanical, Zoological and Anthropological Surveys of India; Meteorological organisations.
Census.
Union Public Service; All-India Services; Union Public Service Commission.
Union pensions, that is to say, pensions payable by the Government of India or out of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Elections to Parliament, to the Legislatures of States and to the offices of President and Vice-President; the Election Commission.
Salaries and allowances of members of Parliament, the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People.

Powers, privileges and immunities of each House of Parliament and of the members and the Committees of each House; enforcement of attendance of persons for giving evidence or producing documents before committees of Parliament or commissions appointed by Parliament.

Emoluments, allowances, privileges, and rights in respect of leave of absence, of the President and Governors; salaries and allowances of the Ministers for the Union; the salaries, allowances, and rights in respect of leave of absence and other conditions of service of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.
Audit of the accounts of the Union and of the States.
Constitution, organisation, jurisdiction and powers of the Supreme Court (including contempt of such Court), and the fees taken therein; persons entitled to practise before the Supreme Court.
Constitution and organisation (including vacations) of the High Courts except provisions as to officers and servants of High Courts; persons entitled to practise before the High Courts[cite: 1295].
Extension of the jurisdiction of a High Court to, and exclusion of the jurisdiction of a High Court from, any Union territory[cite: 1295].

Extension of the powers and jurisdiction of members of a police force belonging to any State to any area outside that State (with conditions); extension of police powers/jurisdiction to railway areas outside that State.
Inter-State migration; inter-State quarantine.
Taxes on income other than agricultural income.
Duties of customs including export duties.

Duties of excise on the following goods manufactured or produced in India: petroleum crude; high speed diesel; motor spirit (petrol); natural gas; aviation turbine fuel; and tobacco and tobacco products[cite: 1295].
Corporation tax.
Taxes on the capital value of the assets, exclusive of agricultural land, of individuals and companies; taxes on the capital of companies.
Estate duty in respect of property other than agricultural land.
Duties in respect of succession to property other than agricultural land.
Terminal taxes on goods or passengers, carried by railway, sea or air; taxes on railway fares and freights.
Taxes other than stamp duties on transactions in stock exchanges and futures markets.
Rates of stamp duty in respect of bills of exchange, cheques, promissory notes, bills of lading, letters of credit, policies of insurance, transfer of shares, debentures, proxies and receipts.
Entry 92 was omitted[cite: 1296].
Taxes on the sale or purchase of goods other than newspapers, where such sale or purchase takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce[cite: 1296].

Taxes on the consignments of goods (whether the consignment is to the person making it or to any other person), where such consignment takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce[cite: 1296].
Entry 92C was omitted[cite: 1296].
Offences against laws with respect to any of the matters in this List.
Inquires, surveys and statistics for the purpose of any of the matters in this List.
Jurisdiction and powers of all courts, except the Supreme Court, with respect to any of the matters in this List; admiralty jurisdiction.
Fees in respect of any of the matters in this List, but not including fees taken in any court.
Any other matter not enumerated in List II or List III including any tax not mentioned in either of those Lists (Residuary Power).

amendments_notes: Entries 2A, 33, 79, 84, 92, 92A, 92B, and 92C reflect key amendments, including the introduction of GST-related modifications (2016) and the division of subjects between lists.

article_title: Matters of State Legislative Jurisdiction (State Legislature has exclusive power)
content: List II covers 66 matters (entries 1-66) over which the State Legislature has exclusive power to make laws (Article 246(3) ). Key areas include Public Order, Police, Local Government, Public Health, Agriculture, Land, and State-specific taxes.

sub_sections.text: Public order (excluding use of Union Armed Forces in aid of civil power [cite: 1297]).
Police (including railway and village police) subject to entry 2A of List I[cite: 1297].
Officers and servants of the High Court; procedure in rent and revenue courts; fees taken in all courts except the Supreme Court[cite: 1297].
Prisons, reformatories, Borstal institutions and other institutions of a like nature, and persons detained therein; arrangements with other States for the use of prisons and other institutions.

Local government, that is to say, the constitution and powers of municipal corporations, improvement trusts, districts boards, mining settlement authorities and other local authorities for the purpose of local self-government or village administration.
Public health and sanitation; hospitals and dispensaries.
Pilgrimages, other than pilgrimages to places outside India.
Intoxicating liquors, that is to say, the production, manufacture, possession, transport, purchase and sale of intoxicating liquors.
Relief of the disabled and unemployable.
Burials and burial grounds; cremations and cremation grounds.
Entry 11 was omitted[cite: 1297].

Libraries, museums and other similar institutions controlled or financed by the State; ancient and historical monuments and records other than those declared by or under law made by Parliament to be of national importance[cite: 1297].

Communications, that is to say, roads, bridges, ferries, and other means of communication not specified in List I; municipal tramways; ropeways; inland waterways and traffic thereon (subject to Lists I and III); vehicles other than mechanically propelled vehicles.
Agriculture, including agricultural education and research, protection against pests and prevention of plant diseases.
Preservation, protection and improvement of stock and prevention of animal diseases; veterinary training and practice.
Pounds and the prevention of cattle trespass.
Water, that is to say, water supplies, irrigation and canals, drainage and embankments, water storage and water power subject to the provisions of entry 56 of List I.

Land, that is to say, rights in or over land, land tenures including the relation of landlord and tenant, and the collection of rents; transfer and alienation of agricultural land; land improvement and agricultural loans; colonization.
Entry 19 was omitted[cite: 1298].
Entry 20 was omitted[cite: 1298].
Fisheries.
Courts of wards subject to the provisions of entry 34 of List I; encumbered and attached estates.
Regulation of mines and mineral development subject to the provisions of List I with respect to regulation and development under the control of the Union.
Industries subject to the provisions of entries 7 and 52 of List I[cite: 1298].
Gas and gas-works.
Trade and commerce within the State subject to the provisions of entry 33 of List III.
Production, supply and distribution of goods subject to the provisions of entry 33 of List III.
Markets and fairs.
Entry 29 was omitted[cite: 1299].
Money-lending and money-lenders; relief of agricultural indebtedness.
Inns and inn-keepers.

Incorporation, regulation and winding up of corporations, other than those specified in List I, and universities; unincorporated trading, literary, scientific, religious and other societies and associations; co-operative societies.
Theatres and dramatic performances; cinemas subject to the provisions of entry 60 of List I; sports, entertainments and amusements.
Betting and gambling.
Works, lands and buildings vested in or in the possession of the State.
Entry 36 was omitted[cite: 1299].
Elections to the Legislature of the State subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament.

Salaries and allowances of members of the Legislature of the State, of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly and, if there is a Legislative Council, of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman thereof.

Powers, privileges and immunities of the Legislative Assembly and of the members and the committees thereof, and, if there is a Legislative Council, of that Council and of the members and the committees thereof; enforcement of attendance of persons for giving evidence or producing documents before committees of the Legislature of the State.
Salaries and allowances of Ministers for the State.
State public services; State Public Service Commission.
State pensions, that is to say, pensions payable by the State or out of the Consolidated Fund of the State.
Public debt of the State.
Treasure trove.
Land revenue, including the assessment and collection of revenue, the maintenance of land records, survey for revenue purposes and records of rights, and alienation of revenues.
Taxes on agricultural income.
